paragraphs.original: Enter RODMERIGO and IAGO
paragraphs.translated: RODERIGO and IAGO enter.

paragraphs.original:
Tush! Never tell me. I take it much unkindly
That thou, Iago, who hast had my purse
As if the strings were thine, shouldst know of this.
paragraphs.translated: Come on, don't tell me that. I don't like it that you knew about this, Iago. All this time I've thought you were such a good friend that I've let you spend my money as if it was yours.

paragraphs.original: 'Sblood, but you'll not hear me! If ever I did dream of such a matter, abhor me.
paragraphs.translated: Damn it, you're not listening to me! I never dreamed this was happening - if you find out I did, you can go ahead and hate me.

paragraphs.original:
Thou told'st me
Thou didst hold him in thy hate.
paragraphs.translated: You told me you hated him.

paragraphs.original:
Despise me
If I do not. Three great ones of the city
(In personal suit to make me his lieutenant)
Off-capped to him, and by the faith of man
I know my price, I am worth no worse a place.
But he (as loving his own pride and purposes)
Evades them with a bombast circumstance
Horribly stuffed with epithets of war,
And in conclusion
Nonsuits my mediators. For "Certes," says he,
"I have already chose my officer."
And what was he?
Forsooth, a great arithmetician,
One Michael Cassio, a Florentine
(A fellow almost damned in a fair wife)
That never set a squadron in the field,
Nor the division of a battle knows
More than a spinster - unless the bookish theoric,
paragraphs.translated:
I do hate
him, I swear. Three of Venice's most important noblemen took their hats off to him and asked him humbly to make me his lieutenant, the second in command. And I know my own worth well enough to know I deserve that position. But he wants to have things his own way, so he sidesteps the issue with a lot of military talk and refuses their request. "I've already chosen my lieutenant," he says. And who does he choose? A guy who knows more about numbers than fighting! This guy from Florence named Michael Cassio. He has a pretty wife but he can't even control her. And he's definitely never commanded men in battle. He's got no more hands-on knowledge of warfare than an old woman - unless you count what he's read in books,
him

paragraphs.original:
Wherein the toged consuls can propose
As masterly as he. Mere prattle without practice
Is all his soldiership. But he, sir, had th' election
And I, of whom his eyes had seen the proof
At Rhodes, at Cyprus, and on other grounds
Christian and heathen, must be belee'd and calmed
By debitor and creditor. This counter-caster
He (in good time) must his lieutenant be
And I, bless the mark, his Moorship's ancient.
paragraphs.translated:
which any peace-lover can do. His military understanding is all theory, no practice. But Cassio's been chosen over me. My career is cut short by some bookkeeper, even though the general saw my fighting skills first-hand in Rhodes and Cyprus. This accountant is now lieutenant, while I end up as the
Moor's flag-bearer.
Moor's

paragraphs.original: By heaven, I rather would have been his hangman.
paragraphs.translated: By God, I'd rather be his executioner.

paragraphs.original:
Why, there's no remedy. 'Tis the curse of service.
Preferment goes by letter and affection,
And not by old gradation, where each second
Stood heir to th' first. Now sir, be judge yourself,
Whether I in any just term am affined
To love the Moor.
paragraphs.translated: And there's nothing I can do about it. That's the curse of military service. You get promoted when someone likes you, not because you're next in line. Now, you tell me: should I feel loyal to the Moor?

paragraphs.original: I would not follow him then.
paragraphs.translated: If you don't like him you should quit.

paragraphs.original:
O sir, content you.
I follow him to serve my turn upon him.
We cannot all be masters, nor all masters
Cannot be truly followed. You shall mark
Many a duteous and knee-crooking knave
That (doting on his own obsequious bondage)
Wears out his time much like his master's ass
For naught but provender, and when he's old, cashiered.
Whip me such honest knaves. Others there are
Who, trimmed in forms and visages of duty,
Keep yet their hearts attending on themselves
And, throwing but shows of service on their lords,
Do well thrive by them. And when they have lined their coats,
Do themselves homage. These fellows have some soul,
paragraphs.translated: No, calm down. I'm serving under him to take advantage of him. We can't all be masters, and not all masters should be followed. Look at all the devoted servants who work for their masters their whole lives for nothing but their food, and then when they get old they're terminated. They ought to be whipped for being so stupid. But then there's another kind of servant who looks dutiful and devoted, but who's really looking out for himself. By pretending to serve their lords, these men get rich, and when they've saved up enough they can be their own masters. Guys like that have soul, and that's the kind of guy I am. Let me tell

paragraphs.original:
And such a one do I profess myself. For, sir,
It is as sure as you are Roderigo,
Were I the Moor, I would not be Iago.
In following him, I follow but myself.
Heaven is my judge, not I for love and duty,
But seeming so, for my peculiar end.
For when my outward action doth demonstrate
The native act and figure of my heart
In compliment extern, 'tis not long after
But I will wear my heart upon my sleeve
For daws to peck at. I am not what I am.
paragraphs.translated: you, as sure as your name's Roderigo, if I were the Moor I wouldn't want to be Iago. I may seem to love and obey him, but in fact, I'm just serving him to get what I want. If my outward appearance started reflecting what I really felt, soon enough I'd be wearing my heart on my sleeve for birds to peck at. No, it's better to hide it. I'm not who I appear to be.

paragraphs.original:
What a full fortune does the Thick-lips owe
If he can carry't thus!
paragraphs.translated:
Thick-lips sure is lucky if he can pull this off!
Thick-lips

paragraphs.original:
Call up her father.
Rouse him. Make after him, Poison his delight,
Proclaim him in the streets. Incense her kinsmen,
And, though he in a fertile climate dwell,
Plague him with flies. Though that his joy be joy
Yet throw such changes of vexation on't,
As it may lose some color.
paragraphs.translated: Let's shout up to Desdemona's father, wake him, pester him, spoil his happiness, spread rumors about him in the streets, enrage his relatives, and irritate him endlessly. However real his happiness is, it will vanish in light of this.

paragraphs.original: Here is her father's house, I'll call aloud.
paragraphs.translated: Here's her father's house. I'll call out.

paragraphs.original:
Do, with like timorous accent and dire yell
As when, by night and negligence, the fire
Is spied in populous cities.
paragraphs.translated: Do it, and shout like the city's on fire.

paragraphs.original: What, ho, Brabantio! Signior Brabantio, ho!
paragraphs.translated: Hey, Brabantio! Signor Brabantio, hey!

paragraphs.original:
Awake! What, ho, Brabantio! Thieves! Thieves!
Look to your house, your daughter, and your bags!
Thieves! thieves!
paragraphs.translated: Wake up, Brabantio! Wake up! Thieves! Thieves! Check on your daughter, your house, your money! Thieves! Thieves!

paragraphs.original: Enter BRABANTIO, above
paragraphs.translated: BRABANTIO enters, above.

paragraphs.original:
What is the reason of this terrible summons?
What is the matter there?
paragraphs.translated: What's the reason for this horrible shouting? What's the matter?

paragraphs.original: Signior, is all your family within?
paragraphs.translated: Sir, is everyone in your family at home?

paragraphs.original: Are your doors locked?
paragraphs.translated: Are your doors locked?

paragraphs.original: Why, wherefore ask you this?
paragraphs.translated: Why are you asking me that?

paragraphs.original:
Zounds, sir, you're robbed! For shame, put on your gown.
Your heart is burst, you have lost half your soul.
Even now, now, very now, an old black ram
Is tupping your white ewe. Arise, arise,
Awake the snorting citizens with the bell
Or else the devil will make a grandsire of you.
Arise, I say!
paragraphs.translated: For God's sake, sir, you've been robbed. Get dressed. Your heart's going to break. It's like half your soul's been ripped out. At this very minute an old black ram is having sex with your little white lamb. Wake up, wake up, ring a bell and wake up all the snoring citizens. If you wait too long you'll have black grandchildren. Get up, I tell you!

paragraphs.original: What, have you lost your wits?
paragraphs.translated: Are you crazy?

paragraphs.original: Most reverend signior, do you know my voice?
paragraphs.translated: Do you recognize my voice, noble lord?

paragraphs.original: Not I. What are you?
paragraphs.translated: Not me. Who are you?

paragraphs.original: My name is Roderigo.
paragraphs.translated: My name's Roderigo.

paragraphs.original:
The worser welcome.
I have charged thee not to haunt about my doors.
In honest plainness thou hast heard me say
My daughter is not for thee. And now in madness,
Being full of supper and distempering drafts,
Upon malicious knavery dost thou come
To start my quiet?
paragraphs.translated: I told you not to hang around my house. I've already told you quite plainly that my daughter will never marry you. Now you come here drunk to make trouble and startle me out of a sound sleep?

paragraphs.original: Sir, sir, sir -
paragraphs.translated: Sir, sir, sir -

paragraphs.original:
But thou must needs be sure
My spirits and my place have in their power
To make this bitter to thee.
paragraphs.translated: You know I'm powerful enough to make you pay for this.

paragraphs.original: Patience, good sir.
paragraphs.translated: Please wait, sir.

paragraphs.original:
What tell'st thou me of robbing? This is Venice,
My house is not a grange.
paragraphs.translated: Why are you talking about robbery? This is Venice. My house isn't in some remote countryside.

paragraphs.original:
Most grave Brabantio,
In simple and pure soul I come to you -
paragraphs.translated: Brabantio, with all due respect, I'm here out of courtesy and good will. I've come to tell you -

paragraphs.original: Zounds, sir, you are one of those that will not serve God, if the devil bid you. Because we come to do you service and you think we are ruffians, you'll have your daughter covered with a Barbary horse. You'll have your nephews neigh to you. You'll have coursers for cousins and gennets for germans.
paragraphs.translated: My God, sir, you're stubborn and suspicious. We come here to help you and you treat us like thugs, but you let an African horse climb all over your daughter. Your grandsons will neigh to you like horses. Your whole family will be ruined.

paragraphs.original: What profane wretch art thou?
paragraphs.translated: What kind of crude jerk are you?

paragraphs.original: I am one, sir, that comes to tell you your daughter and the Moor are now making the beast with two backs.
paragraphs.translated: The kind that tells you that the Moor is having sex with your daughter right now.

paragraphs.original: Thou art a villain!
paragraphs.translated: You're a villain!

paragraphs.original: You are a senator!
paragraphs.translated: You're a senator!

paragraphs.original: This thou shalt answer. I know thee, Roderigo.
paragraphs.translated: You're going to pay for this, Roderigo. I know who you are.

paragraphs.original:
Sir, I will answer any thing. But, I beseech you,
If't be your pleasure and most wise consent
(As partly I find it is) that your fair daughter
At this odd-even and dull watch o' th' night
paragraphs.translated: I'll answer for everything. I don't know if you know or approve of this, but in the wee hours of the morning your daughter left your house, with no better escort than a hired gondolier, to go into the rough embrace of a lustful Moor. If all of this happened with your

paragraphs.original:
Transported with no worse nor better guard
But with a knave of common hire, a gondolier,
To the gross clasps of a lascivious Moor,
If this be known to you and your allowance,
We then have done you bold and saucy wrongs.
But if you know not this my manners tell me
We have your wrong rebuke. Do not believe
That, from the sense of all civility,
I thus would play and trifle with your reverence.
Your daughter (if you have not given her leave)
I say again, hath made a gross revolt,
Tying her duty, beauty, wit, and fortunes
In an extravagant and wheeling stranger
Of here and everywhere. Straight satisfy yourself.
If she be in her chamber or your house,
Let loose on me the justice of the state
For thus deluding you.
paragraphs.translated: approval, then we've been very rude to bother you like this. But if you didn't know about it, then you were wrong to get mad at us. I'd never play pranks on you. If you didn't allow your daughter to do what she's doing, then she's rebelling against you. She's throwing her life away on some stranger. Go ahead, see for yourself if she's in her bedroom. If she is, you can sue me for lying to you.

paragraphs.original:
Strike on the tinder, ho!
Give me a taper, call up all my people!
This accident is not unlike my dream,
Belief of it oppresses me already.
Light, I say, light!
paragraphs.translated: Light the candles! Wake up my whole household! I dreamt about this. I'm starting to worry it's true. Give me some light!

paragraphs.original: Exit above
paragraphs.translated: BRABANTIO exits.

paragraphs.original:
(to RODERIGO)
to
)
Farewell, for I must leave you.
It seems not meet, nor wholesome to my place,
To be producted (as, if I stay, I shall)
Against the Moor. For I do know the state
(However this may gall him with some check)
Cannot with safety cast him, for he's embarked
With such loud reason to the Cyprus wars
(Which even now stand in act) that, for their souls,
Another of his fathom they have none
To lead their business. In which regard,
paragraphs.translated:
(to RODERIGO)
(to
)
It's time for me to say goodbye to you. It would be inappropriate - dangerous, even - for me to be seen working against the Moor, as I would if I stayed. The Venetian government might reprimand him for this, but it can't safely get rid of him, since it needs him urgently for the imminent Cyprus wars. They couldn't find another man with his abilities to lead their armed forces - not if their souls depended on it. I hate him, but I've got to show him signs of loyalty

paragraphs.original:
Though I do hate him as I do hell pains,
Yet for necessity of present life
I must show out a flag and sign of love,
(Which is indeed but sign). That you shall surely find him,
Lead to the Sagittary the raisèd search,
And there will I be with him. So farewell.
paragraphs.translated: and affection, even if it's just an act. If you want to find him, send the search party to the Sagittarius Inn. He and I will be there.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: IAGO exits.

paragraphs.original: Enter BRABANTIO, with servants and torches
paragraphs.translated: BRABANTIO enters with servants and torches.

paragraphs.original:
It is too true an evil. Gone she is.
And what's to come of my despisèd time
Is naught but bitterness. Now, Roderigo,
Where didst thou see her? - Oh, unhappy girl! - 
With the Moor, say'st thou? - Who would be a father? - 
How didst thou know 'twas she? - Oh, she deceives me
Past thought! - What said she to you? - Get more tapers,
Raise all my kindred. Are they married, think you?
paragraphs.translated: It's true. She's gone. The rest of my life will be nothing but bitterness. Now, Roderigo, where did you see her? - Oh, that miserable wretch! - You say you saw her with the Moor? - Oh, who would want to be a father? - How did you know it was her? - To think she tricked me so easily! - What did she say to you? - Get me more candles, and wake up all my relatives. Do you think they're married?

paragraphs.original: Truly, I think they are.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, I really think so.

paragraphs.original:
Oh, heaven, how got she out? Oh, treason of the blood!
Fathers, from hence trust not your daughters' minds
By what you see them act. Is there not charms
By which the property of youth and maidhood
May be abused? Have you not read, Roderigo,
Of some such thing?
paragraphs.translated: Oh, heaven, how did she get out? My own flesh and blood rebels against me! Fathers, never trust your daughters just because they act obedient and innocent. Are there magic spells that can lead young virgins astray? Have you ever heard of anything like that, Roderigo?

paragraphs.original: Yes, sir, I have indeed.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, sir, I have.

paragraphs.original:
Call up my brother - Oh, would you had had her!
Some one way, some another. Do you know
Where we may apprehend her and the Moor?
paragraphs.translated: Call my brother. - Now I wish you'd married her! - Some of you go one way, some the other way. - Do you know where we can find her and the Moor?

paragraphs.original:
I think I can discover him, if you please
To get good guard and go along with me.
paragraphs.translated: I think I can find him. Get together a group of armed men and follow me.

paragraphs.original:
Pray you lead on. At every house I'll call.
I may command at most. - Get weapons, ho!
And raise some special officers of might. - 
On, good Roderigo. I will deserve your pains.
paragraphs.translated: Lead the way. I'll stop at every house. I'm respected enough that most of them will do what I say. - Get your weapons! And get the officers who guard the city at night. - Let's go, Roderigo. I'll reward you for your troubles.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit

paragraphs.original: Enter OTHELLO, IAGO, and attendants with torches
paragraphs.translated: OTHELLO and IAGO enter, followed by attendants with torches.

paragraphs.original:
Though in the trade of war I have slain men,
Yet do I hold it very stuff o' th' conscience
To do no contrived murder. I lack iniquity
Sometimes to do me service. Nine or ten times
I had thought t' have yerked him here under the ribs.
paragraphs.translated: I've killed many men in battle, but I still believe it's deeply wrong to murder someone. Sometimes I worry I'm not cruel enough for this job. Nine or ten times I wanted to stab him under the ribs.

paragraphs.original: 'Tis better as it is.
paragraphs.translated: It's better that you didn't kill him.

paragraphs.original:
Nay, but he prated
And spoke such scurvy and provoking terms
Against your honor
That, with the little godliness I have,
I did full hard forbear him. But I pray you, sir,
Are you fast married? Be assured of this:
That the Magnifico is much beloved
And hath in his effect a voice potential
As double as the Duke's. He will divorce you,
Or put upon you what restraint and grievance
The law (with all his might to enforce it on)
Will give him cable.
paragraphs.translated:
But he kept chattering so foolishly, talking about you in such insulting and despicable terms, that it was hard for me to restrain myself. But please tell me, sir, is your marriage
secure? Brabantio is an important man in this city, almost as powerful as the duke himself. He'll try to annul your marriage, or else inflict whatever punishment the law and his power will allow him to.
secure

paragraphs.original:
Let him do his spite.
My services which I have done the signiory
Shall out-tongue his complaints. 'Tis yet to know - 
Which, when I know that boasting is an honor,
I shall promulgate. I fetch my life and being
From men of royal siege, and my demerits
May speak unbonneted to as proud a fortune
As this that I have reached. For know, Iago,
But that I love the gentle Desdemona,
I would not my unhousèd free condition
Put into circumscription and confine
For the sea's worth. But look, what lights come yond?
paragraphs.translated: Let him do his worst. The services I have done for the Venetian government will count for more than his complaints will. No one knows this yet - and I don't like to brag, but I come from a royal family, and I'm as noble as the woman I've married. And let me tell you, Iago, if I didn't love Desdemona as much as I do, I'd never agree to get married and lose my freedom at all. But look at those lights. Who's coming?

paragraphs.original:
Those are the raisèd father and his friends.
You were best go in.
paragraphs.translated: That's her father and his friends, who've been roused out of bed. You'd better go inside.

paragraphs.original:
Not I, I must be found.
My parts, my title, and my perfect soul
Shall manifest me rightly. Is it they?
paragraphs.translated: No, I must let them find me. My good qualities, my legal status as Desdemona's husband, and my innocence will protect me. Is it them?

paragraphs.original: By Janus, I think no.
paragraphs.translated: I don't think so.

paragraphs.original: Enter CASSIO, with officers and torches
paragraphs.translated: CASSIO enters with officers and men carrying torches.

paragraphs.original:
The servants of the Duke and my lieutenant?
The goodness of the night upon you, friends!
What is the news?
paragraphs.translated: The servants of the Duke and my lieutenant? Hello, everyone! What's going on?

paragraphs.original:
The Duke does greet you, general,
And he requires your haste-post-haste appearance,
Even on the instant.
paragraphs.translated: The Duke sends his regards. He needs to see you right away.

paragraphs.original: What's the matter, think you?
paragraphs.translated: What do you think he wants?

paragraphs.original:
Something from Cyprus as I may divine.
It is a business of some heat. The galleys
Have sent a dozen sequent messengers
This very night at one another's heels,
And many of the consuls, raised and met,
Are at the Duke's already. You have been hotly called for.
When being not at your lodging to be found
The Senate hath sent about three several guests
To search you out.
paragraphs.translated: Something about Cyprus. I think it's important. The warships have sent a dozen messages tonight, one after the other, and many of the senators have been awakened and are at the Duke's already. They're very anxious for you to get there. When you weren't at home, the Senate sent out three different search parties to find you.

paragraphs.original:
'Tis well I am found by you.
I will but spend a word here in the house
And go with you.
paragraphs.translated: It's good you found me. I'll just speak a word or two here in the house and then I'll go with you.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: OTHELLO exits.

paragraphs.original: Ancient, what makes he here?
paragraphs.translated: Ensign, what's he doing in there?

paragraphs.original:
Faith, he tonight hath boarded a land carrack.
If it prove lawful prize, he's made for ever.
paragraphs.translated: Tonight he boarded a treasure ship. If he can keep it, he'll be set forever.

paragraphs.original: I do not understand.
paragraphs.translated: I don't understand.

paragraphs.original: He's married.
paragraphs.translated: He's married.

paragraphs.original: To who?
paragraphs.translated: To whom?

paragraphs.original: Marry, to -
paragraphs.translated: To -

paragraphs.original: Enter OTHELLO
paragraphs.translated: OTHELLO enters.

paragraphs.original: Come, captain, will you go?
paragraphs.translated: Are you ready?

paragraphs.original: Have with you.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, I'll go with you now.

paragraphs.original: Here comes another troop to seek for you.
paragraphs.translated: Here comes another group looking for you.

paragraphs.original: Enter BRABANTIO, RODERIGO, and officers with torches and weapons
paragraphs.translated: BRABANTIO and RODERIGO enter, followed by OFFICERS and men with torches.

paragraphs.original:
It is Brabantio. General, be advised,
He comes to bad intent.
paragraphs.translated: It's Brabantio. Look out, sir. He intends to do something bad to you.

paragraphs.original: Holla! Stand there!
paragraphs.translated: Hey! Stop right there!

paragraphs.original: Signior, it is the Moor.
paragraphs.translated: Sir, it's the Moor.

paragraphs.original: Down with him, thief!
paragraphs.translated: Get him, he's a thief!

paragraphs.original: They draw their swords
paragraphs.translated: Both sides draw their swords.

paragraphs.original: You, Roderigo! Come, sir, I am for you.
paragraphs.translated: You, Roderigo! Come on, I'll fight you.

paragraphs.original:
Keep up your bright swords, for the dew will rust them.
Good signior, you shall more command with years
Than with your weapons.
paragraphs.translated: Put away your swords. They'll get rusty in the dew. Sir, your age and status inspire more respect than your weapons do.

paragraphs.original:
O thou foul thief, where hast thou stowed my daughter?
Damned as thou art, thou hast enchanted her!
For I'll refer me to all things of sense,
If she in chains of magic were not bound,
Whether a maid so tender, fair, and happy,
So opposite to marriage that she shunned
The wealthy curlèd darlings of our nation,
Would ever have, t' incur a general mock,
Run from her guardage to the sooty bosom
Of such a thing as thou - to fear, not to delight.
Judge me the world if 'tis not gross in sense
That thou hast practiced on her with foul charms,
Abused her delicate youth with drugs or minerals
That weakens motion. I'll have 't disputed on.
'Tis probable and palpable to thinking.
I therefore apprehend and do attach thee
For an abuser of the world, a practicer
Of arts inhibited and out of warrant. - 
Lay hold upon him. If he do resist,
Subdue him at his peril!
paragraphs.translated: You evil thief, where have you hidden my daughter? You devil, you've put a spell on her! Anybody with eyes could tell you that a beautiful and happy young girl like her, who's refused to marry all of the handsome young men of the city, wouldn't run off with a black thing like you unless she'd been bewitched. You're something to fear, not to love. It's obvious to everyone that you've tricked her, drugged her, or kidnapped her. That's probably what happened, so I'm arresting you. - Arrest this man as a practitioner of black magic. Grab him. If he struggles, use force!

paragraphs.original:
Hold your hands,
Both you of my inclining and the rest.
Were it my cue to fight, I should have known it
Without a prompter. Whither will you that I go
To answer this your charge?
paragraphs.translated: Just a minute. I don't need anyone to tell me when to fight. You've accused me of some serious crimes. Where do you want me to go to respond to these charges?

paragraphs.original:
To prison, till fit time
Of law and course of direct session
Call thee to answer.
paragraphs.translated: To prison, until you're called into court.

paragraphs.original:
What if I do obey?
How may the Duke be therewith satisfied,
Whose messengers are here about my side
Upon some present business of the state
To bring me to him?
paragraphs.translated: What if I do what you say? How would I satisfy the Duke then? His messengers are waiting here to take me to him immediately, on pressing state business.

paragraphs.original:
'Tis true, most worthy signior.
The Duke's in council and your noble self,
I am sure, is sent for.
paragraphs.translated: It's true. The Duke's in a meeting right now, and he's sent for you too.

paragraphs.original:
How? The Duke in council?
In this time of the night? Bring him away.
Mine's not an idle cause. The Duke himself,
Or any of my brothers of the state,
Cannot but feel this wrong as 'twere their own.
For if such actions may have passage free,
Bond-slaves and pagans shall our statesmen be.
paragraphs.translated: The Duke's in a meeting? At this time of night? Bring him with us. The law's on my side. The Duke and any of my fellow senators will take this wrong as seriously as if it were their own. If we let crimes like this happen, slaves and heathens will be our rulers.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter DUKE, SENATORS, and OFFICERS
paragraphs.translated: The DUKE enters with SENATORS and OFFICERS.

paragraphs.original:
There's no composition in this news
That gives them credit.
paragraphs.translated: These reports are inconsistent. You can't trust them.

paragraphs.original:
Indeed, they are disproportioned.
My letters say a hundred and seven galleys.
paragraphs.translated: It's true, they're inconsistent. My letters say there are a hundred and seven ships.

paragraphs.original: And mine a hundred and forty.
paragraphs.translated: And mine say a hundred and forty.

paragraphs.original:
And mine, two hundred.
But though they jump not on a just account - 
As in these cases, where the aim reports
'Tis oft with difference - yet do they all confirm
A Turkish fleet, and bearing up to Cyprus.
paragraphs.translated: And mine say two hundred. But often in these cases, reports are just estimates. The important thing is that they all say a Turkish fleet is approaching Cyprus.

paragraphs.original:
Nay, it is possible enough to judgment.
I do not so secure me in the error,
But the main article I do approve
In fearful sense.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, we get the idea. The inconsistency doesn't make me think that the reports are all wrong. I have no doubt about what they're basically saying, and it's frightening.

paragraphs.original:
(within)
(within)
What, ho, what, ho, what, ho!
paragraphs.translated:
(offstage) Hello! Hey, hello!
(offstage)

paragraphs.original: A messenger from the galleys.
paragraphs.translated: It's a messenger from the warships.

paragraphs.original: Enter SAILOR
paragraphs.translated: A SAILOR enters.

paragraphs.original: Now, what's the business?
paragraphs.translated: Why are you here?

paragraphs.original:
The Turkish preparation makes for Rhodes,
So was I bid report here to the state
By Signior Angelo.
paragraphs.translated: Signor Angelo told me to come here and tell you that the Turkish fleet is heading for Rhodes, not Cyprus.

paragraphs.original: How say you by this change?
paragraphs.translated: What do you think about this change?

paragraphs.original:
This cannot be,
By no assay of reason. 'Tis a pageant,
To keep us in false gaze. When we consider
Th' importancy of Cyprus to the Turk,
And let ourselves again but understand
That as it more concerns the Turk than Rhodes
So may he with more facile question bear it,
For that it stands not in such warlike brace
But altogether lacks th' abilities
That Rhodes is dressed in. If we make thought of this
We must not think the Turk is so unskillful
To leave that latest which concerns him first,
Neglecting an attempt of ease and gain
To wake and wage a danger profitless.
paragraphs.translated: They can't have changed; there's no way this could be true. It's a trick to confuse us. Think about how important Cyprus is to the Turks, and remember that they could capture Cyprus more easily, since it isn't as well protected as Rhodes is. If we keep these things in mind, we can't possibly imagine that the Turks would be so incompetent as to put off for last what they want to achieve first, setting aside something easy and profitable to do something dangerous and pointless.

paragraphs.original: Nay, in all confidence, he's not for Rhodes.
paragraphs.translated: No, I think we can be confident that the Turks aren't really headed for Rhodes.

paragraphs.original: Here is more news.
paragraphs.translated: Here's some more news coming in.

paragraphs.original: Enter a MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: A MESSENGER enters.

paragraphs.original:
The Ottomites, reverend and gracious,
Steering with due course toward the isle of Rhodes,
Have there injointed them with an after fleet.
paragraphs.translated: Sir, the Turks sailed to Rhodes, where they joined with another fleet.

paragraphs.original: Ay, so I thought. How many, as you guess?
paragraphs.translated: That's just what I thought. How many, can you guess?

paragraphs.original:
Of thirty sail. And now they do re-stem
Their backward course, bearing with frank appearance
Their purposes toward Cyprus. Signior Montano,
Your trusty and most valiant servitor,
With his free duty recommends you thus,
And prays you to believe him.
paragraphs.translated: Thirty ships. Now they've turned around and are clearly heading for Cyprus. Signor Montano, your brave and loyal servant, gives you this information and asks you to send reinforcements to relieve him.

paragraphs.original:
'Tis certain then for Cyprus.
Marcus Luccicos, is not he in town?
paragraphs.translated: Then it's certain they're heading for Cyprus. Is Marcus Luccicos in town?

paragraphs.original: He's now in Florence.
paragraphs.translated: No, he's in Florence.

paragraphs.original: Write from us to him. Post-post-haste, dispatch.
paragraphs.translated: Write to him immediately. Hurry.

paragraphs.original: Here comes Brabantio and the valiant Moor.
paragraphs.translated: Here come Brabantio and the brave Moor.

paragraphs.original: Enter BRABANTIO, OTHELLO, CASSIO, IAGO, RODERIGO, and officers
paragraphs.translated: BRABANTIO, OTHELLO, CASSIO, IAGO, RODERIGO and the officers enter.

paragraphs.original:
Valiant Othello, we must straight employ you
Against the general enemy Ottoman - 
(to BRABANTIO) I did not see you. Welcome, gentle signior.
(to
)
We lacked your counsel and your help tonight.

So did I yours. Good your grace, pardon me.
Neither my place nor aught I heard of business
Hath raised me from my bed, nor doth the general care
Take hold on me, for my particular grief
Is of so flood-gate and o'erbearing nature
That it engluts and swallows other sorrows
And it is still itself.
paragraphs.translated: I could have used yours as well. Forgive me, your grace. I didn't get out of bed and come here in the dead of night because I heard about the war or because I was worried about the city's defense. I have a personal problem so painful and gut-wrenching that it overwhelms everything else.

paragraphs.original: Why, what's the matter?
paragraphs.translated: Why, what's the matter?

paragraphs.original: My daughter! Oh, my daughter!
paragraphs.translated: It's my daughter! Oh, my daughter!

paragraphs.original: Dead?
paragraphs.translated: Is she dead?

paragraphs.original:
Ay, to me.
She is abused, stol'n from me, and corrupted
By spells and medicines bought of mountebanks.
paragraphs.translated: She's dead to me. She's been tricked and stolen from me, enchanted by black magic spells. She must've

paragraphs.original:
For nature so prepost'rously to err,
Being not deficient, blind, or lame of sense,
Sans witchcraft could not.
paragraphs.translated: been tricked or drugged, because there's no way she could have made this mistake on her own.

paragraphs.original:
Whoe'er he be that in this foul proceeding
Hath thus beguiled your daughter of herself
And you of her, the bloody book of law
You shall yourself read in the bitter letter,
After your own sense, yea, though our proper son
Stood in your action.
paragraphs.translated: Whoever tricked your daughter and stole her from you will pay for it. And you yourself will determine the sentence as you see fit, and impose the death penalty if you choose to, even if the criminal were my own son.

paragraphs.original:
Humbly I thank your grace.
Here is the man, this Moor, whom now it seems,
Your special mandate for the state affairs
Hath hither brought.
paragraphs.translated: I humbly thank you, sir. Here is the man, the Moor. It seems you had your own reasons for summoning him here.

paragraphs.original: We are very sorry for't.
paragraphs.translated: We're sorry to hear this.

paragraphs.original: Nothing, but this is so.
paragraphs.translated: Nothing, but this is true.

paragraphs.original:
Most potent, grave, and reverend signiors,
My very noble and approved good masters,
That I have ta'en away this old man's daughter,
It is most true. True, I have married her.
The very head and front of my offending
Hath this extent, no more. Rude am I in my speech,
And little blessed with the soft phrase of peace,
For since these arms of mine had seven years' pith
Till now some nine moons wasted, they have used
Their dearest action in the tented field,
And little of this great world can I speak,
paragraphs.translated: Noble, honorable gentlemen whom I serve: it's true that I've taken this man's daughter from him and married her. But that's my only offense. There's nothing more. I'm awkward in my speech and I'm not a smooth talker. From the time I was seven years old until nine months ago I've been fighting in battles. I don't know much about the world apart from fighting. So I won't do myself much good by speaking in my own defense. But if you'll let me, I'll tell you the plain

paragraphs.original:
More than pertains to feats of broils and battle,
And therefore little shall I grace my cause
In speaking for myself. Yet, by your gracious patience,
I will a round unvarnished tale deliver
Of my whole course of love. What drugs, what charms,
What conjuration and what mighty magic - 
For such proceeding I am charged withal - 
I won his daughter.
paragraphs.translated: story of how we fell in love, and what drugs, charms, spells, and powerful magic - because that's what I'm being accused of - I used to win his daughter.

paragraphs.original:
A maiden never bold,
Of spirit so still and quiet that her motion
Blushed at herself. And she, in spite of nature,
Of years, of country, credit, everything,
To fall in love with what she feared to look on?
It is a judgment maimed and most imperfect
That will confess perfection so could err.
Against all rules of nature, and must be driven
To find out practices of cunning hell
Why this should be. I therefore vouch again
That with some mixtures powerful o'er the blood
Or with some dram, conjured to this effect,
He wrought upon her.
paragraphs.translated: She's a good girl, quiet and obedient. She blushes at the slightest thing. And you want me to believe that despite her young age and proper upbringing she fell in love with a man she'd be afraid to look at? The very thought of it is ridiculous. You'd have to be stupid to think that someone so perfect could make such an unnatural mistake as that. The devil must be behind this. Therefore I say again that he must have used some powerful drug or magic potion on her.

paragraphs.original:
To vouch this is no proof,
Without more wider and more overt test
Than these thin habits and poor likelihoods
Of modern seeming do prefer against him.
paragraphs.translated: Your saying this isn't proof. There has to be clear evidence that he's done this, not just these accusations.

paragraphs.original:
But, Othello, speak.
Did you by indirect and forcèd courses
Subdue and poison this young maid's affections?
Or came it by request and such fair question
As soul to soul affordeth?
paragraphs.translated: Tell us, Othello. Did you trick or deceive this lady in some way? Or did you agree to this as equals?

paragraphs.original:
I do beseech you,
Send for the lady to the Sagittary,
paragraphs.translated: Please, send for Desdemona to come here from the Sagittarius Inn and ask her to speak about me in front

paragraphs.original:
And let her speak of me before her father.
If you do find me foul in her report
The trust, the office I do hold of you,
Not only take away, but let your sentence
Even fall upon my life.
paragraphs.translated: of her father. If she has anything bad to say about me, then you can sentence me to death.

paragraphs.original: Fetch Desdemona hither.
paragraphs.translated: Bring Desdemona here.

paragraphs.original: Ancient, conduct them. You best know the place.
paragraphs.translated: Iago, bring Desdemona here. You know where she is.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt IAGO and attendants
paragraphs.translated: IAGO and attendants exit.

paragraphs.original:
And till she come, as truly as to heaven
I do confess the vices of my blood
So justly to your grave ears I'll present
How I did thrive in this fair lady's love
And she in mine.
paragraphs.translated: In the meantime I'll tell you all, as honestly as I confess my sins to God, how I wooed this beautiful lady, and how she came to love me.

paragraphs.original: Say it, Othello.
paragraphs.translated: Tell us, Othello.

paragraphs.original:
Her father loved me, oft invited me,
Still questioned me the story of my life
From year to year, the battles, sieges, fortunes,
That I have passed.
I ran it through, even from my boyish days,
To th' very moment that he bade me tell it,
Wherein I spoke of most disastrous chances,
Of moving accidents by flood and field,
Of hair-breadth 'scapes i' th' imminent deadly breach,
Of being taken by the insolent foe
And sold to slavery, of my redemption thence
And portance in my traveler's history.
Wherein of antres vast and deserts idle,
Rough quarries, rocks, hills whose heads touch heaven
It was my hint to speak - such was my process - 
And of the Cannibals that each others eat,
paragraphs.translated: Her father loved me and used to invite me to his house often, continually asking me about my life and all the battles I've fought. I told him everything, from my boyhood up until the time when I was talking to him. I told him about unfortunate disasters, hair-raising adventures on sea and on land, and near-catastrophes and dangerous adventures I've been through. I told him how I was captured and sold as a slave, how I bought my freedom, and how I wandered through caves and deserts. I was able to tell him about cannibals who eat each other, and men with heads growing below their shoulders. When I talked about all these things, Desdemona used to listen attentively. If she had to go do some household chore, I noticed that she'd always come back quickly to hear more of my stories.

paragraphs.original:
The Anthropophagi, and men whose heads
Grew beneath their shoulders. These things to hear
Would Desdemona seriously incline.
But still the house affairs would draw her hence,
Which ever as she could with haste dispatch,
She'd come again, and with a greedy ear
Devour up my discourse, which I, observing,
Took once a pliant hour and found good means
To draw from her a prayer of earnest heart
That I would all my pilgrimage dilate,
Whereof by parcels she had something heard
But not intentively. I did consent,
And often did beguile her of her tears
When I did speak of some distressful stroke
That my youth suffered. My story being done
She gave me for my pains a world of sighs.
She swore, in faith, 'twas strange, 'twas passing strange,
'Twas pitiful, 'twas wondrous pitiful.
She wished she had not heard it, yet she wished
That heaven had made her such a man. She thanked me
And bade me, if I had a friend that loved her,
I should but teach him how to tell my story
And that would woo her. Upon this hint I spake.
She loved me for the dangers I had passed,
And I loved her that she did pity them.
This only is the witchcraft I have used.
Here comes the lady. Let her witness it.
paragraphs.translated: When I was relaxing, she'd pull me aside and ask to hear some part of a story she had missed. Her eyes would fill with tears at the bad things I went through in my younger years. When my stories were done, she'd sigh and tell me how strangely wonderful and sad my life had been. She said she wished she hadn't heard it, but she also wished there was a man like me for her. She thanked me and told me that if a friend of mine had a story like mine to tell, she'd fall in love with him. I took the hint and spoke to her. She said she loved me for the dangers I'd survived, and I loved her for feeling such strong emotions about me. That's the only witchcraft I ever used. Here comes my wife now. She'll confirm everything.

paragraphs.original: Enter DESDEMONA, IAGO, and attendants
paragraphs.translated: DESDEMONA, IAGO, and attendants enter.

paragraphs.original:
I think this tale would win my daughter too.
Good Brabantio. Take up this mangled matter at the best.
Men do their broken weapons rather use
Than their bare hands.
paragraphs.translated: I think a story like that would win my own daughter over. Brabantio, I urge you to make the best of this. Try to accept what's happened.

paragraphs.original:
I pray you, hear her speak.
If she confess that she was half the wooer,
Destruction on my head if my bad blame
Light on the man. - Come hither, gentle mistress.
Do you perceive in all this noble company
Where most you owe obedience?
paragraphs.translated: Please let her speak. If she admits she wanted this, then I won't blame Othello. - Come here, my child. Who do you obey here?

paragraphs.original:
My noble father,
I do perceive here a divided duty.
To you I am bound for life and education.
My life and education both do learn me
How to respect you. You are the lord of duty.
I am hitherto your daughter. But here's my husband.
And so much duty as my mother showed
To you, preferring you before her father,
So much I challenge that I may profess
Due to the Moor my lord.
paragraphs.translated: Father, this isn't easy for me. I'm torn. I owe you respect because you gave me life and education. You're the one I have to obey. I'm your daughter. But this man here is my husband now, and I owe him as much as my mother owed you, just as she preferred you to her own father. So I have to give my obedience to the Moor, my husband.

paragraphs.original:
God be with you. I have done.
Please it your grace, on to the state affairs.
I had rather to adopt a child than get it. - 
Come hither, Moor.
I here do give thee that with all my heart
Which, but thou hast already, with all my heart
I would keep from thee. For your sake, jewel,
I am glad at soul I have no other child.
For thy escape would teach me tyranny,
To hang clogs on them. - I have done, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: I'm finished, then. Duke, please go ahead with your state business. I'd rather adopt a child than have one of my own. - Come here, Moor. I'm forced to give my blessing to this marriage. With all my heart, I give you that thing which, if you didn't already have it, I'd try with all my heart to keep from you. Desdemona, I'm glad you're my only child, since if I had others I'd keep them all locked up. You would have made me treat them like a tyrant. - I'm done, my lord.

paragraphs.original:
Let me speak like yourself and lay a sentence
Which, as a grise or step, may help these lovers.
When remedies are past, the griefs are ended
By seeing the worst, which late on hopes depended.
paragraphs.translated: Let me refer to a proverb that may help you forgive these lovers: if you can't change something, don't cry about it. When you lament something bad that's already happened, you're setting yourself up for more

paragraphs.original:
To mourn a mischief that is past and gone
Is the next way to draw new mischief on.
What cannot be preserved when fortune takes,
Patience her injury a mock'ry makes.
The robbed that smiles steals something from the thief,
He robs himself that spends a bootless grief.
paragraphs.translated: bad news. A robbery victim who can smile about his losses is superior to the thief who robbed him, but if he cries he's just wasting time.

paragraphs.original:
So let the Turk of Cyprus us beguile,
We lose it not, so long as we can smile.
He bears the sentence well that nothing bears
But the free comfort which from thence he hears.
But he bears both the sentence and the sorrow
That, to pay grief, must of poor patience borrow.
These sentences to sugar or to gall,
Being strong on both sides, are equivocal.
But words are words. I never yet did hear
That the bruised heart was piercèd through the ears.
I humbly beseech you, proceed to th' affairs of state.
paragraphs.translated: So if the Turks steal Cyprus from us, it won't be bad as long as we keep smiling. It's easy to accept platitudes like that if you haven't lost anything. But I've lost something precious, and I have to put up with the platitude as well as suffering my loss. Talk is cheap. I've never heard of someone feeling better because of someone else's words. Please, I'm asking you, go ahead and get back to your state affairs.

paragraphs.original: The Turk with a most mighty preparation makes for Cyprus. Othello, the fortitude of the place is best known to you, and though we have there a substitute of most allowed sufficiency, yet opinion, a sovereign mistress of effects, throws a more safer voice on you. You must therefore be content to slubber the gloss of your new fortunes with this more stubborn and boist'rous expedition.
paragraphs.translated: The Turks are heading for Cyprus with a powerful fleet. Othello, you understand better than anyone how the defenses for Cyprus work. Even though we have a very good officer in charge there already, everyone says you're the better man for the job. So I'll have to ask you to put a damper on your marriage celebrations and take part in this dangerous expedition.

paragraphs.original:
The tyrant custom, most grave senators,
Hath made the flinty and steel couch of war
My thrice-driven bed of down. I do agnize
A natural and prompt alacrity
I find in hardness, and do undertake
These present wars against the Ottomites.
Most humbly therefore bending to your state,
paragraphs.translated: I've gotten used to the hardships of a military life. I rise to the occasion when faced with difficulties. I will take charge of this war against the Turks. But I humbly ask you to make appropriate arrangements for my wife,

paragraphs.original:
I crave fit disposition for my wife.
Due reference of place and exhibition,
With such accommodation and besort
As levels with her breeding.
paragraphs.translated: giving her a place to live and people to keep her company that suit her high rank.

paragraphs.original: Why, at her father's.
paragraphs.translated: She can stay at her father's house.

paragraphs.original: I'll not have it so.
paragraphs.translated: I won't allow it.

paragraphs.original: Nor I.
paragraphs.translated: Neither will I.

paragraphs.original:
Nor would I there reside,
To put my father in impatient thoughts
By being in his eye. Most gracious Duke,
To my unfolding lend your prosperous ear
And let me find a charter in your voice,
T' assist my simpleness.
paragraphs.translated: And I wouldn't stay there. I don't want to upset my father by being in his house. Dear Duke, please listen to what I have to say.

paragraphs.original: What would you, Desdemona?
paragraphs.translated: What do you want to do, Desdemona?

paragraphs.original:
That I did love the Moor to live with him,
My downright violence and storm of fortunes
May trumpet to the world. My heart's subdued
Even to the very quality of my lord.
I saw Othello's visage in his mind,
And to his honors and his valiant parts
Did I my soul and fortunes consecrate.
So that, dear lords, if I be left behind
A moth of peace and he go to the war,
The rites for which I love him are bereft me,
And I a heavy interim shall support
By his dear absence. Let me go with him.
paragraphs.translated: When I fell in love with Othello I made up my mind that I wanted to live with him. You can see how much I wanted to be with him by how violently I threw away my old life. I feel like I'm a part of him now, and that means I'm part of a soldier. I saw Othello's true face when I saw his mind. I gave my whole life to him because of his honor and bravery. If I were left at home uselessly while he went off to war, then I'm separated from my husband in his natural element. I'd be miserable without him. Let me go with him.

paragraphs.original:
Let her have your voice.
Vouch with me, heaven, I therefore beg it not
To please the palate of my appetite,
paragraphs.translated: Please allow her to do this. I'm not asking to have her near me for sex - I'm too old for that, and my sexual

paragraphs.original:
Nor to comply with heat the young affects
In my defunct and proper satisfaction,
But to be free and bounteous to her mind,
And heaven defend your good souls, that you think
I will your serious and great business scant
When she is with me. No, when light-winged toys
Of feathered Cupid seel with wanton dullness
My speculative and officed instrument,
That my disports corrupt and taint my business,
Let housewives make a skillet of my helm
And all indign and base adversities
Make head against my estimation.
paragraphs.translated: urges are dead. I want this because she wants it - I love her for her mind. And I'd never want you to think that I'd neglect my serious official duties while she was there with me. If I ever let love blind me so that I choose to lounge around in bed with my loved one instead of going off to war, then you can let a housewife use my helmet as a frying pan. My reputation would be disgraced if I ever acted like that.

paragraphs.original:
Be it as you shall privately determine,
Either for her stay or going. Th' affair cries haste
And speed must answer it.
paragraphs.translated: You can decide that privately. I don't care whether she stays or goes. What's important is the urgency of this mission. You've got to act fast.

paragraphs.original: You must away tonight.
paragraphs.translated: You'll have to leave tonight.

paragraphs.original: With all my heart.
paragraphs.translated: With all my heart, I'll go right away.

paragraphs.original:
At nine i' th' morning here we'll meet again.
Othello, leave some officer behind
And he shall our commission bring to you,
And such things else of quality and respect
As doth import you.
paragraphs.translated: We'll meet again at nine in the morning. Othello, have one of your officers stay behind to bring you your commission and whatever else is important to you.

paragraphs.original:
So please your grace, my ancient.
A man he is of honesty and trust.
To his conveyance I assign my wife,
With what else needful your good grace shall think
To be sent after me.
paragraphs.translated: My lord, my ensign is an honest and trustworthy man. He'll accompany my wife, and bring whatever else you think I might need.

paragraphs.original:
Let it be so.
Good night to every one. - (to BRABANTIO)
to
And, noble signior,
If virtue no delighted beauty lack,
Your son-in-law is far more fair than black.
Adieu, brave Moor. Use Desdemona well.
paragraphs.translated: Goodbye, black Moor. Treat Desdemona well.

paragraphs.original:
Look to her, Moor, if thou hast eyes to see.
She has deceived her father, and may thee.
paragraphs.translated: Keep an eye on her, Moor. She lied to me, and she may lie to you.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt DUKE, BRABANTIO, CASSIO, SENATORS, and officers
paragraphs.translated: The DUKE, BRABANTIO, CASSIO, SENATORS, and officers exit.

paragraphs.original:
My life upon her faith! - Honest Iago,
My Desdemona must I leave to thee.
I prithee, let thy wife attend on her,
And bring them after in the best advantage.
Come, Desdemona, I have but an hour
Of love, of worldly matter and direction,
To spend with thee. We must obey the time.
paragraphs.translated: I'd bet my life she'd never lie to me. Iago, I'm leaving my dear Desdemona with you. Have your wife attend to her, and bring them along as soon as you can. Come on, Desdemona, I've only got an hour of love to spend with you, to tell you what you need to do. We're on a tight schedule.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt OTHELLO and DESDEMONA
paragraphs.translated: OTHELLO and DESDEMONA exit.

paragraphs.original: Iago.
paragraphs.translated: Iago.

paragraphs.original: What say'st thou, noble heart?
paragraphs.translated: What do you have to say, noble friend?

paragraphs.original: What will I do, think'st thou?
paragraphs.translated: What do you think I should do?

paragraphs.original: Why, go to bed, and sleep.
paragraphs.translated: Go to bed, and sleep.

paragraphs.original: I will incontinently drown myself.
paragraphs.translated: I'm going to go drown myself.

paragraphs.original: If thou dost I shall never love thee after. Why, thou silly gentleman!
paragraphs.translated: If you do that, I'll never respect you again. Why, you silly man!

paragraphs.original: It is silliness to live when to live is torment, and then have we a prescription to die when death is our physician.
paragraphs.translated: It's silly to live when life is torture. The only cure is death.

paragraphs.original: Oh, villainous! I have looked upon the world for four times seven years, and since I could distinguish betwixt a benefit and an injury I never found man that knew how to love himself. Ere I would say I would drown myself for the love of a guinea hen, I would change my humanity with a baboon.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, how stupid! I've been alive for twenty-eight years, and I've never met a man who knew what was good for him. I'd rather be a baboon than kill myself out of love for some woman I can't have.

paragraphs.original: What should I do? I confess it is my shame to be so fond, but it is not in my virtue to amend it.
paragraphs.translated: What should I do? I know it's foolish to be so much in love, but I can't help it.

paragraphs.original: Virtue? A fig! 'Tis in ourselves that we are thus or thus. Our bodies are our gardens, to the which our wills are gardeners. So that if we will plant nettles or sow lettuce, set hyssop and weed up thyme, supply it with one gender of herbs or distract it with many - either to have it sterile with idleness, or manured with industry - why, the power and corrigible authority of this lies in our wills. If the balance of our lives had not one scale of reason to poise another of sensuality, the blood and baseness of our natures would conduct us to most prepost'rous conclusions. But we have reason to cool our raging motions, our carnal stings, our unbitted lusts. Whereof I take this that you call love to be a sect or scion.
paragraphs.translated: Can't help it? Nonsense! What we are is up to us. Our bodies are like gardens and our willpower is like the gardener. Depending on what we plant - weeds or lettuce, or one kind of herb rather than a variety, the garden will either be barren and useless, or rich and productive. If we didn't have rational minds to counterbalance our emotions and desires, our bodily urges would take over. We'd end up in ridiculous situations. Thankfully, we have reason to cool our raging lusts. In my opinion, what you call love is just an offshoot of lust.

paragraphs.original: It cannot be.
paragraphs.translated: I don't believe it.

paragraphs.original: It is merely a lust of the blood and a permission of the will. Come, be a man. Drown thyself? Drown cats and blind puppies! I have professed me thy friend, and I confess me knit to thy deserving with cables of perdurable toughness.
paragraphs.translated: You feel love because you feel lust and you have no willpower. Come on, be a man. Drown yourself? Drowning is for cats or blind puppies - don't drown yourself! I've told you I'm your friend, and I'll stick by you.

paragraphs.original: I could never better stead thee than now. Put money in thy purse. Follow thou the wars, defeat thy favor with an usurped beard. I say, put money in thy purse. It cannot be long that Desdemona should continue her love to the Moor - put money in thy purse - nor he his to her. It was a violent commencement in her, and thou shalt see an answerable sequestration - put but money in thy purse. These Moors are changeable in their wills - fill thy purse with money. The food that to him now is as luscious as locusts shall be to him shortly as bitter as coloquintida. She must change for youth. When she is sated with his body she will find the errors of her choice. Therefore, put money in thy purse. If thou wilt needs damn thyself, do it a more delicate way than drowning. Make all the money thou canst. If sanctimony and a frail vow betwixt an erring barbarian and supersubtle Venetian be not too hard for my wits and all the tribe of hell, thou shalt enjoy her. Therefore make money. A pox of drowning thyself! 'Tis clean out of the way. Seek thou rather to be hanged in compassing thy joy than to be drowned and go without her.
paragraphs.translated: I've never been more useful to you than I will be now. Here's what you'll do. Sell all your assets and your land, and turn it into cash. Desdemona can't continue loving the Moor any more than he can continue loving her. She fell in love with him very suddenly, and they'll break up just as suddenly. Moors are moody people. - So sell your lands and raise a lot of cash. What seems sweet to him now will soon turn bitter. She'll dump Othello for a younger man. When she's had enough of the Moor's body, she'll realize her mistake. She'll need to have a new lover. She'll have to have it. So have your money ready. If you want to go to hell, there are better ways to do it than killing yourself. Raise all the money you can. I can get the better of religion and a few flimsy vows between a misguided barbarian and a depraved Venetian girl. You'll get to sleep with her - just put together some money. And to hell with drowning yourself! That's completely beside the point. If you're ready to die, you can risk death by committing crimes in an attempt to get the woman you want. Don't just give up on her and drown yourself.

paragraphs.original: Wilt thou be fast to my hopes, if I depend on the issue?
paragraphs.translated: Can I count on you if I wait to see what happens?

paragraphs.original: Thou art sure of me. Go, make money. I have told thee often, and I re-tell thee again and again, I hate the Moor. My cause is hearted. Thine hath no less reason. Let us be conjunctive in our revenge against him. If thou canst cuckold him, thou dost thyself a pleasure, me a sport. There are many events in the womb of time which will be delivered. Traverse, go, provide thy money. We will have more of this tomorrow. Adieu.
paragraphs.translated: You can trust me. Go now and get cash. I told you before, and I'll tell you again and again: I hate the Moor. I'm devoted to my cause of hating him, just as devoted as you are to yours. So let's join forces and get revenge. If you seduce Desdemona and make a fool out of him, it'll be fun for both of us. Many things may happen. Go get money. We'll speak again tomorrow. Goodbye.

paragraphs.original: Where shall we meet i' th' morning?
paragraphs.translated: Where will we meet in the morning?

paragraphs.original: At my lodging.
paragraphs.translated: At my house.

paragraphs.original: I'll be with thee betimes.
paragraphs.translated: I'll be there early.

paragraphs.original:
Go to, farewell.
Do you hear, Roderigo?
paragraphs.translated: Go home. Goodbye. Oh, and one more thing -

paragraphs.original: What say you?
paragraphs.translated: What is it?

paragraphs.original: No more of drowning, do you hear?
paragraphs.translated: No more talk about killing yourself, okay?

paragraphs.original: I am changed.
paragraphs.translated: I've changed my mind about that.

paragraphs.original: Go to, farewell. Put money enough in your purse.
paragraphs.translated: Go then, goodbye. Put a lot of cash together.

paragraphs.original: I'll sell all my land.
paragraphs.translated: I'm going to sell all my land.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: RODERIGO exits.

paragraphs.original:
Thus do I ever make my fool my purse.
For I mine own gained knowledge should profane
If I would time expend with such a snipe
But for my sport and profit. I hate the Moor,
And it is thought abroad that 'twixt my sheets
He's done my office. I know not if 't be true,
But I, for mere suspicion in that kind,
Will do as if for surety. He holds me well.
The better shall my purpose work on him.
Cassio's a proper man. Let me see now,
paragraphs.translated: That's how I always do it, getting money from fools. I'd be wasting my skills dealing with an idiot like that if I couldn't get something useful out of him. I hate the Moor, and there's a widespread rumor that he's slept with my wife. I'm not sure it's true, but just the suspicion is enough for me. He thinks highly of me. That'll help. Cassio's a handsome man. Let's see, how can I

paragraphs.original:
To get his place and to plume up my will
In double knavery. How? How? Let's see.
After some time, to abuse Othello's ear
That he is too familiar with his wife.
He hath a person and a smooth dispose
To be suspected, framed to make women false.
The Moor is of a free and open nature
That thinks men honest that but seem to be so,
And will as tenderly be led by th' nose
As asses are.
I have 't. It is engendered! Hell and night
Must bring this monstrous birth to the world's light.
paragraphs.translated: get his position and use him to hurt Othello at the same time? How? How? Let's see. After a while I'll start telling Othello that Cassio is too intimate with Desdemona. Cassio is a smooth talker and a good-looking guy, the sort of man that people would expect to be a seducer. The Moor is open and straightforward. He thinks any man who seems honest is honest. People like that are easy to manipulate. So it's all decided. I've worked it out. With a little help from the devil, I'll bring this monstrous plan to success.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: Enter MONTANO and two GENTLEMEN
paragraphs.translated: MONTANO and two GENTLEMEN enter.

paragraphs.original: What from the cape can you discern at sea?
paragraphs.translated: What can you see out on the ocean?

paragraphs.original:
Nothing at all. It is a high-wrought flood.
I cannot 'twixt the heaven and the main
Descry a sail.
paragraphs.translated: Nothing. The water's so rough that I can't see any sails, either in the bay or on the ocean.

paragraphs.original:
Methinks the wind hath spoke aloud at land,
A fuller blast ne'er shook our battlements.
If it hath ruffianed so upon the sea
What ribs of oak, when mountains melt on them,
Can hold the mortise? What shall we hear of this?
paragraphs.translated: It was windy on shore too. A big blast of wind shook our fortifications. How could a ship made out of wood hold together in those mountainous waves? What do you think will be the result of this storm?

paragraphs.original:
A segregation of the Turkish fleet.
For do but stand upon the foaming shore,
The chidden billow seems to pelt the clouds,
The wind-shaked surge, with high and monstrous mane,
Seems to cast water on the burning bear,
And quench the guards of th' ever-fixèd pole.
I never did like molestation view
On the enchafèd flood.
paragraphs.translated: The Turkish navy will be broken up. The wind's whipping up the waves so high you expect them to reach the clouds and splash against the stars in the sky. I've never seen the waters so disturbed.

paragraphs.original:
If that the Turkish fleet
Be not ensheltered and embayed, they are drowned.
It is impossible they bear it out.
paragraphs.translated: If the Turkish fleet isn't protected in some harbor, their men must all be drowned. No ship could survive this storm.

paragraphs.original: Enter a THIRD GENTLEMAN
paragraphs.translated: A THIRD GENTLEMAN enters.

paragraphs.original:
News, lads, Our wars are done!
The desperate tempest hath so banged the Turks,
That their designment halts. A noble ship of Venice
Hath seen a grievous wreck and sufferance
On most part of their fleet.
paragraphs.translated: I've got news, boys, the war's over! This terrible storm has smashed the Turks so badly that their plans are ruined. One of our ships has reported that it saw most of their fleet shipwrecked.

paragraphs.original: How? Is this true?
paragraphs.translated: What? Is this true?

paragraphs.original:
The ship is here put in,
A Veronesa. Michael Cassio,
Lieutenant to the warlike Moor Othello,
Is come on shore. The Moor himself at sea
And is in full commission here for Cyprus.
paragraphs.translated: The ship's sailing into harbor now; it's from Verona. Michael Cassio, lieutenant of the Moor Othello, has arrived on shore. The Moor himself is still at sea. He's been commissioned to come here to Cyprus.

paragraphs.original: I am glad on 't. 'Tis a worthy governor.
paragraphs.translated: I'm happy about that. He'll be a good governor.

paragraphs.original:
But this same Cassio, though he speak of comfort
Touching the Turkish loss, yet he looks sadly
And prays the Moor be safe. For they were parted
With foul and violent tempest.
paragraphs.translated: Cassio brings good news about the Turkish defeat, but he's worried about the Othello's safety. The two of them were separated during the storm.

paragraphs.original:
Pray heavens he be,
For I have served him, and the man commands
Like a full soldier. Let's to the seaside, ho!
As well to see the vessel that's come in
As to throw out our eyes for brave Othello,
Even till we make the main and th' aerial blue
An indistinct regard.
paragraphs.translated: I hope to God Othello's all right. I served under him, and I know what an excellent commander he is. Let's go to the shore to get a look at the ship that came in, and to look out for Othello's ship. We'll stare out at the sea until the sea and the sky blur together.

paragraphs.original:
Come, let's do so.
For every minute is expectancy
Of more arrivance.
paragraphs.translated: Let's do that. Every minute we expect more ships to arrive.

paragraphs.original: Enter CASSIO
paragraphs.translated: CASSIO enters.

paragraphs.original:
Thanks, you the valiant of this warlike isle
That so approve the Moor. Oh, let the heavens
Give him defense against the elements,
For I have lost him on a dangerous sea.
paragraphs.translated: Thanks, you brave men who defend this island and respect Othello. I hope heaven protects him from the weather, because I lost sight of him on the stormy sea.

paragraphs.original: Is he well shipped?
paragraphs.translated: Is his ship sturdy?

paragraphs.original:
His bark is stoutly timbered and his pilot
Of very expert and approved allowance
Therefore my hopes, not surfeited to death,
Stand in bold cure.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, it's well built, and the ship's pilot is very expert and experienced. For that reason I still have some hope for him, even though I don't have my hopes up too high.

paragraphs.original:
(within) A sail, a sail, a sail!
(within)
paragraphs.translated:
(offstage) A sail! A sail! A sail!
(offstage)

paragraphs.original: Enter a MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: A MESSENGER enters.

paragraphs.original: What noise?
paragraphs.translated: What's all that shouting about?

paragraphs.original:
The town is empty. On the brow o' th' sea
Stand ranks of people, and they cry "A sail!"
paragraphs.translated: Everybody in town is down at the shore shouting "A sail!"

paragraphs.original: My hopes do shape him for the governor.
paragraphs.translated: I hope it's Othello.

paragraphs.original: A shot
paragraphs.translated: A shot is heard.

paragraphs.original:
They do discharge their shot of courtesy.
Our friends at least.
paragraphs.translated: They've fired a greeting shot, so at least it's a friendly ship.

paragraphs.original:
I pray you sir, go forth
And give us truth who 'tis that is arrived.
paragraphs.translated: Please go find out for certain who has arrived.

paragraphs.original: I shall.
paragraphs.translated: I'll do that.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: SECOND GENTLEMAN exits.

paragraphs.original: But good lieutenant, is your general wived?
paragraphs.translated: Good lieutenant, is your general married?

paragraphs.original:
Most fortunately. He hath achieved a maid
That paragons description and wild fame,
One that excels the quirks of blazoning pens,
And in th' essential vesture of creation
Does tire the ingener.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, and he's very lucky to have married the woman he did. His wife defies description. She's God's masterpiece, and she'd exhaust whoever tried to do her justice while praising her.

paragraphs.original: Enter SECOND GENTLEMAN
paragraphs.translated: The SECOND GENTLEMAN enters.

paragraphs.original: How now? Who has put in?
paragraphs.translated: Who's arrived in the harbor?

paragraphs.original: 'Tis one Iago, ancient to the general.
paragraphs.translated: A man named Iago, the general's ensign.

paragraphs.original:
He's had most favorable and happy speed.
Tempests themselves, high seas, and howling winds,
The guttered rocks and congregated sands,
Traitors ensteeped to enclog the guiltless keel,
As having sense of beauty, do omit
Their mortal natures, letting go safely by
The divine Desdemona.
paragraphs.translated: He made good time. You see how the storm, the jagged rocks, and the sand banks that trap ships all appreciate a beautiful woman. They let the heavenly Desdemona arrive safe and sound.

paragraphs.original: What is she?
paragraphs.translated: Who's that?

paragraphs.original:
She that I spake of, our great captain's captain,
Left in the conduct of the bold Iago,
Whose footing here anticipates our thoughts
A se'nnight's speed. Great Jove, Othello guard,
And swell his sail with thine own powerful breath,
That he may bless this bay with his tall ship,
Make love's quick pants in Desdemona's arms,
Give renewed fire to our extincted spirits
And bring all Cyprus comfort!
paragraphs.translated: She's the one I was talking about, the general's wife. The brave Iago was put in charge of bringing her here, and he's arrived a week sooner than we expected. Dear God, please protect Othello and help him arrive here safely, so he and Desdemona can be in each other's arms, and Othello can cheer us up and bring comfort to Cyprus.

paragraphs.original: Enter DESDEMONA, EMILIA, IAGO, RODERIGO with attendants
paragraphs.translated: DESDEMONA, IAGO, RODERIGO and EMILIA enter.

paragraphs.original:
Oh, behold,
The riches of the ship is come on shore!
You men of Cyprus, let her have your knees.
Hail to thee, lady, and the grace of heaven,
Before, behind thee, and on every hand,
Enwheel thee round!
paragraphs.translated: Look, the precious Desdemona has arrived on shore. We should all kneel before her, men of Cyprus! Greetings, my lady, and may God always be with you.

paragraphs.original:
I thank you, valiant Cassio.
What tidings can you tell me of my lord?
paragraphs.translated: Thank you, brave Cassio. Is there any news about my husband?

paragraphs.original:
He is not yet arrived. Nor know I aught
But that he's well and will be shortly here.
paragraphs.translated: He hasn't arrived yet. As far as I know, he's okay and will arrive here soon.

paragraphs.original: Oh, but I fear. How lost you company?
paragraphs.translated: Oh, but I'm worried. How did you two get separated?

paragraphs.original:
The great contention of the sea and skies
Parted our fellowship -
paragraphs.translated: The storm separated us.

paragraphs.original:
(within) A sail, a sail!
(within)
paragraphs.translated:
(offstage) A sail! A sail!
(offstage)

paragraphs.original: But, hark! a sail.
paragraphs.translated: Listen, they've spotted another ship!

paragraphs.original: A shot
paragraphs.translated: A gunshot is heard.

paragraphs.original:
They give this greeting to the citadel.
This likewise is a friend.
paragraphs.translated: They fired a greeting shot too, so this is also a friendly ship.

paragraphs.original: See for the news.
paragraphs.translated: Go find out the news.

paragraphs.original: Exit a SECOND GENTLEMEN
paragraphs.translated: SECOND GENTLEMAN exits.

paragraphs.original:
Good ancient, you are welcome. - Welcome, mistress.
(kisses EMILIA)
(kisses
)
Let it not gall your patience, good Iago,
That I extend my manners. 'Tis my breeding
That gives me this bold show of courtesy.

Sir, would she give you so much of her lips
As of her tongue she oft bestows on me,
You'll have enough.
paragraphs.translated: If she gave you as much lip as she gives me, you'd be sick of her by now.

paragraphs.original: Alas, she has no speech!
paragraphs.translated: On the contrary, she's a soft-spoken woman.

paragraphs.original:
In faith, too much.
I find it still, when I have leave to sleep.
Marry, before your ladyship, I grant,
She puts her tongue a little in her heart
And chides with thinking.
paragraphs.translated: No, she talks too much. She's always talking when I want to sleep. I admit that in front of you, my lady, she keeps a bit quiet. But she's scolding me silently.

paragraphs.original: You have little cause to say so.
paragraphs.translated: You have no reason to say that.

paragraphs.original: Come on, come on. You are pictures out of door, bells in your parlors, wild-cats in your kitchens, saints in your injuries, devils being offended, players in your housewifery, and housewives in your beds.
paragraphs.translated: Come on, come on. You women are all the same. You're as pretty as pictures when you're out in public, but in your own houses you're as noisy as jangling bells. In your own kitchens you act like wildcats. You make yourselves sound like saints when you're complaining about something, but you act like devils when someone offends you. You don't take your jobs as housewives seriously, and you're shameless hussies in bed.

paragraphs.original: Oh, fie upon thee, slanderer!
paragraphs.translated: Shame on you, you slanderer!

paragraphs.original:
Nay, it is true, or else I am a Turk.
You rise to play and go to bed to work.
paragraphs.translated: No, it's true, or if it's not, I'm a villain. You wake up to have fun, and you start work when you go to bed.

paragraphs.original: You shall not write my praise.
paragraphs.translated: You clearly have nothing good to say about me.

paragraphs.original: No, let me not.
paragraphs.translated: No, I don't.

paragraphs.original: What wouldst thou write of me, if thou should'st praise me?
paragraphs.translated: But if you had to say something nice about me, what would you say?

paragraphs.original:
O gentle lady, do not put me to 't,
For I am nothing, if not critical.
paragraphs.translated: Don't make me do it, my lady. I'm critical by nature.

paragraphs.original: Come on, assay. There's one gone to the harbor?
paragraphs.translated: Come on, just try. - By the way, has someone gone down to the harbor?

paragraphs.original: Ay, madam.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, madam.

paragraphs.original:
I am not merry, but I do beguile
The thing I am by seeming otherwise.
Come, how wouldst thou praise me?
paragraphs.translated: I'm not as happy as I seem. I'm just trying not to show how worried I am about Othello's safety. Come on, what would you say about me?

paragraphs.original:
I am about it, but indeed my invention
Comes from my pate as birdlime does from frieze,
It plucks out brains and all. But my Muse labors
And thus she is delivered:
If she be fair and wise, fairness and wit,
The one's for use, the other useth it.
paragraphs.translated: I'm trying to think of something, but I'm not good at inventing clever things. It takes time. Ah, I've got it. If a woman is pretty and smart, she uses her good looks to get what she wants.

paragraphs.original: Well praised! How if she be black and witty?
paragraphs.translated: Very clever! But what if the woman is smart but ugly?

paragraphs.original:
If she be black, and thereto have a wit,
She'll find a white that shall her blackness fit.
paragraphs.translated: Even if she's ugly, she'll be smart enough to find a guy to sleep with her.

paragraphs.original: Worse and worse!
paragraphs.translated: This is getting worse and worse!

paragraphs.original: How if fair and foolish?
paragraphs.translated: What if she's pretty but stupid?

paragraphs.original:
She never yet was foolish that was fair,
For even her folly helped her to an heir.
paragraphs.translated: No pretty woman is stupid, because her stupidity will make her more attractive to men.

paragraphs.original:
These are old fond paradoxes to make fools laugh i' th' alehouse. What miserable praise hast thou for her
