That's foul and foolish?
paragraphs.translated: These are stupid old jokes that men tell each other in bars. What horrible thing do you have to say about a woman who's both ugly and stupid?

paragraphs.original:
There's none so foul and foolish thereunto,
But does foul pranks which fair and wise ones do.
paragraphs.translated: No matter how ugly or stupid the woman is, she plays the same dirty tricks that the smart and pretty ones do.

paragraphs.original: Oh, heavy ignorance! Thou praisest the worst best. But what praise couldst thou bestow on a deserving woman indeed, one that in the authority of her merit did justly put on the vouch of very malice itself?
paragraphs.translated: You don't know a thing! You give your best praise to the worst women. But how would you praise a truly good woman, someone who had no reason to worry about what anyone said about her?

paragraphs.original:
She that was ever fair and never proud,
Had tongue at will and yet was never loud,
Never lacked gold and yet went never gay,
Fled from her wish and yet said "Now I may,"
She that being angered, her revenge being nigh,
Bade her wrong stay and her displeasure fly,
She that in wisdom never was so frail
To change the cod's head for the salmon's tail,
She that could think and ne'er disclose her mind,
See suitors following and not look behind,
She was a wight, if ever such wights were -
paragraphs.translated: A woman who was beautiful but never proud, who could speak well but knew when to be quiet, who dressed well but was never overdressed, who had self-restraint even when she could get what she wanted, a woman who never took revenge, who overlooked it when people hurt her, who was too wise to do anything stupid, who could think without revealing her thoughts, and who could refrain from flirting with men in love with her, that kind of woman, if she ever existed, would -

paragraphs.original: To do what?
paragraphs.translated: Would do what?

paragraphs.original: To suckle fools and chronicle small beer.
paragraphs.translated: Would raise babies and clip coupons.

paragraphs.original: Oh, most lame and impotent conclusion! Do not learn of him, Emilia, though he be thy husband. How say you, Cassio? Is he not a most profane and liberal counselor?
paragraphs.translated: Oh, that's pathetic! Don't listen to him, Emilia, even though he's your husband. What do you think about him, Cassio? Isn't he a horrible man?

paragraphs.original: He speaks home, madam. You may relish him more in the soldier than in the scholar.
paragraphs.translated: He speaks bluntly, madam. He's more of a soldier than a wise man.

paragraphs.original:
CASSIO takes DESDEMONA'S hand

DESDEMONA'S
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIO takes DESDEMONA'S hand.

DESDEMONA'S

paragraphs.original:
(aside) He takes her by the palm. Ay, well said, whisper! With as little a web as this will I ensnare as great a fly as Cassio. Ay, smile upon her, do, I will gyve thee in thine own courtship. You say true, 'Tis so, indeed.
aside
paragraphs.translated:
(to himself) He's taking her hand. That's right, go ahead and whisper together. This is all I need to get Cassio. Yes, keep smiling at her, Cassio. Your fine manners around women will be your downfall. Oh, I'm sure you're saying something very clever.
(to himself)

paragraphs.original: If such tricks as these strip you out of your lieutenantry, it had been better you had not kissed your three fingers so oft, which now again you are most apt to play the sir in. Very good, well kissed, and excellent courtesy! 'tis so, indeed. Yet again your fingers to your lips? Would they were clyster-pipes for your sake! -
paragraphs.translated:
If you lose your job because of little flirtations like this, you'll wish you hadn't been so courteous with her. Oh, how nice, you're
kissing your own hand, one finger at a time? I wish those fingers were enema tubes! - 
kissing

paragraphs.original: Trumpet within
paragraphs.translated: A trumpet plays offstage.

paragraphs.original: The Moor! I know his trumpet.
paragraphs.translated: That's the Moor! I recognize his trumpet.

paragraphs.original: 'Tis truly so.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, it is.

paragraphs.original: Let's meet him and receive him.
paragraphs.translated: Let's go greet him when he lands.

paragraphs.original: Lo, where he comes!
paragraphs.translated: Look, here he comes.

paragraphs.original: Enter OTHELLO and attendants
paragraphs.translated: OTHELLO enters with attendants.

paragraphs.original: Oh my fair warrior!
paragraphs.translated: My beautiful warrior!

paragraphs.original: My dear Othello!
paragraphs.translated: My darling Othello!

paragraphs.original:
It gives me wonder great as my content
To see you here before me. Oh, my soul's joy!
If after every tempest come such calms,
May the winds blow till they have wakened death,
And let the laboring bark climb hills of seas
Olympus-high, and duck again as low
As hell's from heaven! If it were now to die,
'Twere now to be most happy, for I fear
My soul hath her content so absolute
That not another comfort like to this
Succeeds in unknown fate.
paragraphs.translated: I'm amazed you got here before me. But I'm overjoyed! My love, if the calm after the storm could always be this wonderful, I'd want the wind to blow until it waked the dead, and whipped up waves as tall as mountains! If I died right now I'd be completely happy, since I'll probably never be as happy as this again in my life.

paragraphs.original:
The heavens forbid
But that our loves and comforts should increase,
Even as our days do grow.
paragraphs.translated: God willing, our love and our happiness will only increase as we get older.

paragraphs.original:
Amen to that, sweet powers!
I cannot speak enough of this content.
It stops me here, it is too much of joy.
And this, and this, the greatest discords be (kissing her)
(kissing her)
That e'er our hearts shall make!
paragraphs.translated:
Amen to that! I can't talk about my happiness anymore. It's too much. I hope these kisses I'm about to give you are the closest we ever come to fighting.(they kiss)
(they kiss)

paragraphs.original:
(aside)
(aside)
Oh, you are well tuned now,
But I'll set down the pegs that make this music,
As honest as I am.
paragraphs.translated:
(to himself) Oh, you're happy now, but I'll ruin your happiness, for all my supposed honesty.
(to himself)

paragraphs.original:
Come, let us to the castle.
News, friends! Our wars are done, the Turks are drowned.
How does my old acquaintance of this isle? - 
Honey, you shall be well desired in Cyprus,
I have found great love amongst them. O my sweet,
I prattle out of fashion, and I dote
In mine own comforts. - I prithee, good Iago,
Go to the bay and disembark my coffers.
Bring thou the master to the citadel.
He is a good one, and his worthiness
Does challenge much respect. - Come, Desdemona,
Once more, well met at Cyprus.
paragraphs.translated: Let's go up to the castle. Good news, friends. The war's over and the Turks are drowned. How are my old friends from this island doing? - Honey, they'll love you here in Cyprus. They've been very good to me here. Oh, my dear, I'm blabbing on and on because I'm so happy. - Iago, would you be good enough to go get my trunks from the ships? And bring the ship's captain to the castle. He's a good man. - Let's go, Desdemona. I'll say it again: I'm so happy to see you here in Cyprus!

paragraphs.original: Exeunt OTHELLO, DESDEMONA, and attendants
paragraphs.translated: OTHELLO, DESDEMONA, and attendants exit.

paragraphs.original: Do thou meet me presently at the harbor. - Come hither. If thou be'st valiant, as they say base men being in love have then a nobility in their natures more than is native to them, list me. The lieutenant tonight watches on the court of guard. First, I must tell thee this: Desdemona is directly in love with him.
paragraphs.translated: Meet me down at the harbor. - Come here. They say love makes cowards brave. So if you're brave, listen to me. Lieutenant Cassio will be on guard duty tonight. But first, I have to tell you that Desdemona's completely in love with him.

paragraphs.original: With him? Why, 'tis not possible.
paragraphs.translated: With Cassio? That's impossible.

paragraphs.original: Lay thy finger thus, and let thy soul be instructed. Mark me with what violence she first loved the Moor, but for bragging and telling her fantastical lies. To love him still for prating? Let not thy discreet heart think it. Her eye must be fed, and what delight shall she have to look on the devil? When the blood is made dull with the act of sport, there should be a game to inflame it and to give satiety a fresh appetite, loveliness in favor, sympathy in years, manners and beauties. All which the Moor is defective in. Now for want of these required conveniences, her delicate tenderness will find itself abused, begin to heave the gorge, disrelish and abhor the Moor. Very nature will instruct her in it and compel her to some second choice. Now sir, this granted - as it is a most pregnant and unforced position - who stands so eminent in the degree of this fortune as Cassio does? A knave very voluble, no further conscionable than in putting on the mere form of civil and humane seeming, for the better compassing of his salt and most hidden loose affection. Why, none, why, none! A slipper and subtle knave, a finder of occasions that has an eye, can stamp and counterfeit advantages, though true advantage never present itself. A devilish knave. Besides, the knave is handsome, young, and hath all those requisites in him that folly and green minds look after. A pestilent complete knave, and the woman hath found him already.
paragraphs.translated: Be quiet and listen to me. Remember how she fell madly in love with the Moor because he bragged and told her made-up stories? Did you expect her to keep on loving him for his chattering? You're too smart to think that. No, she needs someone nice-looking. Othello's ugly, what pleasure could she find in him? Lovemaking gets boring after a while. To keep things hot, she'll need to see someone with a handsome face, someone close to her in age, someone who looks and acts like her. Othello isn't any of those things. Since he doesn't have these advantages to make him attractive to her, she'll get sick of him until he makes her want to puke. She'll start looking around for a second choice. Now, if that's true - and it's obviously true - who's in a better position than Cassio? He's a smooth talker, and uses sophistication and fine manners to hide his lust. Nobody's as crafty as he is. Besides, he's young and handsome, and he's got all the qualities that naïve and silly girls go for. He's a bad boy, and Desdemona's got her eye on him already.

paragraphs.original: I cannot believe that in her. She's full of most blessed condition.
paragraphs.translated: I can't believe that. She's not that kind of woman. She's very moral.

paragraphs.original: Blessed fig's-end! The wine she drinks is made of grapes. If she had been blessed, she would never have loved the Moor. Blessed pudding! Didst thou not see her paddle with the palm of his hand? Didst not mark that?
paragraphs.translated: Like hell she is! She's made of the same flesh and blood as everyone else. If she were so moral, she would never have fallen in love with the Moor in the first place. Good lord! Did you notice how she and Cassio were fondling each other's hands? Did you see that?

paragraphs.original: Yes, that I did, but that was but courtesy.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, I did. But that wasn't romantic, it was just polite manners.

paragraphs.original: Lechery, by this hand, an index and obscure prologue to the history of lust and foul thoughts. They met so near with their lips that their breaths embraced together. Villainous thoughts, Roderigo! When these mutabilities so marshal the way, hard at hand comes the master and main exercise, th' incorporate conclusion. Pish! But, sir, be you ruled by me. I have brought you from Venice. Watch you tonight for the command, I'll lay 't upon you. Cassio knows you not. I'll not be far from you. Do you find some occasion to anger Cassio, either by speaking too loud, or tainting his discipline, or from what other course you please, which the time shall more favorably minister.
paragraphs.translated: They were lusting after each other. You could tell by how they were acting that they're going to be lovers. They were so close that their breath was mingling. When two people get that intimate, sex will soon follow. Disgusting! But listen to me; let me guide you. I brought you here from Venice. Be on guard duty tonight. I'll put you in charge. Cassio doesn't know you. I'll be nearby. Make Cassio angry somehow, either by speaking too loud, or insulting his military skills, or however else you want.

paragraphs.original: Well.
paragraphs.translated: All right.

paragraphs.original: Sir, he's rash and very sudden in choler, and haply may strike at you. Provoke him that he may. For even out of that will I cause these of Cyprus to mutiny, whose qualification shall come into no true taste again but by the displanting of Cassio. So shall you have a shorter journey to your desires by the means I shall then have to prefer them, and the impediment most profitably removed, without the which there were no expectation of our prosperity.
paragraphs.translated: He's hot-tempered, and he might try to hit you with his staff. Try to get him to do that. That'll allow me to stir up public sentiment against him here in Cyprus. I'll get them so riled up that they'll only calm down when Cassio's fired. To get what you want, you need to get Cassio out of the way. If you don't do that, things are hopeless for you.

paragraphs.original: I will do this, if you can bring it to any opportunity.
paragraphs.translated: I'll do it, if you help me out.

paragraphs.original: I warrant thee. Meet me by and by at the citadel. I must fetch his necessaries ashore. Farewell.
paragraphs.translated: I promise I will. Meet me in a little while at the citadel. I need to get Othello's things from the ship. Goodbye.

paragraphs.original: Adieu.
paragraphs.translated: Goodbye.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: RODERIGO exits.

paragraphs.original:
That Cassio loves her, I do well believe 't.
That she loves him, 'tis apt and of great credit.
The Moor, howbeit that I endure him not,
Is of a constant, loving, noble nature,
And I dare think he'll prove to Desdemona
A most dear husband. Now, I do love her too,
Not out of absolute lust - though peradventure
I stand accountant for as great a sin - 
But partly led to diet my revenge,
For that I do suspect the lusty Moor
Hath leaped into my seat. The thought whereof
Doth, like a poisonous mineral, gnaw my inwards,
And nothing can or shall content my soul
Till I am evened with him, wife for wife.
Or, failing so, yet that I put the Moor
At least into a jealousy so strong
That judgment cannot cure. Which thing to do,
If this poor trash of Venice, whom I trace
For his quick hunting, stand the putting on,
I'll have our Michael Cassio on the hip,
Abuse him to the Moor in the right garb
(For I fear Cassio with my night-cape too)
Make the Moor thank me, love me, and reward me
For making him egregiously an ass
And practicing upon his peace and quiet
Even to madness. 'Tis here, but yet confused.
Knavery's plain face is never seen till used.
paragraphs.translated: I think Cassio really does love her, and it's perfectly likely that she loves him too. I can't stand the Moor, but I have to admit that he's a reliable, loving, and good-natured man. He'd probably be a good husband to Desdemona. I love her too, not simply out of lust, but also to feed my revenge. I have a feeling the Moor slept with my wife. That thought keeps gnawing at me, eating me up inside. I won't be satisfied until I get even with him, wife for wife. If I can't do that, I can at least make the Moor so jealous that he can't think straight. If that piece of Venetian trash Roderigo can do what I need to carry out my plan, I'll have power over Cassio. I'll say bad things about him to the Moor. I have a feeling Cassio seduced my wife as well. I'll make the Moor thank me, love me, and reward me, even though the joke will be on him the whole time. I've got a good plan, though I haven't worked out the details yet. You can never see the end of an evil plan until the moment comes.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: IAGO exits.

paragraphs.original: Enter Othello's HERALD, with a proclamation
paragraphs.translated: Othello's HERALD enters with a proclamation.

paragraphs.original: It is Othello's pleasure, our noble and valiant general, that, upon certain tidings now arrived, importing the mere perdition of the Turkish fleet, every man put himself into triumph: some to dance, some to make bonfires, each man to what sport and revels his addiction leads him. For besides these beneficial news, it is the celebration of his nuptial. So much was his pleasure should be proclaimed. All offices are open, and there is full liberty of feasting from this present hour of five till the bell have told eleven. Bless the isle of Cyprus and our noble general Othello!
paragraphs.translated: Our noble and courageous general Othello having been informed that the Turkish fleet has been completely destroyed, invites every man to celebrate our victory. Some of you dance, some of you make bonfires, and every man celebrate in whatever way he likes to. For besides the good news, we are also celebrating his marriage. That's the end of the announcement. There will be a feast from five o'clock until eleven. God bless the island of Cyprus and our noble general Othello!

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: The HERALD exits.

paragraphs.original: Enter OTHELLO, DESDEMONA, CASSIO, and attendants
paragraphs.translated: OTHELLO, DESDEMONA, CASSIO and attendants enter.

paragraphs.original:
Good Michael, look you to the guard tonight.
Let's teach ourselves that honorable stop
Not to outsport discretion.
paragraphs.translated: Good Michael, keep a careful eye on the guards tonight. Let's exercise restraint and not let the party get too wild.

paragraphs.original:
Iago hath direction what to do,
But notwithstanding with my personal eye
Will I look to 't.
paragraphs.translated: Iago has orders what to do. But I'll see to it personally anyway.

paragraphs.original:
Iago is most honest.
Michael, good night. Tomorrow with your earliest
Let me have speech with you. - 
Come, my dear love,
The purchase made, the fruits are to ensue:
That profit's yet to come 'tween me and you.
Good night.
paragraphs.translated: Iago's a good man. Goodnight, Michael. Come talk to me tomorrow as early as you can. - Come with me, my dear love. Now that the wedding's over, we can have the pleasure of consummating our marriage. Good night, everyone.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt OTHELLO, DESDEMONA, and attendants
paragraphs.translated: OTHELLO and DESDEMONA exit with their attendants.

paragraphs.original: Enter IAGO
paragraphs.translated: IAGO enters.

paragraphs.original: Welcome, Iago. We must to the watch.
paragraphs.translated: Hello, Iago. It's time for us to stand guard.

paragraphs.original: Not this hour, lieutenant, 'tis not yet ten o' the clock. Our general cast us thus early for the love of his Desdemona - who let us not therefore blame. He hath not yet made wanton the night with her, and she is sport for Jove.
paragraphs.translated:
Not yet, lieutenant. It's not even ten o'clock. The general got rid of us early tonight so he could be with Desdemona. - I can't blame him. He hasn't spent the night with her yet, and she's beautiful enough to be
Jove's lover.
Jove's

paragraphs.original: She's a most exquisite lady.
paragraphs.translated: She's an exquisitely beautiful lady.

paragraphs.original: And, I'll warrant her, full of game.
paragraphs.translated: And I bet she's good in bed too.

paragraphs.original: Indeed she's a most fresh and delicate creature.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, she's young and tender.

paragraphs.original: What an eye she has! Methinks it sounds a parley to provocation.
paragraphs.translated: And such pretty eyes! Like an invitation.

paragraphs.original: An inviting eye, and yet methinks right modest.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, she's pretty. But she's modest and ladylike too.

paragraphs.original: And when she speaks, is it not an alarum to love?
paragraphs.translated: And when she speaks, doesn't her voice stir up passion?

paragraphs.original: She is indeed perfection.
paragraphs.translated: She's a perfect woman, it's true.

paragraphs.original: Well, happiness to their sheets! Come, lieutenant, I have a stoup of wine, and here without are a brace of Cyprus gallants that would fain have a measure to the health of black Othello.
paragraphs.translated: Well, good luck to them tonight in bed! Come with us, lieutenant. I've got a jug of wine, and these two Cyprus gentlemen want to drink a toast to the black Othello.

paragraphs.original: Not tonight, good Iago. I have very poor and unhappy brains for drinking. I could well wish courtesy would invent some other custom of entertainment.
paragraphs.translated: Not tonight, Iago. I'm not much of a drinker. I wish there was less social pressure to drink.

paragraphs.original: Oh, they are our friends. But one cup. I'll drink for you.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, but these are our friends. Just one glass. I'll do most of the drinking for you.

paragraphs.original: I have drunk but one cup tonight, and that was craftily qualified too, and behold what innovation it makes here. I am unfortunate in the infirmity, and dare not task my weakness with any more.
paragraphs.translated: I've already had a glass of wine tonight, watered down, but look how drunk I am. I'm not a heavy drinker. I wouldn't dare drink much more than that.

paragraphs.original: What, man, 'tis a night of revels! The gallants desire it.
paragraphs.translated: What are you talking about, man? Tonight is for celebrating! The gentlemen are waiting.

paragraphs.original: Where are they?
paragraphs.translated: Where are they?

paragraphs.original: Here at the door. I pray you call them in.
paragraphs.translated: By the door. Please invite them in.

paragraphs.original: I'll do 't, but it dislikes me.
paragraphs.translated: I'll do it, but I don't like it.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: CASSIO exits.

paragraphs.original:
If I can fasten but one cup upon him,
With that which he hath drunk tonight already,
He'll be as full of quarrel and offense
As my young mistress' dog. Now my sick fool Roderigo,
Whom love hath turned almost the wrong side out,
To Desdemona hath tonight caroused
Potations pottle-deep, and he's to watch.
Three lads of Cyprus, noble swelling spirits
(That hold their honors in a wary distance,
The very elements of this warlike isle)
Have I tonight flustered with flowing cups,
And they watch too. Now 'mongst this flock of drunkards
Am I to put our Cassio in some action
That may offend the isle.
But here they come.
If consequence do but approve my dream
My boat sails freely, both with wind and stream.
paragraphs.translated: If I can just get him to drink one more glass after what he's drunk already, he'll be as argumentative and eager to fight as a little dog. That fool Roderigo, all twisted up inside with love, has been drinking toasts to Desdemona by the gallon, and he's on guard duty.I've gotten the rest of the guards drunk, as well as several gentlemen from Cyprus who are quick to take offense. Now I'll get Cassio to do something in front of all these drunkards that will offend everyone on the island. Here they come. If the future turns out as I hope it will, I'm all set for success.

paragraphs.original: Enter CASSIO, MONTANO and gentlemen
paragraphs.translated: CASSIO, MONTANO, and GENTLEMEN enter, followed by servants with wine.

paragraphs.original: 'Fore heaven, they have given me a rouse already.
paragraphs.translated: My God, they've given me a lot to drink.

paragraphs.original: Good faith, a little one, not past a pint, As I am a soldier.
paragraphs.translated: No, it was a little one, not more than a pint.

paragraphs.original:
Some wine, ho!
(sings)
(sings)
And let me the cannikin clink, clink,
And let me the cannikin clink, clink,
And let me the cannikin clink.
And let me the cannikin clink.
A soldier's a man,
A soldier's a man,
A life's but a span,
A life's but a span,
Why then let a soldier drink.
Why then let a soldier drink.
Some wine, boys!
Some wine, boys!
paragraphs.translated:
Bring in more wine!
(he sings)
(he sings)
And clink your glasses together,
And clink your glasses together
And clink your glasses together.
And clink your glasses together
A soldier's a man,
A soldier's a man
And a man's life is short,
And a man's life is short
So let the soldier drink.
So let the soldier drink
Have some more wine, boys!
Have some more wine, boys!

paragraphs.original: Fore heaven, an excellent song.
paragraphs.translated: My God, what a great song!

paragraphs.original: I learned it in England where indeed they are most potent in potting. Your Dane, your German, and your swag-bellied Hollander - Drink, ho! - are nothing to your English.
paragraphs.translated: I learned it in England, where they have a talent for drinking. The Danes, the Germans, and the Dutch - come on, drink, drink! - are nothing compared to the English.

paragraphs.original: Is your Englishman so expert in his drinking?
paragraphs.translated: Are Englishmen really such heavy drinkers?

paragraphs.original: Why, he drinks you with facility your Dane dead drunk; he sweats not to overthrow your Almain. He gives your Hollander a vomit ere the next pottle can be filled.
paragraphs.translated: They drink Danes under the table, and it takes them no effort at all to out-drink Germans. And the Dutch are vomiting while the English are asking for refills.

paragraphs.original: To the health of our general!
paragraphs.translated: Let's drink to our general!

paragraphs.original: I am for it, lieutenant, and I'll do you justice.
paragraphs.translated: Hear, hear! I'll drink as much as you do!

paragraphs.original:
Oh, sweet England!
(sings)
(sings)
King Stephen was a worthy peer,
King Stephen was a worthy peer,
His breeches cost him but a crown,
His breeches cost him but a crown,
He held them sixpence all too dear,
He held them sixpence all too dear,
With that he called the tailor lown.
With that he called the tailor lown.
He was a wight of high renown,
He was a wight of high renown,
And thou art but of low degree,
And thou art but of low degree,
'Tis pride that pulls the country down,
'Tis pride that pulls the country down,
Then take thine auld cloak about thee.
Then take thine auld cloak about thee.
Some wine, ho!
Some wine, ho!
paragraphs.translated:
Oh, sweet England!
(he sings)
(he sings)
King Stephen was a good king, and his pants were very cheap,
King Stephen was a good king, and his pants were very cheap
But he thought his tailor overcharged him, so he called him a peasant.
But he thought his tailor overcharged him, so he called him a peasant
And that was a man of noble rank, much higher than you are.
And that was a man of noble rank, much higher than you are
So be happy with your worn-out cloak,
So be happy with your worn-out cloak
Since pride is ruining the nation.
Since pride is ruining the nation
More wine!
More wine!

paragraphs.original: Why, this is a more exquisite song than the other.
paragraphs.translated: God, that song's even better than the other one.

paragraphs.original: Will you hear 't again?
paragraphs.translated: Do you want to hear it again?

paragraphs.original: No, for I hold him to be unworthy of his place that does those things. Well, heaven's above all, and there be souls must be saved, and there be souls must not be saved.
paragraphs.translated: No, because we shouldn't be doing that - stuff. Oh well, God's in charge, and some people have to go to heaven, while other people have to go to hell.

paragraphs.original: It's true, good lieutenant.
paragraphs.translated: That's true, lieutenant.

paragraphs.original: For mine own part, no offence to the general nor any man of quality, I hope to be saved.
paragraphs.translated: Speaking for myself - and no offense to the general or anyone else - I hope I'm going to heaven.

paragraphs.original: And so do I too, lieutenant.
paragraphs.translated: Me too, lieutenant.

paragraphs.original: Ay, but (by your leave) not before me. The lieutenant is to be saved before the ancient. Let's have no more of this, let's to our affairs. - Forgive us our sins! - Gentlemen, let's look to our business. Do not think, gentlemen, I am drunk. This is my ancient, this is my right hand, and this is my left. I am not drunk now. I can stand well enough, and I speak well enough.
paragraphs.translated:
Okay, but please not before me. The lieutenant has to get to heaven before the ensign. But let's stop this drinking and get down to business. - God forgive our sins! - Gentlemen, let's get down to business. By the way, I don't want anyone thinking I'm drunk. This is my ensign. This is my right hand, and this is my left hand.
I'm not drunk. I can stand well enough, and I can speak just fine.

paragraphs.original: Excellent well!
paragraphs.translated: Yes, you're speaking very well.

paragraphs.original: Why, very well then. You must not think then that I am drunk.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, very well. So don't think that I'm drunk.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: CASSIO exits.

paragraphs.original: To th' platform, masters. Come, let's set the watch.
paragraphs.translated: Let's go to the platform where we'll stand guard. Come on.

paragraphs.original: Exit GENTLEMEN
paragraphs.translated: GENTLEMEN exit.

paragraphs.original:
You see this fellow that is gone before,
He is a soldier fit to stand by Caesar
And give direction. And do but see his vice,
'Tis to his virtue a just equinox,
The one as long as th' other. 'Tis pity of him.
I fear the trust Othello puts him in
On some odd time of his infirmity
Will shake this island.
paragraphs.translated: You see that man who just left? He's a good soldier, good enough to be Caesar's right-hand man. But he has a serious weakness. It's too bad. I'm worried that Othello trusts him too much, and it'll be bad for Cyprus eventually.

paragraphs.original: But is he often thus?
paragraphs.translated: But is he often like this?

paragraphs.original:
'Tis evermore the prologue to his sleep.
He'll watch the horologe a double set
If drink rock not his cradle.
paragraphs.translated: He drinks like this every night before he goes to sleep. He'd stay up all night and all day if he didn't drink himself to sleep.

paragraphs.original:
It were well
The general were put in mind of it.
Perhaps he sees it not, or his good nature
Prizes the virtue that appears in Cassio
And looks not on his evils. Is not this true?
paragraphs.translated: The general should be informed about this. Maybe he's never noticed, or he only wants to see Cassio's good side. Don't you think so?

paragraphs.original: Enter RODERIGO
paragraphs.translated: RODERIGO enters.

paragraphs.original:
(aside) How now, Roderigo?
(aside)
I pray you, after the lieutenant, go!
paragraphs.translated:
(speaking so that only RODERIGO can hear) Hello, Roderigo. Please, follow the lieutenant. Hurry! Go!
(speaking so that only
can hear

paragraphs.original: Exit RODERIGO
paragraphs.translated: RODERIGO exits.

paragraphs.original:
And 'tis great pity that the noble Moor
Should hazard such a place as his own second
With one of an ingraft infirmity.
It were an honest action to say
So to the Moor.
paragraphs.translated: And it's too bad that the Moor chose a man with such a deep-rooted drinking problem as his second-in-command. We should definitely say something to the Moor.

paragraphs.original:
Not I, for this fair island.
I do love Cassio well, and would do much
To cure him of this evil -
paragraphs.translated: I wouldn't say anything, not if you gave me the whole island for doing so. I respect Cassio and I'd like to help cure his alcoholism -

paragraphs.original: Cry within "Help! help!"
paragraphs.translated: A voice offstage calls "Help! Help!"

paragraphs.original: But, hark! What noise?
paragraphs.translated: What's that noise?

paragraphs.original: Enter CASSIO, pursuing RODERIGO
paragraphs.translated: CASSIO enters, chasing RODERIGO.

paragraphs.original: Zounds! You rogue! You rascal!
paragraphs.translated: Damn you, you villain, you rascal!

paragraphs.original: What's the matter, lieutenant?
paragraphs.translated: What's the matter, lieutenant?

paragraphs.original:
A knave teach me my duty?
I'll beat the knave into a twiggen bottle.
paragraphs.translated: To think that fool had the nerve to try to teach me manners! I'll beat him until the welts look like basket-weave!

paragraphs.original: Beat me?
paragraphs.translated: You'll beat me?

paragraphs.original:
Dost thou prate, rogue? (strikes him)
(strikes him)

Nay, good lieutenant! I pray you, sir, hold your hand. (stays him)
(stays him)
Let me go, sir, or I'll knock you o'er the mazzard.
paragraphs.translated: Let me go, or I'll knock you on the head.

paragraphs.original: Come, come, you're drunk.
paragraphs.translated: Come on, you're drunk.

paragraphs.original: Drunk?
paragraphs.translated: Drunk?

paragraphs.original: They fight
paragraphs.translated: MONTANO and CASSIO fight.

paragraphs.original:
(aside to RODERIGO)
(aside to
)
Away, I say, go out, and cry a mutiny. -
paragraphs.translated:
(speaking so that only RODERIGO can hear) Go tell everyone there's a riot. - 
(speaking so that only
can hear)

paragraphs.original: Exit RODERIGO
paragraphs.translated: RODERIGO exits.

paragraphs.original:
Nay, good lieutenant! Alas, gentlemen - 
Help, ho! -  Lieutenant - sir, Montano - 
Help, masters! - Here's a goodly watch indeed!
paragraphs.translated: No, lieutenant - God, gentlemen - Help - Lieutenant - sir, Montano - Help, men! - The night guard is coming!

paragraphs.original: Bell rings
paragraphs.translated: Someone rings a bell.

paragraphs.original:
Who's that which rings the bell? - Diablo, ho!
The town will rise. Fie, Fie, lieutenant,
You'll be ashamed for ever.
paragraphs.translated: Who's sounding that alarm? The whole town will riot! God, lieutenant, please stop! You'll be ashamed of this forever!

paragraphs.original: Enter OTHELLO and attendants
paragraphs.translated: OTHELLO enters with attendants.

paragraphs.original: What is the matter here?
paragraphs.translated: What is the matter here?

paragraphs.original:
I bleed still,
I am hurt to the death. He dies!
paragraphs.translated: My God, I'm bleeding! I've been mortally wounded. I'll kill him!

paragraphs.original: Hold, for your lives!
paragraphs.translated: Stop right now!

paragraphs.original:
Hold, ho! Lieutenant - sir, Montano - gentlemen,
Have you forgot all place of sense and duty?
Hold! The general speaks to you. Hold, for shame!
paragraphs.translated: Stop! Lieutenant - sir, Montano - gentlemen! Have you forgotten your duty and your sense of decorum? Stop! The general is talking to you! Stop, for God's sake!

paragraphs.original:
Why, how now, ho! From whence ariseth this?
Are we turned Turks? And to ourselves do that
Which heaven hath forbid the Ottomites?
For Christian shame, put by this barbarous brawl.
He that stirs next to carve for his own rage
Holds his soul light, he dies upon his motion.
Silence that dreadful bell, it frights the isle
From her propriety. What is the matter, masters? - 
Honest Iago, that looks dead with grieving,
Speak, who began this? On thy love, I charge thee.
paragraphs.translated: How did this all start? Have we all become as savage as the Turks, treating each other as badly as they would have treated us? For heaven's sake, stop this savage brawl! The next man who swings his sword must not care about his life, because the instant he strikes, he dies. Stop that alarm from ringing, it's scaring the islanders. What's the matter here, gentlemen? - Honest Iago, you look upset. Speak up and tell me who started this. Answer me.

paragraphs.original:
I do not know. Friends all but now, even now,
In quarter, and in terms like bride and groom
Divesting them for bed. And then, but now,
As if some planet had unwitted men,
paragraphs.translated: I don't know. We were all having fun until just a minute ago; we were as happy as a bride and groom taking off their clothes. But then the mood suddenly changed. It was as if something had driven the men insane and made them point their swords at one another. I don't

paragraphs.original:
Swords out, and tilting one at other's breasts
In opposition bloody. I cannot speak
Any beginning to this peevish odds,
And would in action glorious I had lost
Those legs that brought me to a part of it.
paragraphs.translated: know what could have started this. I'd rather have lost my legs in battle than be a part of this!

paragraphs.original: How comes it, Michael, you are thus forgot?
paragraphs.translated: How did you manage to lose your self-control like this, Michael?

paragraphs.original: I pray you pardon me, I cannot speak.
paragraphs.translated: Please, excuse me, sir. I can't speak.

paragraphs.original:
Worthy Montano, you were wont be civil.
The gravity and stillness of your youth
The world hath noted, and your name is great
In mouths of wisest censure. What's the matter
That you unlace your reputation thus
And spend your rich opinion for the name
Of a night-brawler? Give me answer to it.
paragraphs.translated: Montano, you're supposed to be calm and collected. You're famous for it. Wise people respect you. What in the world made you risk your reputation like this and become a street brawler? Tell me.

paragraphs.original:
Worthy Othello, I am hurt to danger.
Your officer Iago can inform you,
While I spare speech, which something now offends me,
Of all that I do know. Nor know I aught
By me that's said or done amiss this night,
Unless self-charity be sometimes a vice,
And to defend ourselves it be a sin
When violence assails us.
paragraphs.translated: Othello, I've been seriously hurt. Your officer Iago can tell you what happened. I should save my breath, since it hurts to talk. I didn't do anything wrong that I know of, unless it was a sin to defend myself when someone attacked me.

paragraphs.original:
Now, by heaven,
My blood begins my safer guides to rule,
And passion, having my best judgment collied,
Assays to lead the way. If I once stir,
paragraphs.translated: All right, now I'm starting to lose my cool. By God, if you don't tell me what happened you'll all suffer. Tell me how this fight began, who started it. Whoever is guilty, even if he were my twin brother, I swear I'm through with him. We're in a town that's just

paragraphs.original:
Or do but lift this arm, the best of you
Shall sink in my rebuke. Give me to know
How this foul rout began, who set it on,
And he that is approved in this offence,
Though he had twinned with me, both at a birth,
Shall lose me. What, in a town of war
Yet wild, the people's hearts brimful of fear,
To manage private and domestic quarrel?
In night, and on the court and guard of safety?
'Tis monstrous. Iago, who began 't?
paragraphs.translated: avoided a war, everyone's still on edge, and you're getting into private fights while you're supposed to be on guard duty? That's unbelievably bad. Iago, who started it?

paragraphs.original:
If partially affined or leagued in office
Thou dost deliver more or less than truth
Thou art no soldier.
paragraphs.translated: I know you're close to Cassio, but if you diverge from the truth in any way, you're not a true soldier.

paragraphs.original:
Touch me not so near.
I had rather have this tongue cut from my mouth
Than it should do offence to Michael Cassio.
Yet I persuade myself to speak the truth
Shall nothing wrong him. This it is, general:
Montano and myself being in speech,
There comes a fellow crying out for help
And Cassio following him with determined sword
To execute upon him. Sir, this gentleman
Steps in to Cassio and entreats his pause,
Myself the crying fellow did pursue,
Lest by his clamor - as it so fell out - 
The town might fall in fright. He, swift of foot,
Outran my purpose, and I returned then rather
For that I heard the clink and fall of swords
And Cassio high in oath, which till tonight
I ne'er might say before. When I came back - 
For this was brief -  I found them close together
At blow and thrust, even as again they were
When you yourself did part them.
More of this matter cannot I report.
paragraphs.translated: You're hitting close to home there. I'd rather cut my tongue out of my mouth than say anything bad about Michael Cassio. But I don't think it'll hurt him to tell the truth. This is what happened, General. Montano and I were talking when a man came running, crying for help. Cassio was chasing him with his sword out, trying to kill the guy. This gentleman stopped Cassio and told him to put away his sword. I followed the guy who was crying for help, to keep him from scaring the public. But he was fast and outran me. When I got back, I heard the swords clinking and Cassio swearing. I'd never heard him swear before. They were nearly killing each other, as you saw when you pulled them apart. I can't tell you anything else.

paragraphs.original:
But men are men, the best sometimes forget.
Though Cassio did some little wrong to him,
As men in rage strike those that wish them best,
Yet surely Cassio, I believe, received
From him that fled some strange indignity
Which patience could not pass.
paragraphs.translated: But nobody's perfect, and even the best man sometimes loses control and strikes out in rage. Cassio was wrong to hurt Montano, who was only trying to help him, but I'm sure the guy who ran away must have offended Cassio in some terrible way, and Cassio couldn't let it pass.

paragraphs.original:
I know, Iago,
Thy honesty and love doth mince this matter,
Making it light to Cassio. Cassio, I love thee
But never more be officer of mine. -
paragraphs.translated: Iago, I know you're fond of Cassio and are downplaying this for his benefit. Cassio, I love you, but you're never again going to be one of my officers. -

paragraphs.original: Enter DESDEMONA, attended
paragraphs.translated: DESDEMONA enters with attendants.

paragraphs.original:
Look, if my gentle love be not raised up!
I'll make thee an example.
paragraphs.translated: Look, you've woken my wife! I'll make you an example for the others to learn from.

paragraphs.original: What's the matter, dear?
paragraphs.translated: What's the matter, dear?

paragraphs.original:
All's well, sweeting,
Come away to bed. - (to MONTANO) Sir, for your hurts
(to
)
Myself will be your surgeon. Lead him off.
MONTANO is led off
paragraphs.translated: MONTANO is carried off.

paragraphs.original:
Iago, look with care about the town
And silence those whom this vile brawl distracted. - 
Come, Desdemona, 'tis the soldiers' life
To have their balmy slumbers waked with strife.
paragraphs.translated: Iago, go and calm down the townspeople. - Come with me, Desdemona. Unfortunately, it's part of the soldier's life to be woken up by trouble.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt all but IAGO and CASSIO
paragraphs.translated: Everyone except CASSIO and IAGO exits.

paragraphs.original: What, are you hurt, lieutenant?
paragraphs.translated: Are you hurt, lieutenant?

paragraphs.original: Ay, past all surgery.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, but no doctor can help me.

paragraphs.original: Marry, heaven forbid!
paragraphs.translated: Oh I hope that's not true!

paragraphs.original: Reputation, reputation, reputation! Oh, I have lost my reputation! I have lost the immortal part of myself, and what remains is bestial. My reputation, Iago, my reputation!
paragraphs.translated: My reputation, my reputation! I've lost my reputation, the longest-living and truest part of myself! Everything else in me is just animal-like. Oh, my reputation, Iago, my reputation!

paragraphs.original: As I am an honest man, I thought you had received some bodily wound. There is more sense in that than in reputation. Reputation is an idle and most false imposition, oft got without merit and lost without deserving. You have lost no reputation at all unless you repute yourself such a loser. What, man, there are ways to recover the general again. You are but now cast in his mood, a punishment more in policy than in malice, even so as one would beat his offenseless dog to affright an imperious lion. Sue to him again and he's yours.
paragraphs.translated: I swear I thought you meant you'd been hurt physically. Your physical health matters more than your reputation. A reputation is a useless and fake quality that others impose on us. You haven't lost it unless you think you have. There are lots of ways to get on the general's good side again. You've been discharged because he's angry, and because he's obliged to do so for policy reasons, not because he dislikes you. He's got to beat up the weak to frighten the strong. Go to him, petition him. He'll change his mind.

paragraphs.original: I will rather sue to be despised than to deceive so good a commander with so slight, so drunken, and so indiscreet an officer. Drunk? And speak parrot? And squabble? Swagger? Swear? And discourse fustian with one's own shadow? O thou invisible spirit of wine, if thou hast no name to be known by, let us call thee devil!
paragraphs.translated: I'd rather ask him to hate me than ask such a good commander to accept such a worthless, drunk, stupid officer as myself. Drunk? Babbling senselessly? Squabbling? Swaggering? Swearing? Ranting and raving to my own shadow! Oh, wine is the devil!

paragraphs.original: What was he that you followed with your sword? What had he done to you?
paragraphs.translated: Who were you chasing with your sword? What did he do to you?

paragraphs.original: I know not.
paragraphs.translated: I don't know.

paragraphs.original: Is 't possible?
paragraphs.translated: Is that possible?

paragraphs.original: I remember a mass of things, but nothing distinctly. A quarrel, but nothing wherefore. Oh, that men should put an enemy in their mouths to steal away their brains! That we should, with joy, pleasance revel and applause, transform ourselves into beasts!
paragraphs.translated: I remember a jumble of impressions, but nothing distinctly. I remember a fight, but not why we were fighting. Oh God, why do men drink and lose their minds? Why do we party until we're like animals?

paragraphs.original: Why, but you are now well enough. How came you thus recovered?
paragraphs.translated: You seem all right now. How did you get better?

paragraphs.original: It hath pleased the devil drunkenness to give place to the devil wrath. One unperfectness shows me another, to make me frankly despise myself.
paragraphs.translated: My drunkenness went away when anger took over. One weakness led to another, to make me hate myself.

paragraphs.original: Come, you are too severe a moraler. As the time, the place, and the condition of this country stands, I could heartily wish this had not befallen. But since it is as it is, mend it for your own good.
paragraphs.translated: Come on, you're being too hard on yourself. I wish none of this had happened, given the situation here, and your rank. But since this has happened, you should fix it for your own good.

paragraphs.original: I will ask him for my place again, he shall tell me I am a drunkard. Had I as many mouths as Hydra, such an answer would stop them all. To be now a sensible man, by and by a fool, and presently a beast! Oh, strange! Every inordinate cup is unblessed and the ingredient is a devil.
paragraphs.translated: I'll ask him for my position back again, and he'll tell me I'm a drunk. Even if I had a whole bunch of mouths, I wouldn't be able to answer that. I was a reasonable man, then I became a fool, and finally a beast! Oh, how strange! Every glass of liquor is damned, and the devil's the main ingredient!

paragraphs.original: Come, come, good wine is a good familiar creature, if it be well used. Exclaim no more against it. And, good lieutenant, I think you think I love you.
paragraphs.translated: Come on now, wine is good for you, if you know how to use it. Don't say anything bad about wine anymore. Lieutenant, I think you know I'm your friend.

paragraphs.original: I have well approved it, sir. I drunk!
paragraphs.translated: I know that, sir. Imagine, me, a drunk!

paragraphs.original: You or any man living may be drunk at a time, man. I tell you what you shall do. Our general's wife is now the general. I may say so in this respect, for that he hath devoted and given up himself to the contemplation, mark, and denotement of her parts and graces. Confess yourself freely to her, importune her help to put you in your place again. She is of so free, so kind, so apt, so blessed a disposition, she holds it a vice in her goodness not to do more than she is requested. This broken joint between you and her husband entreat her to splinter, and, my fortunes against any lay worth naming, this crack of your love shall grow stronger than it was before.
paragraphs.translated: Any man can get drunk sometime. I'll tell you what to do. Othello's wife has a lot of influence now. He's completely devoted to her. Go open your heart to her. Ask her to help you get back your position. She is so generous, kind, and ready to help that she thinks it's wrong not to do everything she can, even more than she is asked to do. Ask her to help you heal the rift between her husband and you. I'd bet my lucky stars your problem will be forgotten, and your relationship will be stronger than ever.

paragraphs.original: You advise me well.
paragraphs.translated: That's good advice.

paragraphs.original: I protest, in the sincerity of love and honest kindness.
paragraphs.translated: I'm helping you because I like and respect you.

paragraphs.original: I think it freely, and betimes in the morning I will beseech the virtuous Desdemona to undertake for me. I am desperate of my fortunes if they check me.
paragraphs.translated: I believe it completely. Early in the morning I'll go visit Desdemona and plead my case. My situation is desperate.

paragraphs.original: You are in the right. Good night, lieutenant, I must to the watch.
paragraphs.translated: You're doing the right thing. Good night, lieutenant. I've got to go to the guard tower.

paragraphs.original: Good night, honest Iago.
paragraphs.translated: Good night, honest Iago.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: CASSIO exits.

paragraphs.original:
And what's he then that says I play the villain?
When this advice is free I give and honest,
Probal to thinking and indeed the course
To win the Moor again? For 'tis most easy
Th' inclining Desdemona to subdue
In any honest suit. She's framed as fruitful
As the free elements. And then for her
To win the Moor, were to renounce his baptism,
All seals and symbols of redeemèd sin,
His soul is so enfettered to her love,
That she may make, unmake, do what she list,
Even as her appetite shall play the god
With his weak function. How am I then a villain
To counsel Cassio to this parallel course,
Directly to his good? Divinity of hell!
When devils will the blackest sins put on
They do suggest at first with heavenly shows
As I do now. For whiles this honest fool
Plies Desdemona to repair his fortune
And she for him pleads strongly to the Moor,
I'll pour this pestilence into his ear:
paragraphs.translated: Who can say I'm evil when my advice is so good? That's really the best way to win the Moor back again. It's easy to get Desdemona on your side. She's full of good intentions. And the Moor loves her so much he would renounce his Christianity to keep her happy. He's so enslaved by love that she can make him do whatever she wants. How am I evil to advise Cassio to do exactly what'll do him good? That's the kind of argument you'd expect from Satan! When devils are about to commit their biggest sins they put on their most heavenly faces, just like I'm doing now. And while this fool is begging Desdemona to help him, and while she's pleading his case to the Moor, I'll poison the Moor's ear against her, hinting that she's taking Cassio's side because of her lust for him. The more she

paragraphs.original:
That she repeals him for her body's lust.
And by how much she strives to do him good
She shall undo her credit with the Moor.
So will I turn her virtue into pitch
And out of her own goodness make the net
That shall enmesh them all.
paragraphs.translated: tries to help Cassio, the more she'll shake Othello's confidence in her. And that's how I'll turn her good intentions into a big trap to snag them all.

paragraphs.original: Enter RODERIGO
paragraphs.translated: RODERIGO enters.

paragraphs.original: How now, Roderigo!
paragraphs.translated: Hello, Roderigo!

paragraphs.original: I do follow here in the chase not like a hound that hunts, but one that fills up the cry. My money is almost spent, I have been tonight exceedingly well cudgeled, and I think the issue will be I shall have so much experience for my pains. And so, with no money at all and a little more wit, return again to Venice.
paragraphs.translated: I'm totally worn out. My chase is too much for me. I've spent most of my money, and tonight I got beaten up. The upshot is that I've got a little more experience. So with no money, but a little more wisdom, I'm going back to Venice.

paragraphs.original:
How poor are they that have not patience!
What wound did ever heal but by degrees?
Thou know'st we work by wit and not by witchcraft,
And wit depends on dilatory time.
Does't not go well? Cassio hath beaten thee.
And thou, by that small hurt, hath cashiered Cassio.
Though other things grow fair against the sun,
Yet fruits that blossom first will first be ripe.
Content thyself awhile. In troth, 'tis morning.
Pleasure and action make the hours seem short.
Retire thee, go where thou art billeted.
Away, I say, thou shalt know more hereafter.
Nay, get thee gone.
paragraphs.translated: You're a poor man if you're this impatient! If you get hurt, does your wound heal immediately? No, it heals gradually. We achieve things with our intelligence, not by magic, and intelligent planning takes time. Aren't things going well? Cassio's beaten you up, but with that tiny sacrifice on your part, you got Cassio discharged! If we're patient, we'll be rewarded with the fruits of our labors. My God, it's morning. All this excitement has made the time fly by. Go back to where you're staying and go to sleep. Go on, I'm telling you. You'll understand better later. Go.

paragraphs.original: Exit RODERIGO
paragraphs.translated: RODERIGO exits.

paragraphs.original:
Two things are to be done:
My wife must move for Cassio to her mistress.
I'll set her on.
Myself, the while, to draw the Moor apart
And bring him jump when he may Cassio find
Soliciting his wife. Ay, that's the way.
Dull not device by coldness and delay.
paragraphs.translated: Now two things still need to be done. My wife has to help make Desdemona take Cassio's side. I'll put her on that. And I need to take the Moor aside right at the moment when Cassio's talking to Desdemona, so he'll see them together. Yes, that's the way I'll do it. Let's not ruin a brilliant plan by being slow to act.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: IAGO exits.

paragraphs.original: Enter CASSIO and MUSICIANS
paragraphs.translated: CASSIO enters with MUSICIANS.

paragraphs.original:
Masters, play here, I will content your pains.
Something that's brief, and bid "Good morrow, general."
paragraphs.translated: Musicians, start playing here. I'll pay you for your trouble. Play something short that will put the general in a good mood.

paragraphs.original: They play. Enter CLOWN
paragraphs.translated: The MUSICIANS play. The CLOWN enters.

paragraphs.original: Why masters, have your instruments been in Naples, that they speak i' th' nose thus?
paragraphs.translated:
Your instruments all have a nasal twang. Have they been to
Naples?
Naples

paragraphs.original: How, sir? How?
paragraphs.translated: Excuse me?

paragraphs.original: Are these, I pray you, wind instruments?
paragraphs.translated: Are these wind instruments?

paragraphs.original: Ay, marry, are they, sir.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, they are.

paragraphs.original: Oh, thereby hangs a tail.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, there's the problem.

paragraphs.original: Whereby hangs a tale, sir?
paragraphs.translated: What's the problem?

paragraphs.original: Marry sir, by many a wind instrument that I know. But, masters, here's money for you, and the general so likes your music that he desires you, for love's sake, to make no more noise with it.
paragraphs.translated: Anyone full of hot air is a problem. But here's some money. The general likes your music a lot, but he asks you to stop playing now.

paragraphs.original: Well, sir, we will not.
paragraphs.translated: Well, we'll stop, then.

paragraphs.original: If you have any music that may not be heard, to 't again. But, as they say, to hear music the general does not greatly care.
paragraphs.translated: If you've got any music that can't be heard, then play that. But as I said, the general isn't really in the mood to hear music now.

paragraphs.original: We have none such, sir.
paragraphs.translated: We don't have any music that can't be heard.

paragraphs.original: Then put up your pipes in your bag, for I'll away. Go, vanish into air, away!
paragraphs.translated: Then pack up your instruments and go away. Go!

paragraphs.original: Exeunt MUSICIANS
paragraphs.translated: The MUSICIANS exit.

paragraphs.original: Dost thou hear, my honest friend?
paragraphs.translated: Do you hear, my friend?

paragraphs.original: No, I hear not your honest friend, I hear you.
paragraphs.translated: No, I don't hear your friend. I hear you.

paragraphs.original: Prithee, keep up thy quillets. There's a poor piece of gold for thee. If the gentlewoman that attends the general's wife be stirring, tell her there's one Cassio entreats her a little favour of speech. Wilt thou do this?
paragraphs.translated:
Please don't play games. (CASSIO gives CLOWN money). There's a bit of gold for you. When the woman taking care of the general's wife wakes up, could you please tell her that Cassio asks to speak with her?
gives
money)

paragraphs.original: She is stirring, sir. If she will stir hither, I shall seem to notify unto her.
paragraphs.translated: She's awake, sir. If she feels like coming over here, I'll give her your message.

paragraphs.original: Exit CLOWN
paragraphs.translated: The CLOWN exits.

paragraphs.original: Enter IAGO
paragraphs.translated: IAGO enters.

paragraphs.original: In happy time, Iago.
paragraphs.translated: Good to see you, Iago.

paragraphs.original: You have not been abed, then?
paragraphs.translated: You didn't go to sleep, then?

paragraphs.original:
Why, no. The day had broke
Before we parted. I have made bold, Iago,
To send in to your wife. My suit to her
Is that she will to virtuous Desdemona
Procure me some access.
paragraphs.translated: No. When I left you it was already morning. I've been bold, Iago. I've asked to talk to your wife. I'm going to ask her to let me talk to Desdemona.

paragraphs.original:
I'll send her to you presently,
And I'll devise a mean to draw the Moor
Out of the way, that your converse and business
May be more free.
paragraphs.translated: I'll send her out to you now. I'll think of a plan to get the Moor out of the way, so you can speak more openly.

paragraphs.original: I humbly thank you for't.
paragraphs.translated: I humbly thank you.

paragraphs.original: Exit IAGO
paragraphs.translated: IAGO exits.

paragraphs.original: I never knew a Florentine more kind and honest.
paragraphs.translated:
Even for a
Florentine, I never knew someone so kind and honest.
Florentine

paragraphs.original: Enter EMILIA
paragraphs.translated: EMILIA enters.

paragraphs.original:
Good morrow, good Lieutenant. I am sorry
For your displeasure, but all will sure be well.
The general and his wife are talking of it,
And she speaks for you stoutly. The Moor replies
That he you hurt is of great fame in Cyprus
And great affinity, and that in wholesome wisdom
He might not but refuse you. But he protests he loves you
And needs no other suitor but his likings
To take the safest occasion by the front
To bring you in again.
paragraphs.translated: Good morning, lieutenant. I'm sorry about what happened, but I'm sure everything will turn out all right. The general and his wife are talking about it now, and she's defending you strongly. The Moor says the man you hurt is very important in Cyprus, and that under the circumstances he has no choice but to refuse to reinstate you. But he says he still loves and respects you, and based on his own feelings alone he's looking for an opportunity to safely take you back.

paragraphs.original:
Yet I beseech you,
If you think fit, or that it may be done,
Give me advantage of some brief discourse
With Desdemona alone.
paragraphs.translated: Please find a way to give me some time alone with Desdemona, if you think that's all right.

paragraphs.original:
Pray you come in.
I will bestow you where you shall have time
To speak your bosom freely.
paragraphs.translated: Please come in. I'll take you to a place where you can speak freely.

paragraphs.original: I am much bound to you.
paragraphs.translated: Thank you very much.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter OTHELLO, IAGO, and GENTLEMEN
paragraphs.translated: OTHELLO, IAGO and GENTLEMEN enter.

paragraphs.original:
These letters give, Iago, to the pilot,
And by him do my duties to the senate.
That done, I will be walking on the works,
Repair there to me.
paragraphs.translated: Iago, give these letters to the ship's captain who brought me here, and ask him to pay my respects to the Senate of Venice. Now that's done, I'm going to walk on the fortification walls. Look for me there when you come back.

paragraphs.original: Well, my good lord, I'll do 't.
paragraphs.translated: I will, my lord.

paragraphs.original: This fortification, gentlemen, shall we see 't?
paragraphs.translated: Shall we go see this fortification, men?

paragraphs.original: We'll wait upon your lordship.
paragraphs.translated: We're at your service, my lord.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter DESDEMONA, CASSIO, and EMILIA
paragraphs.translated: DESDEMONA, CASSIO and EMILIA enter.

paragraphs.original:
Be thou assured, good Cassio, I will do
All my abilities in thy behalf.
paragraphs.translated: I'll do everything I can for you, Cassio.

paragraphs.original:
Good madam, do. I warrant it grieves my husband
As if the cause were his.
paragraphs.translated: Please do, madam. My husband's so upset about Cassio's problem you'd think it was his own.

paragraphs.original:
Oh, that's an honest fellow. Do not doubt, Cassio,
But I will have my lord and you again
As friendly as you were.
paragraphs.translated: Your husband's such a good man. Don't worry, Cassio. I'm sure you and my husband will be as friendly as you were before.

paragraphs.original:
Bounteous madam,
Whatever shall become of Michael Cassio,
He's never anything but your true servant.
paragraphs.translated: My dear beautiful lady, whatever happens to Michael Cassio, he'll always be your humble servant.

paragraphs.original:
I know 't, I thank you. You do love my lord.
You have known him long, and be you well assured
He shall in strangeness stand no farther off
Than in a polite distance.
paragraphs.translated: I know that. Thank you. You're my husband's friend and you've known him a long time. I assure you the only reason he's keeping away from you now is political.

paragraphs.original:
Ay, but, lady,
That policy may either last so long,
Or feed upon such nice and waterish diet,
Or breed itself so out of circumstances,
That, I being absent and my place supplied,
My general will forget my love and service.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, my lady. But those political considerations might last such a long time that the general will forget my love and service, especially if I'm gone and someone else has my job.

paragraphs.original:
Do not doubt that. Before Emilia here
I give thee warrant of thy place. Assure thee,
If I do vow a friendship, I'll perform it
To the last article. My lord shall never rest,
I'll watch him tame and talk him out of patience.
paragraphs.translated: That'll never happen. Emilia here will be my witness: I promise you that you'll get your position back again. And if I promise to help someone, I do everything I can. My husband will never get a moment's rest, I'll keep him up at night talking about you until he runs out

paragraphs.original:
His bed shall seem a school, his board a shrift,
I'll intermingle everything he does
With Cassio's suit. Therefore be merry, Cassio,
For thy solicitor shall rather die
Than give thy cause away.
paragraphs.translated: of patience. He will think that his bed has become a conference table for discussing your problem - he won't be able to get away from it. I'll bring up your name at every moment. So cheer up. I'm your advocate, and I'd rather die than give up on you.

paragraphs.original: Enter OTHELLO and IAGO
paragraphs.translated: OTHELLO and IAGO enter.

paragraphs.original: Madam, here comes my lord.
paragraphs.translated: Madam, here comes your husband.

paragraphs.original: Madam, I'll take my leave.
paragraphs.translated: Madam, I'd better leave now.

paragraphs.original: Why, stay and hear me speak.
paragraphs.translated: Why not stay and hear me talk to him?

paragraphs.original:
Madam, not now. I am very ill at ease,
Unfit for mine own purposes.
paragraphs.translated: No, madam. I'm very uncomfortable, and that won't help my case.

paragraphs.original: Well, do your discretion.
paragraphs.translated: Well, do whatever you think best.

paragraphs.original: Exit CASSIO
paragraphs.translated: CASSIO exits.

paragraphs.original: Ha! I like not that.
paragraphs.translated: Hey! I don't like that.

paragraphs.original: What dost thou say?
paragraphs.translated: What did you say?

paragraphs.original: Nothing, my lord, or if - I know not what.
paragraphs.translated: Nothing, my lord, or if I did - I don't know what.

paragraphs.original: Was not that Cassio parted from my wife?
paragraphs.translated: Wasn't that Cassio leaving my wife?

paragraphs.original:
Cassio, my lord? No, sure, I cannot think it
That he would steal away so guilty-like
Seeing you coming.
paragraphs.translated: Cassio, my lord? No, I don't think so. He wouldn't sneak away looking so guilty when he saw you coming.

paragraphs.original: I do believe 'twas he.
paragraphs.translated: I really think it was him.

paragraphs.original:
How now, my lord?
I have been talking with a suitor here,
A man that languishes in your displeasure.
paragraphs.translated: What's this, my lord? I was talking to a petitioner here just now, someone who's suffering from your anger.

paragraphs.original: Who is 't you mean?
paragraphs.translated: Who do you mean?

paragraphs.original:
Why, your lieutenant, Cassio. Good my lord,
If I have any grace or power to move you
His present reconciliation take.
For if he be not one that truly loves you,
That errs in ignorance and not in cunning,
I have no judgment in an honest face.
I prithee, call him back.
paragraphs.translated: Your lieutenant, Cassio. Oh, if I've got any influence over you at all, please patch things up with him. In my judgment, this man truly loves you, and his mistake was innocent rather than wicked. Please call him and tell him to come back here.

paragraphs.original: Went he hence now?
paragraphs.translated: Was that him just now?

paragraphs.original:
Ay, sooth, so humbled
That he hath left part of his grief with me
To suffer with him. Good love, call him back.
paragraphs.translated: Yes. He feels so bad and humble that I feel bad along with him. My love, call him back in here.

paragraphs.original: Not now, sweet Desdemona. Some other time.
paragraphs.translated: Not now, my sweet Desdemona. Some other time.

paragraphs.original: But shall 't be shortly?
paragraphs.translated: But will it be soon?

paragraphs.original: The sooner, sweet, for you.
paragraphs.translated: Very soon, because you want it.

paragraphs.original: Shall 't be tonight at supper?
paragraphs.translated: Will it be tonight at supper?

paragraphs.original: No, not tonight.
paragraphs.translated: No, not tonight.

paragraphs.original: Tomorrow dinner, then?
paragraphs.translated: Then tomorrow at dinner?

paragraphs.original:
I shall not dine at home,
I meet the captains at the citadel.
paragraphs.translated: I won't be eating dinner at home. I'll be meeting the captains at the citadel.

paragraphs.original:
Why, then, tomorrow night, or Tuesday morn.
On Tuesday noon, or night, or Wednesday morn.
I prithee name the time, but let it not
Exceed three days. In faith, he's penitent,
And yet his trespass, in our common reason
(Save that, they say, the wars must make example
Out of her best) is not, almost, a fault
T' incur a private check. When shall he come?
Tell me, Othello. I wonder in my soul
What you would ask me that I should deny
Or stand so mamm'ring on. What? Michael Cassio
That came a-wooing with you, and so many a time,
When I have spoke of you dispraisingly,
Hath ta'en your part, to have so much to do
To bring him in? Trust me, I could do much -
paragraphs.translated: Well then, tomorrow night, or Tuesday morning. Or Tuesday noon or at night, or Wednesday morning. Please just name a time, but don't wait more than three days. He's very sorry. His mistake was hardly worth punishing him for in the first place - though in wartime it is sometimes necessary to make examples out of even the best soldiers. So when should he come? Tell me, Othello. I can't imagine you asking me for something and me telling you no or standing there muttering. Michael Cassio came with you when you were trying to win my love. Sometimes I'd criticize you to him, and he'd defend you. And now I have to make this big fuss about bringing him back? I swear, I could do so much -

paragraphs.original:
Prithee, no more. Let him come when he will,
I will deny thee nothing.
paragraphs.translated: Please, no more. He can come whenever he wants. I won't refuse you anything.

paragraphs.original:
Why, this is not a boon,
'Tis as I should entreat you wear your gloves,
Or feed on nourishing dishes, or keep you warm,
Or sue to you to do a peculiar profit
To your own person. Nay, when I have a suit
Wherein I mean to touch your love indeed
It shall be full of poise and difficult weight
And fearful to be granted.
paragraphs.translated: Don't act like you're doing me a favor! This is like if I asked you to wear your gloves when it's cold outside, or eat nutritious food, or do something that's good for you. If I ever have to ask you for something that will put your luck to the test, it'll be something difficult and terrible.

paragraphs.original:
I will deny thee nothing!
Whereon I do beseech thee, grant me this,
To leave me but a little to myself.
paragraphs.translated: I won't deny you anything! But in return, please, do one thing for me: leave me alone for a little while.

paragraphs.original: Shall I deny you? No. Farewell, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: Would I ever deny you anything? No. Goodbye, my husband.

paragraphs.original: Farewell, my Desdemona. I'll come to thee straight.
paragraphs.translated: Goodbye, my Desdemona. I'll come see you right away.

paragraphs.original:
Emilia, come. - Be as your fancies teach you.
Whate'er you be, I am obedient.
paragraphs.translated: Come here, Emilia. - Do whatever you feel like doing, my husband, and I'll obey you.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt DESDEMONA and EMILIA
paragraphs.translated: DESDEMONA and EMILIA exit.

paragraphs.original:
Excellent wretch! Perdition catch my soul
But I do love thee! And when I love thee not
Chaos is come again.
paragraphs.translated: What a wonderful girl! God help me, I love you! And when I stop loving you, the universe will fall back into the chaos that was there when time began.

paragraphs.original: My noble lord -
paragraphs.translated: My noble lord -

paragraphs.original: What dost thou say, Iago?
paragraphs.translated: What is it, Iago?

paragraphs.original:
Did Michael Cassio, when you wooed my lady,
Know of your love?
paragraphs.translated: When you were wooing Desdemona, did Michael Cassio know about it?

paragraphs.original:
He did, from first to last.
Why dost thou ask?
paragraphs.translated: Yes, he knew about it the whole time. Why do you ask?

paragraphs.original:
But for a satisfaction of my thought,
No further harm.
paragraphs.translated: I was just curious. No reason.

paragraphs.original: Why of thy thought, Iago?
paragraphs.translated: Why are you curious, Iago?

paragraphs.original: I did not think he had been acquainted with her.
paragraphs.translated: I didn't realize he knew her.

paragraphs.original: Oh, yes, and went between us very oft.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, yes. He carried messages back and forth between us very often.

paragraphs.original: Indeed?
paragraphs.translated: Oh, really?

paragraphs.original:
Indeed? Ay, indeed! Discern'st thou aught in that?
Is he not honest?
paragraphs.translated: Oh, really? Yes, really. Do you see something wrong with that? Isn't he an honest man?

paragraphs.original: Honest, my lord?
paragraphs.translated: Honest, my lord?

paragraphs.original: Honest, ay, honest.
paragraphs.translated: Honest, yes, honest.

paragraphs.original: My lord, for aught I know.
paragraphs.translated: As far as I know, sir.

paragraphs.original: What dost thou think?
paragraphs.translated: What are you thinking?

paragraphs.original: Think, my lord?
paragraphs.translated: Thinking, my lord?

paragraphs.original:
"Think, my lord?" Alas, thou echo'st me
As if there were some monster in thy thought
Too hideous to be shown. Thou dost mean something.
I heard thee say even now thou lik'st not that
When Cassio left my wife. What didst not like?
And when I told thee he was of my counsel
Of my whole course of wooing, thou cried'st "Indeed?"
And didst contract and purse thy brow together
As if thou then hadst shut up in thy brain
Some horrible conceit. If thou dost love me
Show me thy thought.
paragraphs.translated: "Thinking, my lord?" My God, you keep repeating everything I say as if you were thinking something too horrible to say out loud. You're thinking something. Just a minute ago I heard you say you didn't like it when Cassio left my wife. What didn't you like? And when I told you he was involved the whole time I was trying to get Desdemona, you were like, "Oh, really?" And then you frowned and wrinkled up your forehead as if you were imagining something horrible. If you're my friend, tell me what you're thinking.

paragraphs.original: My lord, you know I love you.
paragraphs.translated: My lord, you know I'm your friend.

paragraphs.original:
I think thou dost.
And for I know thou 'rt full of love and honesty
And weigh'st thy words before thou giv'st them breath,
Therefore these stops of thine fright me the more.
For such things in a false disloyal knave
Are tricks of custom, but in a man that's just
They are close dilations, working from the heart,
That passion cannot rule.
paragraphs.translated: I think you are. And I know you're full of love and honesty, and you think carefully before you speak. That's why these pauses of yours frighten me. If some fool were withholding things from me, I wouldn't think twice about it. If some lying, cheating villain acted like that, it would just be a trick. But when an honest man acts like that, you know he's wrestling with bad thoughts and can't help it.

paragraphs.original:
For Michael Cassio,
I dare be sworn, I think, that he is honest.
paragraphs.translated: As for Michael Cassio, I think it would be safe for me to swear that he's honest.

paragraphs.original: I think so too.
paragraphs.translated: I think so too.

paragraphs.original:
Men should be what they seem,
Or those that be not, would they might seem none!
paragraphs.translated: People should be what they appear to be. If they're not honest, they shouldn't look like they are!

paragraphs.original: Certain, men should be what they seem.
paragraphs.translated: Absolutely, people should be what they appear to be.

paragraphs.original: Why then I think Cassio's an honest man.
paragraphs.translated: In that case, I think Cassio's an honest man.

paragraphs.original:
Nay, yet there's more in this.
I prithee speak to me as to thy thinkings,
As thou dost ruminate, and give thy worst of thoughts
The worst of words.
paragraphs.translated: No, I think there's more to this than you're letting on. Please tell me what you're thinking - even your worst suspicions.

paragraphs.original:
Good my lord, pardon me,
Though I am bound to every act of duty
I am not bound to that all slaves are free to.
Utter my thoughts? Why, say they are vile and false,
As where's that palace whereinto foul things
Sometimes intrude not? Who has that breast so pure
Wherein uncleanly apprehensions
Keep leets and law-days and in sessions sit
With meditations lawful?
paragraphs.translated: Please don't make me do that, sir. I have to obey all your orders, but surely I'm not obligated to reveal my deepest thoughts - even slaves aren't expected to do that. You want me to say what I'm thinking? What if my thoughts are disgusting and wrong? Even good people think horrible things sometimes. Who is so pure that they never think a bad thought?

paragraphs.original:
Thou dost conspire against thy friend, Iago,
If thou but think'st him wronged and mak'st his ear
A stranger to thy thoughts.
paragraphs.translated:
You're not being a good friend, Iago, if you even think your friend has been wronged and you don't tell him about it.
think

paragraphs.original:
I do beseech you,
Though I perchance am vicious in my guess,
As, I confess, it is my nature's plague
To spy into abuses, and oft my jealousy
Shapes faults that are not, that your wisdom,
From one that so imperfectly conceits,
Would take no notice, nor build yourself a trouble
Out of his scattering and unsure observance.
It were not for your quiet nor your good,
paragraphs.translated: Please don't ask me to tell you. I might be completely wrong. I have a bad tendency to be suspicious of people and to look too closely into what they're doing. Often I imagine crimes that aren't really there. You would be wise to ignore my weak guesses and imaginary suspicions, and don't worry yourself about the meaningless things I've noticed. For me to tell you my thoughts would only destroy your peace of mind, and

paragraphs.original:
Nor for my manhood, honesty, and wisdom
To let you know my thoughts.
paragraphs.translated: it wouldn't be wise, honest, or responsible for me to tell them.

paragraphs.original: What dost thou mean?
paragraphs.translated: What are you talking about?

paragraphs.original:
Good name in man and woman, dear my lord,
Is the immediate jewel of their souls.
Who steals my purse steals trash. 'Tis something, nothing:
'Twas mine, 'tis his, and has been slave to thousands.
But he that filches from me my good name
Robs me of that which not enriches him
And makes me poor indeed.
paragraphs.translated: A good reputation is the most valuable thing we have - men and women alike. If you steal my money, you're just stealing trash.
