It's something, it's nothing: it's yours, it's mine, and it'll belong to thousands more. But if you steal my reputation, you're robbing me of something that doesn't make you richer, but makes me much poorer.

paragraphs.original: I'll know thy thoughts.
paragraphs.translated: I'm going to find out what you're thinking.

paragraphs.original:
You cannot, if my heart were in your hand,
Nor shall not, whilst 'tis in my custody.
paragraphs.translated: You can't find that out, even if you held my heart in your hand you couldn't make me tell you. And as long my heart's inside my body, you never will.

paragraphs.original: Ha!
paragraphs.translated: What?

paragraphs.original:
Oh, beware, my lord, of jealousy!
It is the green-eyed monster which doth mock
The meat it feeds on. That cuckold lives in bliss
Who, certain of his fate, loves not his wronger,
But, oh, what damnèd minutes tells he o'er
Who dotes, yet doubts -  suspects, yet soundly loves!
paragraphs.translated: Beware of jealousy, my lord! It's a green-eyed monster that makes fun of the victims it devours. The man who knows his wife is cheating on him is happy, because at least he isn't friends with the man she's sleeping with. But think of the unhappiness of a man who worships his wife, yet doubts her faithfulness. He suspects her, but still loves her.

paragraphs.original: Oh, misery!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, what misery!

paragraphs.original:
Poor and content is rich, and rich enough,
But riches fineless is as poor as winter
To him that ever fears he shall be poor.
Good heaven, the souls of all my tribe defend
From jealousy!
paragraphs.translated: The person who's poor and contented is rich enough. But infinite riches are nothing to someone who's always afraid he'll be poor. God, help us not be jealous!

paragraphs.original:
Why, why is this?
Think'st thou I'd make a life of jealousy,
To follow still the changes of the moon
With fresh suspicions? No! To be once in doubt
Is to be resolved. Exchange me for a goat
When I shall turn the business of my soul
To such exsufflicate and blowed surmises,
Matching thy inference. 'Tis not to make me jealous
To say my wife is fair, feeds well, loves company,
Is free of speech, sings, plays, and dances.
Where virtue is, these are more virtuous.
Nor from mine own weak merits will I draw
The smallest fear or doubt of her revolt,
For she had eyes and chose me. No, Iago,
I'll see before I doubt, when I doubt, prove,
And on the proof there is no more but this:
Away at once with love or jealousy!
paragraphs.translated: Why are you telling me this? Do you think I would live a life of jealousy, tormented by new suspicions every hour? No. If there's any doubt, there is no doubt. I might as well be a goat if I ever let myself become obsessed with the kind of suspicions you're implying. If you say my wife is beautiful, eats well, loves good company, speaks freely, sings, plays music, and dances well, you're not making me jealous. When a woman is virtuous, talents like these just make her better. And I'm not going to start feeling inferior. She had her eyes wide open when she chose me. No, Iago, I'll have to see some real evidence before I start suspecting her of anything bad, and when I suspect her, I'll look for proof, and if there's proof, that's when I'll let go of my love and my jealousy.

paragraphs.original:
I am glad of this, for now I shall have reason
To show the love and duty that I bear you
With franker spirit. Therefore, as I am bound,
Receive it from me. I speak not yet of proof.
Look to your wife, observe her well with Cassio.
Wear your eyes thus, not jealous nor secure.
I would not have your free and noble nature
Out of self-bounty be abused. Look to 't.
I know our country disposition well.
In Venice they do let God see the pranks
They dare not show their husbands. Their best conscience
Is not to leave 't undone, but keep't unknown.
paragraphs.translated: I'm glad to hear you say that. Now I can show you my devotion and my duty with more honesty. So please listen to me. I'm not talking about proof yet. Watch your wife. Watch how she is with Cassio. Just watch - don't be either completely suspicious or completely trustful. I wouldn't want to see you taken advantage of because you're such an open and trusting guy. Watch out! I know the people of Venice well. They let God see things they wouldn't show their husbands. They don't avoid doing things that are wrong, they just try not to get caught.

paragraphs.original: Dost thou say so?
paragraphs.translated: Do you really think so?

paragraphs.original:
She did deceive her father, marrying you,
And when she seemed to shake and fear your looks,
She loved them most.
paragraphs.translated: She lied to her father to marry you. And when she pretended to be afraid of you, she loved you the most.

paragraphs.original: And so she did.
paragraphs.translated: That's right, she did.

paragraphs.original:
Why, go to then.
She that, so young, could give out such a seeming,
To seel her father's eyes up close as oak,
He thought 'twas witchcraft. But I am much to blame.
I humbly do beseech you of your pardon
For too much loving you.
paragraphs.translated: Well, there you go. She was so young, but she deceived her father so thoroughly he thought it was witchcraft! But I'm sorry I've blurted all this out. I beg your pardon for loving you too much.

paragraphs.original: I am bound to thee forever.
paragraphs.translated: I'm indebted to you forever.

paragraphs.original: I see this hath a little dashed your spirits.
paragraphs.translated: You seem a little depressed about this.

paragraphs.original: Not a jot, not a jot.
paragraphs.translated: Not at all, not at all.

paragraphs.original:
Trust me, I fear it has.
I hope you will consider what is spoke
Comes from my love. But I do see you're moved.
I am to pray you not to strain my speech
To grosser issues nor to larger reach
Than to suspicion.
paragraphs.translated: Really, I'm afraid you are. I hope you remember that I said all this because I love you. But I see you're troubled. Please don't take what I said more seriously than it deserves to be taken.

paragraphs.original: I will not.
paragraphs.translated: I won't.

paragraphs.original:
Should you do so, my lord,
My speech should fall into such vile success
Which my thoughts aimed not at. Cassio's my worthy friend - 
My lord, I see you're moved.
paragraphs.translated: If you take it too seriously, it'll have bad effects that I didn't want it to have. Cassio's a good friend of mine - My lord, I can see you're upset.

paragraphs.original:
No, not much moved.
I do not think but Desdemona's honest.
paragraphs.translated: No, not too upset. I'm sure Desdemona would never cheat on me.

paragraphs.original: Long live she so. And long live you to think so.
paragraphs.translated: I hope she never does! And I hope you keep on thinking she wouldn't.

paragraphs.original: And yet how nature, erring from itself -
paragraphs.translated: But still, it's true that good things can go bad, away from their true natures -

paragraphs.original:
Ay, there's the point. As, to be bold with you,
Not to affect many proposèd matches
Of her own clime, complexion, and degree,
Whereto we see in all things nature tends - 
Foh! One may smell in such a will most rank,
Foul disproportions, thoughts unnatural.
But - pardon me - I do not in position
Distinctly speak of her, though I may fear
Her will, recoiling to her better judgment,
May fall to match you with her country forms,
And happily repent.
paragraphs.translated: That's the point I'm trying to make. If I can be frank with you, she veered away from her own nature in turning down all those young men from her own country, with her skin color, with her status - everything her nature would have drawn her to - Ugh! You can almost smell the dark and ugly desires inside her, the unnatural thoughts - But - I'm sorry - I didn't mean to refer to her specifically just now. I only worry that she might snap back to her natural taste in men one day, and compare you unfavorably to other Italians.

paragraphs.original:
Farewell, farewell.
If more thou dost perceive, let me know more.
Set on thy wife to observe. Leave me, Iago.
paragraphs.translated: Goodbye, goodbye. If you see anything else, let me know. Tell your wife to watch her. Leave me alone now, Iago.

paragraphs.original:
My lord, I take my leave. (going)
(going)
paragraphs.translated:
My lord, I'll say goodbye now. (beginning to exit)
(beginning to exit)

paragraphs.original:
(aside) Why did I marry? This honest creature doubtless
(aside)
Sees and knows more, much more, than he unfolds.
paragraphs.translated:
(to himself) Why did I ever get married? I'm sure this good and honest man sees and knows more, much more, than he's telling me.
(to himself)

paragraphs.original:
(returns) My lord, I would I might entreat your honor
(returns)
To scan this thing no farther. Leave it to time.
Although 'tis fit that Cassio have his place,
For sure, he fills it up with great ability,
Yet, if you please to hold him off awhile,
You shall by that perceive him and his means.
Note if your lady strain his entertainment
paragraphs.translated:
(returning) My lord, please don't think about this any more. Time will tell. It's right for Cassio to have his lieutenancy back - he's very talented. But keep him away for a while, and you'll see how he goes about getting it back. Notice whether your wife insists on your
(returning)

paragraphs.original:
With any strong or vehement importunity.
Much will be seen in that. In the meantime,
Let me be thought too busy in my fears - 
As worthy cause I have to fear I am - 
And hold her free, I do beseech your honor.
paragraphs.translated: giving it back to him. That will tell you a lot. But in the meantime, just assume that I'm paranoid - as I'm pretty sure I am - and keep thinking she's innocent, please.

paragraphs.original: Fear not my government.
paragraphs.translated: Don't worry about how I handle it.

paragraphs.original: I once more take my leave.
paragraphs.translated: I'll say goodbye once more.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: IAGO exits.

paragraphs.original:
This fellow's of exceeding honesty
And knows all quantities, with a learnèd spirit,
Of human dealings. If I do prove her haggard,
Though that her jesses were my dear heartstrings,
I'd whistle her off and let her down the wind
To prey at fortune. Haply, for I am black
And have not those soft parts of conversation
That chamberers have, or for I am declined
Into the vale of years - yet that's not much - 
She's gone, I am abused, and my relief
Must be to loathe her. Oh, curse of marriage
That we can call these delicate creatures ours
And not their appetites! I had rather be a toad
And live upon the vapor of a dungeon
Than keep a corner in the thing I love
For others' uses. Yet 'tis the plague to great ones,
Prerogatived are they less than the base.
'Tis destiny unshunnable, like death.
Even then this forkèd plague is fated to us
When we do quicken. Look where she comes.
paragraphs.translated: This Iago is extremely honest and good, and he knows a lot about human behavior. If it turns out that she really is running around on me, I'll send her away, even though it'll break my heart. Maybe because I'm black, and I don't have nice manners like courtiers do, or because I'm getting old - but that's not much - She's gone, and I've been cheated on. I have no choice but to hate her. Oh what a curse marriage is! We think our beautiful wives belong to us, but their desires are free! I'd rather be a toad in a moldy basement than to have only a part of someone I love, sharing the rest of her with others. This is the plague of important men - our wives betray us more than those of poor men. It's our destiny, like death. We are destined to be betrayed when we are born. Oh, here she comes.

paragraphs.original: Enter DESDEMONA and EMILIA
paragraphs.translated: DESDEMONA and EMILIA enter.

paragraphs.original:
If she be false, heaven mocked itself.
I'll not believe 't.
paragraphs.translated: If she's cheated on me, then heaven itself is a fake. I don't believe it.

paragraphs.original:
How now, my dear Othello?
Your dinner, and the generous islanders
By you invited, do attend your presence.
paragraphs.translated: What's going on, Othello, darling? The nobles of Cyprus whom you invited to dinner are waiting for you.

paragraphs.original: I am to blame.
paragraphs.translated: I'm sorry.

paragraphs.original:
Why do you speak so faintly?
Are you not well?
paragraphs.translated: Why are you whispering? Are you sick?

paragraphs.original: I have a pain upon my forehead, here.
paragraphs.translated:
I have a
headache, right here in my forehead.
headache

paragraphs.original:
Why that's with watching, 'twill away again.
Let me but bind it hard, within this hour
It will be well. (pulls out a handkerchief)
(pulls out a handkerchief)
paragraphs.translated:
That's from lack of sleep. It'll go away. Let me wrap up your head, and it will feel okay in less than an hour. (she pulls out a handkerchief)
(she pulls out a handkerchief)

paragraphs.original:
Your napkin is too little,
Let it alone.
paragraphs.translated: No, your handkerchief's too little. Leave my head alone.

paragraphs.original: Her handkerchief drops
paragraphs.translated: The handkerchief falls to the floor.

paragraphs.original: Come, I'll go in with you.
paragraphs.translated: Come on, I'll escort you to dinner.

paragraphs.original: I am very sorry that you are not well.
paragraphs.translated: I'm very sorry you're not feeling well.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt OTHELLO and DESDEMONA
paragraphs.translated: OTHELLO and DESDEMONA exit.

paragraphs.original:
(picks up the handkercheif)
(picks up the handkercheif)
I am glad I have found this napkin,
This was her first remembrance from the Moor.
My wayward husband hath a hundred times
paragraphs.translated:
(picking up the handkerchief) I'm glad I found this handkerchief. It's the first keepsake the Moor gave her. My stubborn husband has asked me to steal it a
(picking up the handkerchief)

paragraphs.original:
Wooed me to steal it, but she so loves the token
(For he conjured her she should ever keep it)
That she reserves it evermore about her
To kiss and talk to. I'll have the work ta'en out
And give 't Iago. What he will do with it
Heaven knows, not I.
I nothing but to please his fantasy.
paragraphs.translated: hundred times. But she loves it so much (since Othello told her she should always keep it with her) that she always keeps it near her to kiss it and talk to it. I'll copy the embroidery pattern and then give it to Iago. Heaven knows what he's going to do with it. I only try to satisfy his whims.

paragraphs.original: Enter IAGO
paragraphs.translated: IAGO enters.

paragraphs.original: How now! What do you here alone?
paragraphs.translated: What's going on? What are you doing here alone?

paragraphs.original: Do not you chide. I have a thing for you.
paragraphs.translated: Don't snap at me. I've got something for you.

paragraphs.original: A thing for me? It is a common thing -
paragraphs.translated:
You've got something for me? It's a common
thing - 
thing

paragraphs.original: Ha?
paragraphs.translated: What?

paragraphs.original: To have a foolish wife.
paragraphs.translated: - to have a stupid wife.

paragraphs.original:
Oh, is that all? What will you give me now
For the same handkerchief?
paragraphs.translated: Oh, is that so? And what would you give me for the handkerchief?

paragraphs.original: What handkerchief?
paragraphs.translated: What handkerchief?

paragraphs.original:
What handkerchief?
Why, that the Moor first gave to Desdemona,
That which so often you did bid me steal.
paragraphs.translated: What handkerchief? The one the Moor gave to Desdemona, which you asked me to steal so many times.

paragraphs.original: Hast stolen it from her?
paragraphs.translated: You stole it from her?

paragraphs.original:
No, but she let it drop by negligence
And, to th' advantage, I being here, took 't up.
Look, here it is.
paragraphs.translated: No, actually. She dropped it carelessly, and, seizing the opportunity, since I was here, I picked it up. Look, here it is.

paragraphs.original: A good wench, give it me.
paragraphs.translated: Good girl, give it to me.

paragraphs.original:
What will you do with 't, that you have been so earnest
To have me filch it?
paragraphs.translated: And what are you going to do with it? Why did you want it so much that you begged me to steal it?

paragraphs.original: Why, what is that to you?
paragraphs.translated: What's it to you?

paragraphs.original:
If it be not for some purpose of import,
Give 't me again. Poor lady, she'll run mad
When she shall lack it.
paragraphs.translated: If you don't need it for some important reason, then give it back to me. Poor lady, she'll go crazy when she sees it's missing.

paragraphs.original:
Be not acknown on 't,
I have use for it. Go, leave me.
paragraphs.translated: Don't admit to knowing anything about it. I need it. Now go, leave me.

paragraphs.original: Exit EMILIA
paragraphs.translated: EMILIA exits.

paragraphs.original:
I will in Cassio's lodging lose this napkin
And let him find it. Trifles light as air
Are to the jealous confirmations strong
As proofs of holy writ. This may do something.
The Moor already changes with my poison.
Dangerous conceits are in their natures poisons
Which at the first are scarce found to distaste,
But with a little act upon the blood
Burn like the mines of sulfur.
paragraphs.translated: I'll leave this handkerchief at Cassio's house and let him find it.To a jealous man, a meaningless little thing like this looks like absolute proof. This handkerchief may be useful to me. The Moor's mind has already become infected with my poisonous suggestions. Ideas can be like poisons. At first they hardly even taste bad, but once they get into your blood they start burning like hot lava.

paragraphs.original: Enter OTHELLO
paragraphs.translated: OTHELLO enters.

paragraphs.original:
I did say so.
Look, where he comes. Not poppy nor mandragora
Nor all the drowsy syrups of the world,
Shall ever medicine thee to that sweet sleep
Which thou owedst yesterday.
paragraphs.translated: Here he comes. No drugs or sleeping pills will ever give you the restful sleep that you had last night.

paragraphs.original: Ha! Ha! False to me?
paragraphs.translated: Argh! She's cheating on me?

paragraphs.original: Why, how now, general? No more of that.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, general, please, no more of that!

paragraphs.original:
Avaunt! Be gone! Thou hast set me on the rack.
I swear 'tis better to be much abused
Than but to know 't a little.
paragraphs.translated: Get lost! You've tortured me with these thoughts. It is better to be tricked completely than to only suspect a little.

paragraphs.original: How now, my lord!
paragraphs.translated: What's with you, my lord?

paragraphs.original:
What sense had I in her stol'n hours of lust?
I saw 't not, thought it not, it harmed not me.
I slept the next night well, fed well, was free and merry.
I found not Cassio's kisses on her lips.
He that is robbed, not wanting what is stol'n,
Let him not know't, and he's not robbed at all.
paragraphs.translated: I had no idea she was cheating on me. I never saw it or suspected it, so it never hurt me. I slept well, ate well, and was happy. I never saw Cassio's kisses on her lips. A man who's robbed, but doesn't miss what's stolen, isn't robbed at all.

paragraphs.original: I am sorry to hear this.
paragraphs.translated: I'm sorry to hear this.

paragraphs.original:
I had been happy if the general camp,
Pioneers and all, had tasted her sweet body,
So I had nothing known. Oh, now forever
Farewell the tranquil mind! Farewell content!
Farewell the plumèd troops and the big wars
That makes ambition virtue! Oh, farewell!
Farewell the neighing steed and the shrill trump,
The spirit-stirring drum, th' ear-piercing fife,
The royal banner, and all quality,
Pride, pomp, and circumstance of glorious war!
And O you mortal engines, whose rude throats
The immortal Jove's dead clamors counterfeit,
Farewell! Othello's occupation's gone.
paragraphs.translated: I would've been happy if the whole army had had sex with her, the lowest-ranking grunts and all, as long as I didn't know anything about it. Oh, goodbye to my peace of mind! Goodbye to my happiness! Goodbye to the soldiers and to the wars that make men great! Goodbye! Goodbye to the horses and the trumpets and the drums, the flute and the splendid banners, and all those proud displays and pageantry of war! And you deadly cannons that roar like thunderbolts thrown by the gods, goodbye! Othello's career is over.

paragraphs.original: Is 't possible, my lord?
paragraphs.translated: Is this possible, my lord?

paragraphs.original:
Villain, be sure thou prove my love a whore,
Be sure of it. Give me the ocular proof
Or by the worth of mine eternal soul
Thou hadst been better have been born a dog
Than answer my waked wrath!
paragraphs.translated: You villain, you'd better be able to prove my wife's a whore! Be sure of it. Get me proof I can see. If you can't, trust me, you won't want to feel my rage!

paragraphs.original: Is 't come to this?
paragraphs.translated: Has it come to this?

paragraphs.original:
Make me to see 't, or at the least so prove it
That the probation bear no hinge nor loop
To hang a doubt on, or woe upon thy life!
paragraphs.translated: Show me, or at least prove it beyond the shadow of a doubt. If you can't, your life is worthless!

paragraphs.original: My noble lord -
paragraphs.translated: My noble lord -

paragraphs.original:
If thou dost slander her and torture me,
Never pray more. Abandon all remorse.
On horror's head horrors accumulate,
Do deeds to make heaven weep, all earth amazed,
For nothing canst thou to damnation add
Greater than that.
paragraphs.translated: If you're slandering her just to torture me, then it'll be no use to pray for mercy or say you're sorry. You might as well go ahead and commit every unspeakable crime you can think of, because there's nothing you could that would top what you've already done!

paragraphs.original:
Oh, grace! Oh, heaven forgive me!
Are you a man? Have you a soul or sense?
God buy you, take mine office. O wretched fool
That lov'st to make thine honesty a vice!
O monstrous world! Take note, take note, O world,
To be direct and honest is not safe.
I thank you for this profit, and from hence
I'll love no friend, sith love breeds such offence.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, heaven help me! Aren't you a rational human being? Don't you have any sense at all? Goodbye. I resign my official position. I'm such an idiot for always telling the truth! What a horrible world we live in! Listen, pay attention, everybody. It's not safe to be straightforward and honest. I'm glad you've taught me this valuable lesson. From now on, I'll never try to help a friend when it hurts him so much to hear the truth.

paragraphs.original: Nay, stay. Thou shouldst be honest.
paragraphs.translated: No, stop. You should always be honest.

paragraphs.original:
I should be wise, for honesty's a fool
And loses that it works for.
paragraphs.translated: I should always be wise. Honesty's stupid, it makes me lose my friends even when I'm trying to help them.

paragraphs.original:
By the world,
I think my wife be honest and think she is not.
I think that thou art just and think thou art not.
I'll have some proof. Her name, that was as fresh
As Dian's visage, is now begrimed and black
As mine own face. If there be cords or knives,
Poison, or fire, or suffocating streams,
I'll not endure it. Would I were satisfied!
paragraphs.translated:
I swear, I think my wife's faithful, and I think she's not. I think you're trustworthy one minute and then not the next. I need proof! Her reputation was as pure as the snow, but now it's as dirty and black as my own face. As long as there are
ropes, knives, poison, fire, or streams to drown in , I won't stand for this. Oh, how I wish I knew the truth!
ropes, knives, poison, fire, or streams to drown in

paragraphs.original:
I see, sir, you are eaten up with passion.
I do repent me that I put it to you.
You would be satisfied?
paragraphs.translated: I see you're all eaten up with emotion. I'm sorry I said anything. You want proof?

paragraphs.original: Would? Nay, and I will.
paragraphs.translated: Want? Yes, I want it, and I'll get it.

paragraphs.original:
And may, but how? How satisfied, my lord?
Would you, the supervisor, grossly gape on,
Behold her topped?
paragraphs.translated: But how? How will you get proof? Are you going to hide and watch them having sex?

paragraphs.original: Death and damnation! Oh!
paragraphs.translated: Death and damnation! Oh!

paragraphs.original:
It were a tedious difficulty, I think,
To bring them to that prospect. Damn them then,
If ever mortal eyes do see them bolster
More than their own! What then? How then?
What shall I say? Where's satisfaction?
It is impossible you should see this,
Were they as prime as goats, as hot as monkeys,
As salt as wolves in pride, and fools as gross
As ignorance made drunk. But yet, I say,
If imputation and strong circumstances
Which lead directly to the door of truth
Will give you satisfaction, you may have 't.
paragraphs.translated: I think it would be very hard to arrange for them to have sex while you watched. If anyone sees them in bed together besides themselves, I guess we could damn them then. So what can we do? What can I say? What proof is there? It'd be impossible for you to watch them, even if they were as horny as animals in heat and as stupid as drunks. But if you would be willing to accept circumstantial evidence as proof, we can get that.

paragraphs.original: Give me a living reason she's disloyal.
paragraphs.translated: Give me one good reason to think she's cheating on me.

paragraphs.original:
I do not like the office.
But, sith I am entered in this cause so far,
Pricked to 't by foolish honesty and love,
I will go on. I lay with Cassio lately
And, being troubled with a raging tooth,
I could not sleep. There are a kind of men
So loose of soul that in their sleeps will mutter
paragraphs.translated: I don't like what you're asking me to do. But since I've gotten myself involved this far, because I'm so stupidly honest and because I like you so much, I'll keep going. I recently shared a bed with Cassio, and I couldn't sleep because of a raging toothache. Well, some people talk in their sleep, and Cassio is one of them. I heard him saying, "Sweet Desdemona, let's be careful and hide our love," in his sleep. And then he grabbed my hand and said, "Oh, my darling!" and

paragraphs.original:
Their affairs. One of this kind is Cassio.
In sleep I heard him say "Sweet Desdemona,
Let us be wary, let us hide our loves."
And then, sir, would he gripe and wring my hand,
Cry "O sweet creature!" and then kiss me hard,
As if he plucked up kisses by the roots
That grew upon my lips, lay his leg
Over my thigh, and sigh, and kiss, and then
Cry "Cursed fate that gave thee to the Moor!"
paragraphs.translated: kissed me hard, as if he were trying to suck my lips off. Then he put his leg over mine, and sighed and kissed me, and said, "Damn fate for giving you to the Moor!"

paragraphs.original: Oh, monstrous! Monstrous!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, that's monstrous! Monstrous!

paragraphs.original: Nay, this was but his dream.
paragraphs.translated: No, it was just a dream.

paragraphs.original: But this denoted a foregone conclusion.
paragraphs.translated: But it shows that something has already happened.

paragraphs.original:
'Tis a shrewd doubt, though it be but a dream.
And this may help to thicken other proofs
That do demonstrate thinly.
paragraphs.translated: It's a reason for suspicion, even though it's just a dream. And it might back up other evidence that may seem too flimsy.

paragraphs.original: I'll tear her all to pieces!
paragraphs.translated: I'll tear her to pieces!

paragraphs.original:
Nay, yet be wise, yet we see nothing done,
She may be honest yet. Tell me but this,
Have you not sometimes seen a handkerchief
Spotted with strawberries in your wife's hand?
paragraphs.translated: No, be reasonable. We don't have any proof yet. She might still be faithful. Just tell me this: have you ever seen her holding a handkerchief with an embroidered strawberry pattern on it?

paragraphs.original: I gave her such a one, 'twas my first gift.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, I gave her one like that. It was my first gift to her.

paragraphs.original:
I know not that, but such a handkerchief - 
I am sure it was your wife's - did I today
See Cassio wipe his beard with.
paragraphs.translated: I don't know about that, but I saw a handkerchief like that today. I'm sure it belongs to your wife, and I saw Cassio use it to wipe his beard.

paragraphs.original: If it be that -
paragraphs.translated: If it's the same one -

paragraphs.original:
If it be that, or any that was hers,
It speaks against her with the other proofs.
paragraphs.translated: If it's the same one, or any one that belongs to her, then together with the other evidence it's pretty strong.

paragraphs.original:
Oh, that the slave had forty thousand lives!
One is too poor, too weak for my revenge.
Now do I see 'tis true. Look here, Iago,
All my fond love thus do I blow to heaven.
'Tis gone.
Arise, black vengeance, from the hollow hell!
Yield up, O love, thy crown and hearted throne
To tyrannous hate! Swell, bosom, with thy fraught,
For 'tis of aspics' tongues!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, I'd kill that bastard Cassio forty thousand times if I could! Killing him once is not enough revenge. Now I see it's true. Oh, Iago, all the love I felt is gone, vanished in the wind. Welcome, hatred and vengeance! Get out of my heart, love! My heart feels like it's full of poisonous snakes!

paragraphs.original: Yet be content.
paragraphs.translated: Calm down -

paragraphs.original: Oh, blood, blood, blood!
paragraphs.translated: I want blood!

paragraphs.original: Patience, I say. Your mind may change.
paragraphs.translated: Be patient, I'm telling you. You may change your mind later.

paragraphs.original:
Never, Iago. Like to the Pontic sea,
Whose icy current and compulsive course
Ne'er keeps retiring ebb but keeps due on
To the Propontic and the Hellespont,
Even so my bloody thoughts with violent pace
Shall ne'er look back, ne'er ebb to humble love
Till that a capable and wide revenge
Swallow them up. Now, by yon marble heaven,
In the due reverence of a sacred vow
I here engage my words. (he kneels)
(he kneels)
paragraphs.translated:
Never, Iago. My thoughts of revenge are flowing through me like a violent river, never turning back to love, only flowing toward full revenge that'll swallow them up. I swear to God I'll get revenge. (he kneels)
(he kneels)

paragraphs.original:
Do not rise yet.
Witness, you ever-burning lights above,
You elements that clip us round about,
Witness that here Iago doth give up
The execution of his wit, hands, heart,
To wronged Othello's service. Let him command,
And to obey shall be in me remorse,
What bloody business ever.
paragraphs.translated: Don't get up yet. Let heaven be my witness - I'm putting my mind, my heart, and my hands in Othello's control. Let him command me, and I'll do whatever he asks, no matter how violent.

paragraphs.original:
I greet thy love
Not with vain thanks but with acceptance bounteous,
And will upon the instant put thee to 't.
Within these three days let me hear thee say
That Cassio's not alive.
paragraphs.translated: I accept your devotion with my deepest love. I'll put you to the test right away. Within the next three days I want to hear you tell me that Cassio's dead.

paragraphs.original:
My friend is dead,
'Tis done at your request. But let her live.
paragraphs.translated: My friend Cassio is dead. It's done, because you request it. But let her live.

paragraphs.original:
Damn her, lewd minx! Oh, damn her, damn her!
Come, go with me apart. I will withdraw
To furnish me with some swift means of death
For the fair devil. Now art thou my lieutenant.
paragraphs.translated: Damn her, the wicked whore! Oh, damn her, damn her! Come away with me. I'm going inside to think up some way to kill that beautiful devil. You're my lieutenant now.

paragraphs.original: I am your own for ever.
paragraphs.translated: I'm yours forever.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter DESDEMONA, EMILIA, and CLOWN
paragraphs.translated: DESDEMONA, EMILIA and the CLOWN enter.

paragraphs.original: Do you know, sirrah, where Lieutenant Cassio lies?
paragraphs.translated:
Excuse me, do you know which room Lieutenant Cassio
lies in?
lies in

paragraphs.original: I dare not say he lies anywhere.
paragraphs.translated: I wouldn't dare say he lies anywhere.

paragraphs.original: Why, man?
paragraphs.translated: Why do you say that?

paragraphs.original: He's a soldier, and for one to say a soldier lies, 'tis stabbing.
paragraphs.translated: He's a soldier. If I accused a soldier of lying, he'd stab me.

paragraphs.original: Go to. Where lodges he?
paragraphs.translated: Oh, come on. Where does he sleep?

paragraphs.original: To tell you where he lodges is to tell you where I lie.
paragraphs.translated: Telling you where he's sleeping is like telling you where I'm lying.

paragraphs.original: Can anything be made of this?
paragraphs.translated: What on earth does that mean?

paragraphs.original: I know not where he lodges, and for me to devise a lodging and say he lies here, or he lies there, were to lie in mine own throat.
paragraphs.translated: I don't know where he's staying, so if I told you he's sleeping here or there, I'd be lying.

paragraphs.original: Can you inquire him out and be edified by report?
paragraphs.translated: Can you ask around and find out?

paragraphs.original: I will catechize the world for him, that is, make questions, and by them answer.
paragraphs.translated: I'll go ask questions everywhere.

paragraphs.original: Seek him, bid him come hither. Tell him I have moved my lord on his behalf, and hope all will be well.
paragraphs.translated: Find him and tell him to come here. Tell him I've spoken to my husband on his behalf, and I think everything will be all right.

paragraphs.original: To do this is within the compass of man's wit, and therefore I will attempt the doing it.
paragraphs.translated: I think I can do that. It's not too much to ask.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: CLOWN exits.

paragraphs.original: Where should I lose that handkerchief, Emilia?
paragraphs.translated: Where could I have lost that handkerchief, Emilia?

paragraphs.original: I know not, madam.
paragraphs.translated: I don't know, madam.

paragraphs.original:
Believe me, I had rather have lost my purse
Full of crusadoes. And but my noble Moor
Is true of mind and made of no such baseness
As jealous creatures are, it were enough
To put him to ill thinking.
paragraphs.translated: Believe me, I'd rather have lost a purse full of gold coins. This would be enough to make my husband suspect me, if he wasn't so free of jealousy.

paragraphs.original: Is he not jealous?
paragraphs.translated: He's not jealous?

paragraphs.original:
Who, he? I think the sun where he was born
Drew all such humors from him.
paragraphs.translated: Who, him? I think all tendencies to jealousy were burned out of him by the sun of his native land.

paragraphs.original: Look where he comes.
paragraphs.translated: Look, here he comes.

paragraphs.original: Enter OTHELLO
paragraphs.translated: OTHELLO enters.

paragraphs.original:
I will not leave him now till Cassio
Be called to him. - How is 't with you, my lord?
paragraphs.translated: I won't leave him alone until he gives Cassio his job back. - How are you, my lord?

paragraphs.original:
Well, my good lady. - (aside) Oh, hardness to dissemble! - 
(aside)
How do you, Desdemona?
paragraphs.translated:
I'm fine, my lady. - (to himself) Oh, it's so hard to pretend! - How are you, Desdemona?
(to himself)

paragraphs.original: Well, my good lord.
paragraphs.translated: I'm fine, my lord.

paragraphs.original: Give me your hand. This hand is moist, my lady.
paragraphs.translated:
Give me your
hand. Your hand's moist, my lady.
hand

paragraphs.original: It hath felt no age nor known no sorrow.
paragraphs.translated: It's moist because it's still young and inexperienced.

paragraphs.original:
This argues fruitfulness and liberal heart.
Hot, hot, and moist. This hand of yours requires
A sequester from liberty, fasting, and prayer,
paragraphs.translated: It says you're fertile, and you've got a giving heart. Hot, hot and moist. With a hand like this you need to

paragraphs.original:
Much castigation, exercise devout,
For here's a young and sweating devil here,
That commonly rebels. 'Tis a good hand,
A frank one.
paragraphs.translated: fast and pray to stave off temptations. Someone with a young sweating hand like this one is bound to act up sooner or later. It's a nice hand, an open one.

paragraphs.original:
You may indeed say so,
For 'twas that hand that gave away my heart.
paragraphs.translated: You're right to say that. This was the hand that gave you my heart.

paragraphs.original:
A liberal hand. The hearts of old gave hands,
But our new heraldry is hands, not hearts.
paragraphs.translated: This hand gives itself away very freely. In the old days, people used to give their hearts to each other when they joined their hands in marriage. But these days, people give each other their hands without their hearts.

paragraphs.original: I cannot speak of this. Come now, your promise.
paragraphs.translated: I don't know about that. Now, don't forget, you promised me something.

paragraphs.original: What promise, chuck?
paragraphs.translated: What did I promise, my dear?

paragraphs.original: I have sent to bid Cassio come speak with you.
paragraphs.translated: I sent for Cassio to come talk with you.

paragraphs.original:
I have a salt and sorry rheum offends me.
Lend me thy handkerchief.
paragraphs.translated: I have a bad cold that's bothering me. Lend me your handkerchief.

paragraphs.original: Here, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: Here, my lord.

paragraphs.original: That which I gave you.
paragraphs.translated: No, the one I gave you.

paragraphs.original: I have it not about me.
paragraphs.translated: I don't have it with me.

paragraphs.original: Not?
paragraphs.translated: You don't?

paragraphs.original: No, indeed, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: No, my lord.

paragraphs.original:
That's a fault. That handkerchief
Did an Egyptian to my mother give,
She was a charmer and could almost read
paragraphs.translated: That's not good. An Egyptian woman gave that handkerchief to my mother. She was a witch, and she could

paragraphs.original:
The thoughts of people. She told her, while she kept it
'Twould make her amiable and subdue my father
Entirely to her love, but if she lost it
Or made gift of it, my father's eye
Should hold her loathèd and his spirits should hunt
After new fancies. She, dying, gave it me
And bid me, when my fate would have me wived,
To give it her. I did so, and take heed on 't,
Make it a darling like your precious eye.
To lose 't or give 't away were such perdition
As nothing else could match.
paragraphs.translated: almost read people's thoughts. She told my mother that as long as she kept it with her, my father would love and desire her. But if she lost it or gave it away, my father would start hating her and looking at other women. When she was dying she gave it to me and told me to give it to my wife when I got married. I did. So pay attention. Treat it as something precious. Losing it or giving it away would be an unspeakable loss, a loss like none other.

paragraphs.original: Is 't possible?
paragraphs.translated: Is that possible?

paragraphs.original:
'Tis true. There's magic in the web of it.
A sibyl, that had numbered in the world
The sun to course two hundred compasses,
In her prophetic fury sewed the work.
The worms were hallowed that did breed the silk,
And it was dyed in mummy which the skillful
Conserved of maidens' hearts.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, it's true. There's magic in its fabric. A two-hundred-year-old witch sewed it while she was in a fevered trance. The silk came from sacred silkworms, and it was dyed with fluid made from embalmed virgins' hearts.

paragraphs.original: Indeed? Is 't true?
paragraphs.translated: Really? Is that true?

paragraphs.original: Most veritable, therefore look to 't well.
paragraphs.translated: It's absolutely true, so take good care of it.

paragraphs.original: Then would to Heaven that I had never seen 't!
paragraphs.translated: I wish I had never seen it!

paragraphs.original: Ha! Wherefore?
paragraphs.translated: Ha! Why?

paragraphs.original: Why do you speak so startingly and rash?
paragraphs.translated: Why are you yelling at me so angrily?

paragraphs.original: Is 't lost? Is 't gone? Speak, is 't out o' th' way?
paragraphs.translated: Is it lost? Is it gone? Tell me, is it missing?

paragraphs.original: Bless us!
paragraphs.translated: God help me!

paragraphs.original: Say you?
paragraphs.translated: What do you have to say for yourself?

paragraphs.original: It is not lost, but what and if it were?
paragraphs.translated: It's not lost, but what if it were?

paragraphs.original: How!
paragraphs.translated: What do you mean?

paragraphs.original: I say, it is not lost.
paragraphs.translated: I'm telling you, it's not lost.

paragraphs.original: Fetch 't, let me see 't.
paragraphs.translated: Then bring it here. Let me see it.

paragraphs.original:
Why, so I can, sir, but I will not now.
This is a trick to put me from my suit.
Pray you, let Cassio be received again.
paragraphs.translated: I could, sir. But I don't want to now. This is just a trick to take my mind off what I'm asking you for. Please hire Cassio again.

paragraphs.original: Fetch me the handkerchief - my mind misgives.
paragraphs.translated: Bring me the handkerchief - My mind is full of doubt.

paragraphs.original:
Come, come,
You'll never meet a more sufficient man.
paragraphs.translated: Come on. You know you'll never find a more capable man.

paragraphs.original: The handkerchief!
paragraphs.translated: The handkerchief!

paragraphs.original:
A man that all his time
Hath founded his good fortunes on your love,
Shared dangers with you -
paragraphs.translated: He's counted on your friendship for his success. He's shared dangers with you -

paragraphs.original: The handkerchief!
paragraphs.translated: The handkerchief!

paragraphs.original: In sooth, you are to blame.
paragraphs.translated: Really, I don't think you're behaving very well.

paragraphs.original: Away!
paragraphs.translated: Damn it!

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: OTHELLO exits.

paragraphs.original: Is not this man jealous?
paragraphs.translated: And you say he's not jealous?

paragraphs.original:
I ne'er saw this before.
Sure, there's some wonder in this handkerchief,
I am most unhappy in the loss of it.
paragraphs.translated: I never saw him like this before. There must be some magic in that handkerchief. I'm miserable that I lost it.

paragraphs.original:
'Tis not a year or two shows us a man.
They are all but stomachs, and we all but food.
To eat us hungerly, and when they are full,
They belch us. Look you, Cassio and my husband!
paragraphs.translated: Men are all the same, but it takes longer than a year or two to see how bad they are. They're like stomachs and we're just the food. They eat us up hungrily, and when they're full, they vomit us up. Look, here comes Cassio and my husband.

paragraphs.original: Enter CASSIO and IAGO
paragraphs.translated: IAGO and CASSIO enter.

paragraphs.original:
There is no other way. 'Tis she must do 't,
And, lo, the happiness! Go and importune her.
paragraphs.translated: There's no other way. She's the one who's got to do it. And what luck, she's here! Go ahead and ask her.

paragraphs.original: How now, good Cassio, what's the news with you?
paragraphs.translated: Hello, Cassio. How are you?

paragraphs.original:
Madam, my former suit. I do beseech you
That by your virtuous means I may again
Exist, and be a member of his love
Whom I, with all the office of my heart
Entirely honor. I would not be delayed.
If my offence be of such mortal kind
That nor my service past, nor present sorrows,
Nor purposed merit in futurity,
Can ransom me into his love again,
But to know so must be my benefit.
So shall I clothe me in a forced content,
And shut myself up in some other course,
To fortune's alms.
paragraphs.translated: Nothing, madam. Just my earlier request. I'm begging you to help me get back on his good side. I'm devoted to him with all my heart. I can't wait any longer. If my wrongdoing was so serious that I can't get back into his good graces either by my past service, or my present situation, or the promise of devoted service in the future, just knowing that would help me. Then I could stop wondering, and find some other career.

paragraphs.original:
Alas, thrice-gentle Cassio,
My advocation is not now in tune.
My lord is not my lord, nor should I know him
Were he in favor as in humor altered.
So help me every spirit sanctified
As I have spoken for you all my best
And stood within the blank of his displeasure
For my free speech. You must awhile be patient.
What I can do I will, and more I will
Than for myself I dare. Let that suffice you.
paragraphs.translated: I'm sorry, dear Cassio, but now is not the right time to bring up your case. My husband's not himself. If his face changed as much as his personality has, I wouldn't recognize him. God knows I have done my best to argue for you, and made him angry at me for being so aggressive. You'll just have to be patient for a little while. I'll do what I can, more than I'd do for myself. Let that be enough for you.

paragraphs.original: Is my lord angry?
paragraphs.translated: Is Othello angry?

paragraphs.original:
He went hence but now,
And certainly in strange unquietness.
paragraphs.translated: He just left, clearly upset about something.

paragraphs.original:
Can he be angry? I have seen the cannon
When it hath blown his ranks into the air
And, like the devil, from his very arm
Puffed his own brother - and is he angry?
Something of moment then, I will go meet him.
There's matter in 't indeed, if he be angry.
paragraphs.translated: Can he even get angry? It's hard to believe. I've seen him stay calm when cannons were blowing his soldiers to bits, even killing his own brother without him batting an eyelid - is he really upset? It must be about something important. I'll go talk to him. If he's angry, there must be something seriously wrong.

paragraphs.original: I prithee, do so.
paragraphs.translated: Please, do so.

paragraphs.original: Exit IAGO
paragraphs.translated: IAGO exits.

paragraphs.original:
Something, sure, of state,
Either from Venice, or some unhatched practice
Made demonstrable here in Cyprus to him,
Hath puddled his clear spirit, and in such cases
Men's natures wrangle with inferior things,
Though great ones are their object. 'Tis even so,
For let our finger ache and it endues
Our other healthful members even to that sense
Of pain. Nay, we must think men are not gods,
Nor of them look for such observances
As fit the bridal. Beshrew me much, Emilia,
I was, unhandsome warrior as I am,
Arraigning his unkindness with my soul,
But now I find I had suborned the witness,
And he's indicted falsely.
paragraphs.translated: There must be some political news from Venice, or some dangerous plot here in Cyprus has ruined his good mood. Men always get angry about little things when they're really worried about bigger ones. That's the way it goes. When our finger hurts, it makes the rest of the body hurt too. We shouldn't expect men to be perfect, or for them to be as polite as on the weddingday. Oh, Emilia, I'm so inexperienced that I thought he was being unkind, but actually I was judging him harshly.

paragraphs.original:
Pray heaven it be
State matters, as you think, and no conception
Nor no jealous toy concerning you.
paragraphs.translated: I hope to God it's something political, like you think, and not jealousy involving you.

paragraphs.original: Alas the day! I never gave him cause.
paragraphs.translated: Oh no! I never gave him reason to be jealous.

paragraphs.original:
But jealous souls will not be answered so.
They are not ever jealous for the cause,
But jealous for they're jealous. It is a monster
Begot upon itself, born on itself.
paragraphs.translated: But jealous people don't think like that. They're never jealous for a reason; they're just jealous. It's like a monster that just grows and grows, out of nothing.

paragraphs.original: Heaven keep the monster from Othello's mind!
paragraphs.translated: I hope God keeps that monster from growing in Othello's mind!

paragraphs.original: Lady, amen.
paragraphs.translated: Amen to that, lady.

paragraphs.original:
I will go seek him. - Cassio, walk hereabout.
If I do find him fit, I'll move your suit
And seek to effect it to my uttermost.
paragraphs.translated: I'll go look for him - Cassio, stay around here. If he's in a good mood I'll mention you again, and do everything I can.

paragraphs.original: I humbly thank your ladyship.
paragraphs.translated: I thank you, lady.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt DESDEMONA and EMILIA
paragraphs.translated: DESDEMONA and EMILIA exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter BIANCA
paragraphs.translated: BIANCA enters.

paragraphs.original: Save you, friend Cassio!
paragraphs.translated: Hello, Cassio!

paragraphs.original:
What make you from home?
How is 't with you, my most fair Bianca?
Indeed, sweet love, I was coming to your house.
paragraphs.translated: Why are you so far from home? How are you, my pretty Bianca? To tell you the truth, I was just going to your house.

paragraphs.original:
And I was going to your lodging, Cassio.
What, keep a week away? Seven days and nights?
Eight score eight hours? And lovers' absent hours
More tedious than the dial eightscore times!
Oh weary reckoning!
paragraphs.translated: And I was just going to yours. You've kept away from me for a week? Seven days and seven nights? A hundred and sixty-eight hours? And lovers' hours are a hundred and sixty times longer than normal ones! What a tedious wait!

paragraphs.original:
Pardon me, Bianca,
I have this while with leaden thoughts been pressed,
But I shall, in a more continuate time,
Strike off this score of absence. Sweet Bianca,
(giving her DESDEMONA's handkerchief)
(giving her
's handkerchief)
Take me this work out.
paragraphs.translated:
I'm sorry, Bianca. All this time I've been depressed and had problems on my mind. When I get some free time I'll make it up to you. (he gives her DESDEMONA 's handkerchief) Sweet Bianca, would you copy this embroidery pattern for me?
(he gives her
's handkerchief)

paragraphs.original:
O Cassio, whence came this?
This is some token from a newer friend!
To the felt absence now I feel a cause.
Is 't come to this? Well, well.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, Cassio, where did you get this? This is a gift from another woman, a new lover! Now I know why you've been staying away from me. Has it come to this? Well, well.

paragraphs.original:
Go to, woman,
Throw your vile guesses in the devil's teeth
From whence you have them. You are jealous now
That this is from some mistress, some remembrance.
No, in good troth, Bianca.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, come on, woman. Stop jumping to silly conclusions. Now you're jealous, thinking that this is from some mistress of mine, but I swear it's not, Bianca.

paragraphs.original: Why, whose is it?
paragraphs.translated: Well, whose is it?

paragraphs.original:
I know not neither, I found it in my chamber.
I like the work well. Ere it be demanded,
As like enough it will, I would have it copied.
Take it and do 't, and leave me for this time.
paragraphs.translated: I don't even know. I found it in my room. It's pretty. Someone is certainly looking for it, and I'll have to give it back. So I'd like it copied. Take it and do that for me, and leave me alone for a while.

paragraphs.original: Leave you! Wherefore?
paragraphs.translated: Leave you alone! Why?

paragraphs.original:
I do attend here on the general
And think it no addition, nor my wish,
To have him see me womaned.
paragraphs.translated: I'm waiting here for the general, and I don't want him to see me with a woman.

paragraphs.original: Why, I pray you?
paragraphs.translated: And why's that?

paragraphs.original: Not that I love you not.
paragraphs.translated: It's not because I don't love you.

paragraphs.original:
But that you do not love me.
I pray you bring me on the way a little
And say if I shall see you soon at night.
paragraphs.translated: But you don't love me. Please, just walk with me a little ways, and tell me if I'll see you later tonight.

paragraphs.original:
'Tis but a little way that I can bring you,
For I attend here. But I'll see you soon.
paragraphs.translated: I can only walk a little way with you, since I'm waiting here. But I'll see you soon.

paragraphs.original: 'Tis very good. I must be circumstanced.
paragraphs.translated: All right, have it your way. I have to make do.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter OTHELLO and IAGO
paragraphs.translated: OTHELLO and IAGO enter.

paragraphs.original: Will you think so?
paragraphs.translated: Do you really think so?

paragraphs.original: Think so, Iago?
paragraphs.translated: What do you mean, do I think so?

paragraphs.original:
What,
To kiss in private?
paragraphs.translated: What, just because they kissed in private?

paragraphs.original: An unauthorized kiss!
paragraphs.translated: An illicit kiss!

paragraphs.original:
Or to be naked with her friend in bed
An hour or more, not meaning any harm?
paragraphs.translated: Maybe she was just naked in bed with him for an hour or so, but they didn't do anything.

paragraphs.original:
Naked in bed, Iago, and not mean harm!
It is hypocrisy against the devil.
They that mean virtuously, and yet do so,
The devil their virtue tempts, and they tempt heaven.
paragraphs.translated: Naked in bed together, but without doing anything? Come on, Iago. That would be like playing a trick on the devil: they'd make him think they're going to commit adultery, but then back off. Anyone who acted like that would be letting the devil tempt them, and tempting God to condemn them.

paragraphs.original:
So they do nothing, 'tis a venial slip.
But if I give my wife a handkerchief -
paragraphs.translated: As long as they didn't do anything, it would only be a minor sin. But if I gave my wife a handkerchief -

paragraphs.original: What then?
paragraphs.translated: Then what?

paragraphs.original:
Why then 'tis hers, my lord, and, being hers,
She may, I think, bestow 't on any man.
paragraphs.translated: Then it's hers. And if it's hers, I guess she can give it to any man she wants.

paragraphs.original:
She is protectress of her honor too.
May she give that?
paragraphs.translated: Her reputation is also her own. Can she give that away too?

paragraphs.original:
Her honor is an essence that's not seen,
They have it very oft that have it not.
But for the handkerchief -
paragraphs.translated: You can't see a reputation. A lot of people don't even deserve the reputations they have. But a handkerchief -

paragraphs.original:
By heaven, I would most gladly have forgot it.
Thou saidst - Oh, it comes o'er my memory,
As doth the raven o'er the infectious house,
Boding to all - he had my handkerchief.
paragraphs.translated: God, I wish I could forget about the handkerchief! What you told me it haunts me like a nightmare - he's got my handkerchief!

paragraphs.original: Ay, what of that?
paragraphs.translated: Yes, what about it?

paragraphs.original: That's not so good now.
paragraphs.translated: That's not good.

paragraphs.original:
What if I had said I had seen him do you wrong?
Or heard him say - as knaves be such abroad,
Who having, by their own importunate suit,
Or voluntary dotage of some mistress,
Convincèd or supplied them, cannot choose
But they must blab -
paragraphs.translated: What if I'd said I saw him do something to hurt you? Or heard him say something about it. You know there are jerks out there who have to brag about bedding some woman. -

paragraphs.original: Hath he said any thing?
paragraphs.translated: Has he said anything?

paragraphs.original:
He hath, my lord, but be you well assured
No more than he'll unswear.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, but he'd deny it all.

paragraphs.original: What hath he said?
paragraphs.translated: What did he say?

paragraphs.original: Why, that he did - I know not what he did.
paragraphs.translated: He said he did - I don't know.

paragraphs.original: What? what?
paragraphs.translated: He what?

paragraphs.original: Lie -
paragraphs.translated: He was in bed with -

paragraphs.original: With her?
paragraphs.translated: With her?

paragraphs.original: With her, on her, what you will.
paragraphs.translated: With her, on top of her - however you want to say it.

paragraphs.original: Lie with her? lie on her? We say "lie on her" when they belie her! Lie with her - that's fulsome. Handkerchief - confessions - handkerchief! To confess, and be hanged for his labor. First to be hanged, and then to confess - I tremble at it. Nature would not invest herself in such shadowing passion without some instruction. It is not words that shake me thus. Pish! Noses, ears, and lips. Is 't possible? Confess! - Handkerchief! - Oh, devil! -
paragraphs.translated: In bed with her? On top of her? I would have thought people were telling lies about her rather than believe he was lying on her. My God, it's nauseating! Handkerchief - confessions - handkerchief! I'll kill him first, and then let him confess - I'm trembling with rage. I wouldn't be trembling like this if I didn't know deep down this was all true. Noses, ears, lips. Is it possible? Tell me the truth - Handkerchief - Damn it!

paragraphs.original: (falls in a trance)
paragraphs.translated: (he falls into a trance)

paragraphs.original:
Work on, My medicine, work! Thus credulous fools are caught,
And many worthy and chaste dames even thus,
All guiltless, meet reproach. - What, ho! My lord!
My lord, I say! Othello!
paragraphs.translated: Keep working, poison! This is the way to trick gullible fools. Many good and innocent women are punished for reasons like this. - My lord? My lord, Othello!

paragraphs.original: Enter CASSIO
paragraphs.translated: CASSIO enters.

paragraphs.original: How now, Cassio!
paragraphs.translated: Hey, Cassio!

paragraphs.original: What's the matter?
paragraphs.translated: What's the matter?

paragraphs.original:
My lord is fall'n into an epilepsy.
This is his second fit. He had one yesterday.
paragraphs.translated: Othello's having some kind of epileptic fit. This is his second fit like this. He had one yesterday.

paragraphs.original: Rub him about the temples.
paragraphs.translated: Rub his temples.

paragraphs.original:
No, forbear.
The lethargy must have his quiet course.
If not, he foams at mouth and by and by
Breaks out to savage madness. Look, he stirs.
Do you withdraw yourself a little while,
paragraphs.translated: No, don't. This fit has to run its course. If you interrupt it, he'll foam at the mouth and go crazy. Look, he's moving. Why don't you go away for a bit? He'll get

paragraphs.original:
He will recover straight. When he is gone
I would on great occasion speak with you.
paragraphs.translated: better right away. When he leaves, it's very important that I talk to you.

paragraphs.original: Exit CASSIO
paragraphs.translated: CASSIO exits.

paragraphs.original: How is it, general? Have you not hurt your head?
paragraphs.translated: What happened, general? Did you hit your head?

paragraphs.original: Dost thou mock me?
paragraphs.translated: Are you making fun of me?

paragraphs.original:
I mock you not, by heaven.
Would you would bear your fortune like a man!
paragraphs.translated: Making fun of you? No, I swear! I wish you could face your bad news like a man!

paragraphs.original: A hornèd man's a monster and a beast.
paragraphs.translated: A man who's been cheated on isn't a real man. He's subhuman, like an animal.

paragraphs.original:
There's many a beast then in a populous city,
And many a civil monster.
paragraphs.translated: In that case there are a lot of animals on the loose in this city.

paragraphs.original: Did he confess it?
paragraphs.translated: Did he confess?

paragraphs.original:
Good sir, be a man,
Think every bearded fellow that's but yoked
May draw with you. There's millions now alive
That nightly lie in those unproper beds
Which they dare swear peculiar. Your case is better.
Oh, 'tis the spite of hell, the fiend's arch-mock,
To lip a wanton in a secure couch,
And to suppose her chaste. No, let me know,
And knowing what I am, I know what she shall be.
paragraphs.translated: Sir, be a man. Every married man has been cheated on. Millions of men sleep with wives who cheat on them, wrongly believing they belong to them alone. Your case is better than that. At least you're not ignorant. The worst thing of all is to kiss your wife thinking she's innocent, when in fact she's a whore. No, I'd rather know the truth. Then I'll know exactly what she is, just as I know what I am.

paragraphs.original: Oh, thou art wise! 'Tis certain.
paragraphs.translated: You're wise! That's for sure.

paragraphs.original:
Stand you awhile apart,
Confine yourself but in a patient list.
Whilst you were here o'erwhelmèd with your grief - 
A passion most resulting such a man - 
Cassio came hither. I shifted him away
And laid good 'scuses upon your ecstasy,
paragraphs.translated: Go somewhere else for a while. Calm down. While you were dazed by grief - which isn't appropriate for a man like you - Cassio showed up here. I got him to leave, and made up an excuse for your trance. I told him to come back and talk to me in a bit, and he promised he would. So hide here and watch how he sneers

paragraphs.original:
Bade him anon return and here speak with me,
The which he promised. Do but encave yourself,
And mark the fleers, the gibes, and notable scorns
That dwell in every region of his face.
For I will make him tell the tale anew
Where, how, how oft, how long ago, and when
He hath, and is again to cope your wife.
I say, but mark his gesture. Marry, patience,
Or I shall say you are all in all in spleen,
And nothing of a man.
paragraphs.translated: at you. I'll make him tell me the whole story again - where, how often, how long ago - and when he plans to sleep with your wife in the future. I'm telling you, just watch his face. But stay calm, and don't get carried away by rage, or I'll think you're not a man.

paragraphs.original:
Dost thou hear, Iago?
I will be found most cunning in my patience,
But - dost thou hear? - most bloody.
paragraphs.translated: Do you hear what I'm saying, Iago? I'll be very patient, but - do you hear me? - I'm not done with him yet

paragraphs.original:
That's not amiss,
But yet keep time in all. Will you withdraw?
paragraphs.translated: That's fine, but for now keep your cool. Will you go hide?

paragraphs.original: OTHELLO withdraws
paragraphs.translated: OTHELLO hides.

paragraphs.original:
Now will I question Cassio of Bianca,
A huswife that by selling her desires
Buys herself bread and clothes. It is a creature
That dotes on Cassio, as 'tis the strumpet's plague
To beguile many and be beguiled by one.
He, when he hears of her, cannot refrain
From the excess of laughter. Here he comes.
paragraphs.translated: Now I'll ask Cassio about Bianca, a prostitute who sells her body for food and clothes. She's crazy about Cassio. That's the whore's curse, to seduce many men, but to be seduced by one. Whenever he talks about her he can't stop laughing.

paragraphs.original: Enter CASSIO
paragraphs.translated: CASSIO enters.

paragraphs.original:
As he shall smile, Othello shall go mad.
And his unbookish jealousy must construe
Poor Cassio's smiles, gestures, and light behavior
Quite in the wrong. - How do you now, lieutenant?
paragraphs.translated: And when he laughs, Othello will go crazy. In his ignorant jealousy, he'll totally misunderstand Cassio's smiles, gestures, and jokes. - How are you, lieutenant?

paragraphs.original:
The worser that you give me the addition
Whose want even kills me.
paragraphs.translated: It doesn't make me feel any better when you call me lieutenant. I'm dying to have that title back again.

paragraphs.original:
Ply Desdemona well, and you are sure on 't.
Now if this suit lay in Bianca's power
How quickly should you speed!
paragraphs.translated: Just keep asking Desdemona, and it'll be yours. If it was up to Bianca to get you your job back, you'd have had it already!

paragraphs.original: Alas, poor caitiff!
paragraphs.translated: The poor thing!

paragraphs.original: Look how he laughs already!
paragraphs.translated: He's laughing already!

paragraphs.original: I never knew woman love man so.
paragraphs.translated: I never knew a woman who loved a man so much.

paragraphs.original: Alas, poor rogue, I think indeed she loves me.
paragraphs.translated: The poor thing, I really think she loves me.

paragraphs.original: Now he denies it faintly, and laughs it out.
paragraphs.translated: Now he denies it a bit, and tries to laugh it off.

paragraphs.original: Do you hear, Cassio?
paragraphs.translated: Have you heard this, Cassio?

paragraphs.original:
Now he importunes him
To tell it o'er. Go to, well said, well said.
paragraphs.translated: He's asking him to tell the story again. Go on, tell it.

paragraphs.original:
She gives it out that you shall marry her.
Do you intend it?
paragraphs.translated: She says you're going to marry her. Are you?

paragraphs.original: Ha, ha, ha!
paragraphs.translated: Ha, ha, ha!

paragraphs.original: Do ye triumph, Roman? Do you triumph?
paragraphs.translated: Are you laughing because you've won? Do you think you've won?

paragraphs.original: I marry her! What? A customer? Prithee bear some charity to my wit. Do not think it so unwholesome. Ha, ha, ha!
paragraphs.translated: Me, marry her? That whore? Please give me a little credit! I'm not that stupid. Ha, ha, ha!

paragraphs.original: So, so, so, so! They laugh that win!
paragraphs.translated: So, so, so, so! The winner's always got the last laugh, hasn't he?

paragraphs.original: Why the cry goes that you shall marry her.
paragraphs.translated: I swear, there's a rumor going around that you'll marry her.

paragraphs.original: Prithee say true!
paragraphs.translated: You're kidding!

paragraphs.original: I am a very villain else.
paragraphs.translated: If it's not true, you can call me a villain.

paragraphs.original: Have you scored me? Well.
paragraphs.translated: Have you given me bastard children to raise? All right, then.

paragraphs.original: This is the monkey's own giving out. She is persuaded I will marry her, out of her own love and flattery, not out of my promise.
paragraphs.translated: The little monkey must have started that rumor herself. She thinks I'll marry her because she loves me. She's just flattering herself. I never promised her anything.

paragraphs.original: Iago beckons me. Now he begins the story.
paragraphs.translated: Iago is gesturing for me to come closer. Now he's telling the story.

paragraphs.original: She was here even now. She haunts me in every place. I was the other day talking on the sea-bank with certain Venetians, and thither comes the bauble and, by this hand, she falls me thus about my neck -
paragraphs.translated: She was here just now. She hangs around me all the time. I was talking to some Venetians down by the shore, and the fool showed up. I swear to you, she put her arms around me like this -

paragraphs.original: Crying "O dear Cassio!" as it were. His gesture imports it.
paragraphs.translated: Saying, "Oh, Cassio," it seems, judging by his gestures.

paragraphs.original: So hangs and lolls and weeps upon me, so shakes, and pulls me! Ha, ha, ha!
paragraphs.translated: She hangs around me and dangles from my neck and cries, shaking me and pulling at me. Ha, ha, ha!

paragraphs.original: Now he tells how she plucked him to my chamber. Oh, I see that nose of yours, but not that dog I shall throw it to.
paragraphs.translated: Now he's saying how she took him into our bedroom. Oh, I can see your nose now. But I can't see the dog I'm going to throw it to.

paragraphs.original: Well, I must leave her company.
paragraphs.translated: I have to get rid of her.

paragraphs.original: Before me! Look, where she comes.
paragraphs.translated: Look out, here she comes.

paragraphs.original: Enter BIANCA
paragraphs.translated: BIANCA enters.

paragraphs.original:
'Tis such another fitchew. Marry, a perfumed one. - 
What do you mean by this haunting of me?
paragraphs.translated: It's a whore like all the others, stinking of cheap perfume. - Why are you always hanging around me?

paragraphs.original: Let the devil and his dam haunt you! What did you mean by that same handkerchief you gave me even now? I was a fine fool to take it. I must take out the work? A likely piece of work, that you should find it in your chamber, and not know who left it there! This is some minx's token, and I must take out the work? There, give it your hobby-horse. Wheresoever you had it, I'll take out no work on 't.
paragraphs.translated: Damn you! What did you mean by giving me this handkerchief? I was an idiot to take it! You want me to copy the embroidery pattern? That was a likely story, that you found it in your room and didn't know who it belonged to. This is a love token from some other slut, and you want me to copy its pattern for you? Give it back to her, I won't do anything with it.

paragraphs.original: How now, my sweet Bianca! How now, how now?
paragraphs.translated: What is it, my dear Bianca? What's wrong?

paragraphs.original: By heaven, that should be my handkerchief!
paragraphs.translated: My God, that's my handkerchief!

paragraphs.original: If you'll come to supper tonight, you may. If you will not, come when you are next prepared for.
paragraphs.translated: If you want to come have dinner with me, you can. If you don't want to, then good riddance.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: BIANCA exits.

paragraphs.original: After her, after her.
paragraphs.translated: Go after her, go.

paragraphs.original: I must, she'll rail in the street else.
paragraphs.translated: Actually, I should. She'll scream in the streets if I don't.

paragraphs.original: Will you sup there?
paragraphs.translated: Will you be having dinner with her tonight?

paragraphs.original: Yes, I intend so.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, I will.

paragraphs.original: Well, I may chance to see you, for I would very fain speak with you.
paragraphs.translated: Well, maybe I'll see you there. I'd really like to speak with you.

paragraphs.original: Prithee come, will you?
paragraphs.translated: Please come. Will you?

paragraphs.original: Go to! Say no more.
paragraphs.translated: Don't talk anymore, go after her.

paragraphs.original: Exit CASSIO
paragraphs.translated: CASSIO exits.

paragraphs.original:
(advancing) How shall I murder him, Iago?
(advancing)
paragraphs.translated:
(coming forward) How should I murder him, Iago?
(coming forward)

paragraphs.original: Did you perceive how he laughed at his vice?
paragraphs.translated: Did you see how he laughed about sleeping with her?

paragraphs.original: O Iago!
paragraphs.translated: Oh Iago!

paragraphs.original: And did you see the handkerchief?
paragraphs.translated: And did you see the handkerchief?

paragraphs.original: Was that mine?
paragraphs.translated: Was it mine?

paragraphs.original: Yours by this hand. And to see how he prizes the foolish woman your wife! She gave it him, and he hath given it his whore.
paragraphs.translated: It was yours, I swear. And do you see how much your foolish wife means to him? She gave it to him, and he gave it to his whore.

paragraphs.original: I would have him nine years a-killing. A fine woman! A fair woman! A sweet woman!
paragraphs.translated: I wish I could keep killing him for nine years straight. Oh, she's a fine woman! A fair woman! A sweet woman!

paragraphs.original: Nay, you must forget that.
paragraphs.translated: No, you have to forget all that now.

paragraphs.original: Ay, let her rot and perish and be damned tonight, for she shall not live. No, my heart is turned to stone. I strike it and it hurts my hand. Oh, the world hath not a sweeter creature, she might lie by an emperor's side and command him tasks.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, let her die and rot and go to hell tonight. She won't stay alive for long. No, my heart's turned to stone - when I hit it, it hurts my hand. Oh, the world never saw a sweeter creature. She could be married to an emperor, and he'd be like her slave!

paragraphs.original: Nay, that's not your way.
paragraphs.translated: But that's not how you're going to be.

paragraphs.original: Hang her! I do but say what she is. So delicate with her needle, an admirable musician. Oh, she will sing the savageness out of a bear! Of so high and plenteous wit and invention!
paragraphs.translated: Damn her, I'm just describing her truthfully! She's so good at sewing, and a wonderful musician. Oh, she could sing a wild bear to sleep! Oh, she's so witty and creative!

paragraphs.original: She's the worse for all this.
paragraphs.translated: All the worse that she stooped this low, then.

paragraphs.original: Oh, a thousand thousand times - and then of so gentle a condition!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, a thousand times worse, a thousand times - and what a sweet personality she has!

paragraphs.original: Ay, too gentle.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, a little too sweet.

paragraphs.original: Nay, that's certain. But yet the pity of it, Iago! O Iago, the pity of it, Iago!
paragraphs.translated: Yes, that's for sure. Oh, it's dreadful, dreadful, Iago!

paragraphs.original: If you are so fond over her iniquity, give her patent to offend, for if it touch not you it comes near nobody.
paragraphs.translated: If you still feel so affectionate toward her, then why not give her permission to cheat on you? If it doesn't bother you, it won't bother anyone else.

paragraphs.original: I will chop her into messes! Cuckold me?
paragraphs.translated: I'll chop her into pieces. How could she cheat on me?

paragraphs.original: Oh, 'tis foul in her.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, it's horrible of her.

paragraphs.original: With mine officer!
paragraphs.translated: And with my own officer!

paragraphs.original: That's fouler.
paragraphs.translated: That's worse.

paragraphs.original: Get me some poison, Iago, this night. I'll not expostulate with her, lest her body and beauty unprovide my mind again - This night, Iago!
paragraphs.translated: Get me some poison tonight, Iago. I won't argue with her, so her beautiful body won't disarm me. - Tonight, Iago.

paragraphs.original: Do it not with poison. Strangle her in her bed, even the bed she hath contaminated.
paragraphs.translated: Don't do it with poison. Strangle her in her bed, the same bed she's contaminated.

paragraphs.original: Good, good, the justice of it pleases! Very good!
paragraphs.translated: Good, good, I like that - it's only fair! Very good!

paragraphs.original: And for Cassio, let me be his undertaker. You shall hear more by midnight.
paragraphs.translated: And let me kill Cassio. You'll hear more from me by midnight.

paragraphs.original: Excellent good.
paragraphs.translated: Excellent, good.

paragraphs.original: A trumpet within
paragraphs.translated: A trumpet sounds offstage.

paragraphs.original: What trumpet is that same?
paragraphs.translated: What's that trumpet for?

paragraphs.original: I warrant something from Venice. 'Tis Lodovico, this, comes from the duke. See, your wife's with him.
paragraphs.translated: I think someone's coming from Venice. It's Lodovico. He must be coming from the duke. Look, your wife is with him.

paragraphs.original: Enter LODOVICO, DESDEMONA, and attendants
paragraphs.translated: LODOVICO, DESDEMONA and attendants enter.

paragraphs.original: Save you, worthy general!
paragraphs.translated: Greetings, good general!

paragraphs.original: With all my heart, sir.
paragraphs.translated: Greetings, sir.

paragraphs.original: The duke and senators of Venice greet you.
paragraphs.translated: The duke and senators of Venice greet you.

paragraphs.original: (gives him a letter)
paragraphs.translated: (he hands OTHELLO a piece of paper)

paragraphs.original: I kiss the instrument of their pleasures.
paragraphs.translated: I'll do whatever they order me to do in this letter.

paragraphs.original: And what's the news, good cousin Lodovico?
paragraphs.translated: What's new, cousin Lodovico?

paragraphs.original: I am very glad to see you, signior. Welcome to Cyprus.
paragraphs.translated: Very nice to see you, sir. Welcome to Cyprus.

paragraphs.original: I thank you. How does lieutenant Cassio?
paragraphs.translated: Thank you. How is lieutenant Cassio?

paragraphs.original: Lives, sir.
paragraphs.translated: Well, he's alive.

paragraphs.original:
Cousin, there's fall'n between him and my lord
An unkind breach, but you shall make all well.
paragraphs.translated: Cousin, there's been a falling out between him and Othello. An unfortunate rift, but you can fix it.

paragraphs.original: Are you sure of that?
paragraphs.translated: Are you sure of that?

paragraphs.original: My lord?
paragraphs.translated: Excuse me?

paragraphs.original:
(reads) "This fail you not to do, as you will - "
(reads)
paragraphs.translated:
(reading) "Don't fail to do this, since you'll - "
(reading)

paragraphs.original:
He did not call, he's busy in the paper.
Is there division 'twixt my lord and Cassio?
paragraphs.translated: He didn't say anything, he's reading. So there's a rift between Othello and Cassio?

paragraphs.original:
A most unhappy one. I would do much
T' atone them, for the love I bear to Cassio.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, unfortunately. I'd do anything to bring them back together, since I really care for Cassio.

paragraphs.original: Fire and brimstone!
paragraphs.translated: Damn it all!

paragraphs.original: My lord?
paragraphs.translated: Excuse me, my lord?

paragraphs.original: Are you wise?
paragraphs.translated: Are you in your right mind?

paragraphs.original: What, is he angry?
paragraphs.translated: Is he angry?

paragraphs.original:
Maybe the letter moved him,
For, as I think, they do command him home,
Deputing Cassio in his government.
paragraphs.translated: Maybe the letter upset him. I think they want him to go home and appoint Cassio governor in his place.

paragraphs.original: Trust me, I am glad on 't.
paragraphs.translated: I'm happy about that.

paragraphs.original: Indeed!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, are you really!

paragraphs.original: My lord?
paragraphs.translated: My lord?

paragraphs.original: I am glad to see you mad.
paragraphs.translated: I'm glad you're insane enough to admit it in front of me.

paragraphs.original: Why, sweet Othello -
paragraphs.translated: Why, sweet Othello -

paragraphs.original:
(striking her) Devil!
(striking her)
paragraphs.translated:
(striking her) You devil!
(striking her)

paragraphs.original: I have not deserved this.
paragraphs.translated: I haven't done anything to deserve this!

paragraphs.original:
