My lord, this would not be believed in Venice,
Though I should swear I saw 't. 'Tis very much.
Make her amends, she weeps.
paragraphs.translated: My lord, no one will believe this in Venice, even though I'd swear I saw it with my own eyes. That was too much. You should apologize. She's crying.

paragraphs.original:
Oh, devil, devil!
If that the earth could teem with woman's tears,
Each drop she falls would prove a crocodile.
Out of my sight!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, you devil, you devil! You can cry all day and all night, and I still won't believe you're sad. Get out of my sight!

paragraphs.original: I will not stay to offend you.
paragraphs.translated: I wouldn't want to stay here and make you angry.

paragraphs.original:
Truly, an obedient lady.
I do beseech your lordship, call her back.
paragraphs.translated: She's obedient - a fine lady. Please, my lord, call her back.

paragraphs.original: Mistress!
paragraphs.translated: Madam!

paragraphs.original: My lord?
paragraphs.translated: My lord?

paragraphs.original: What would you with her, sir?
paragraphs.translated: What do you want with her, sir?

paragraphs.original: Who, I, my lord?
paragraphs.translated: Who, me?

paragraphs.original:
Ay, you did wish that I would make her turn.
Sir, she can turn, and turn, and yet go on,
And turn again. And she can weep, sir, weep.
And she's obedient, as you say, obedient,
Very obedient. - Proceed you in your tears. - 
Concerning this, sir - Oh, well-painted passion! - 
I am commanded home. - Get you away,
I'll send for you anon. - Sir, I obey the mandate
And will return to Venice. - Hence, avaunt!
paragraphs.translated: Yes, you asked me to call her back. See how well she can turn? She can turn and turn, and then turn on you again. And she can cry, sir - oh, how she can cry! And she's obedient, as you say, obedient. Very obedient - keep crying. - Concerning this - oh, what fake emotion! - I am being ordered home - Get away from me, I'll send for you later. - Sir, I'll obey the order and return to Venice. Get away from me, you witch!

paragraphs.original: Exit DESDEMONA
paragraphs.translated: DESDEMONA exits.

paragraphs.original:
Cassio shall have my place. And, sir, tonight
I do entreat that we may sup together.
You are welcome, sir, to Cyprus. Goats and monkeys!
paragraphs.translated: Cassio can have my job. And tonight, sir, I invite you have dinner with me. Welcome to Cyprus. Horny animals!

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: OTHELLO exits.

paragraphs.original:
Is this the noble Moor whom our full senate
Call all in all sufficient? Is this the nature
Whom passion could not shake? Whose solid virtue
The shot of accident nor dart of chance
Could neither graze nor pierce?
paragraphs.translated: Is this the same Moor whom the senate considers so capable? Is this the guy who's supposed to never get emotional, and who never gets rattled, no matter what disaster happens?

paragraphs.original: He is much changed.
paragraphs.translated: He's changed a great deal.

paragraphs.original: Are his wits safe? Is he not light of brain?
paragraphs.translated: Is he sane? Is he losing his mind?

paragraphs.original:
He's that he is. I may not breathe my censure
What he might be. If what he might he is not,
I would to heaven he were!
paragraphs.translated: He is what he is. I won't say anything negative about what he might be. If he isn't what he might be, then I wish to God he were!

paragraphs.original: What? Strike his wife?
paragraphs.translated: Hitting his wife?

paragraphs.original:
'Faith, that was not so well. Yet would I knew
That stroke would prove the worst!
paragraphs.translated: It's true, that wasn't such a nice thing to do. But I wish I could say that's the last time he'll do it!

paragraphs.original:
Is it his use?
Or did the letters work upon his blood
And new-create his fault?
paragraphs.translated: Is it a habit of his? Or did the letter make him emotional somehow, and this is the first time he's done it?

paragraphs.original:
Alas, alas!
It is not honesty in me to speak
What I have seen and known. You shall observe him,
And his own courses will denote him so
That I may save my speech. Do but go after
And mark how he continues.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, it's too bad! It wouldn't be right for me to tell you everything I've seen and heard. You'll see what he's like. His own actions will show you what kind of person he is, so I won't have to bother telling you. Just go after him and watch what he does next.

paragraphs.original: I am sorry that I am deceived in him.
paragraphs.translated: I'm sorry I was so wrong about him.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter OTHELLO and EMILIA
paragraphs.translated: OTHELLO and EMILIA enter.

paragraphs.original: You have seen nothing then?
paragraphs.translated: You haven't seen anything, then?

paragraphs.original: Nor ever heard, nor ever did suspect.
paragraphs.translated: No, and I didn't hear anything either, or suspect anything at all.

paragraphs.original: Yes, you have seen Cassio and she together.
paragraphs.translated: But you've seen her and Cassio together.

paragraphs.original:
But then I saw no harm, and then I heard
Each syllable that breath made up between them.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, but I didn't see anything wrong, and I heard every syllable they said.

paragraphs.original: What, did they never whisper?
paragraphs.translated: Didn't they ever whisper?

paragraphs.original: Never, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: Never, my lord.

paragraphs.original: Nor send you out o' th' way?
paragraphs.translated: Or ask you to leave the room?

paragraphs.original: Never.
paragraphs.translated: Never.

paragraphs.original: To fetch her fan, her gloves, her mask, nor nothing?
paragraphs.translated: Not even to get her fan, or her gloves, or her mask, or anything?

paragraphs.original: Never, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: No, my lord.

paragraphs.original: That's strange.
paragraphs.translated: That's strange.

paragraphs.original:
I durst, my lord, to wager she is honest,
Lay down my soul at stake. If you think other
Remove your thought, it doth abuse your bosom.
If any wretch have put this in your head
Let heaven requite it with the serpent's curse
For if she be not honest, chaste, and true
There's no man happy. The purest of their wives
Is foul as slander.
paragraphs.translated: I'd swear to you on my soul that she's a good, honest person, sir. If you suspect otherwise, stop thinking that right now because you're wrong. If any jerk has tried to convince you she's bad, I hope God curses him. If she's not honest, faithful, and true, then there's no such thing as a faithful wife or a happy husband.

paragraphs.original: Bid her come hither. Go.
paragraphs.translated: Tell her to come here. Go.

paragraphs.original: Exit EMILIA
paragraphs.translated: EMILIA exits.

paragraphs.original:
She says enough, yet she's a simple bawd
That cannot say as much. This is a subtle whore,
A closet, lock and key, of villainous secrets.
And yet she'll kneel and pray, I have seen her do 't.
paragraphs.translated: She says all the right things, but the dumbest brothel-keeper would tell the same story. Desdemona's a tricky whore with a closet full of awful secrets, but still she'll kneel and pray like an honest woman. I've seen her do it.

paragraphs.original: Enter DESDEMONA with EMILIA
paragraphs.translated: DESDEMONA and EMILIA enter.

paragraphs.original: My lord, what is your will?
paragraphs.translated: My lord, what do you want?

paragraphs.original: Pray, chuck, come hither.
paragraphs.translated: Please, dear, come here.

paragraphs.original: What is your pleasure?
paragraphs.translated: What can I do for you?

paragraphs.original:
Let me see your eyes.
Look in my face.
paragraphs.translated: Let me see your eyes. Look at my face.

paragraphs.original: What horrible fancy's this?
paragraphs.translated: What horrible thing are you imagining?

paragraphs.original:
(to EMILIA) Some of your function, mistress,
(to
)
Leave procreants alone and shut the door.
Cough or cry "hem" if any body come.
Your mystery, your mystery! Nay, dispatch!
paragraphs.translated:
(to EMILIA) Go do what you do best, madam. Leave us alone for our hanky-panky, and shut the door behind you. If somebody comes, give a shout. That's your
job, your job. Go on, hurry!
(to
)
job

paragraphs.original: Exit EMILIA
paragraphs.translated: EMILIA exits.

paragraphs.original:
Upon my knee, what doth your speech import?
I understand a fury in your words,
But not the words.
paragraphs.translated: I'm begging you on my knees to tell me what your words mean. I can tell you're furious, but I don't understand what you're saying.

paragraphs.original: Why, what art thou?
paragraphs.translated: Why? Who are you?

paragraphs.original: Your wife, my lord. Your true and loyal wife.
paragraphs.translated: I'm your wife, your true and loyal wife.

paragraphs.original:
Come, swear it, damn thyself.
Lest, being like one of heaven, the devils themselves
Should fear to seize thee. Therefore be double damned,
Swear thou art honest!
paragraphs.translated: Go ahead, swear to that, so you'll be damned to hell for lying. Otherwise the devils will mistake you for an angel and be too scared to grab you. Go ahead, make sure you damn yourself by swearing you've been faithful to me.

paragraphs.original: Heaven doth truly know it.
paragraphs.translated: Heaven knows I am.

paragraphs.original: Heaven truly knows that thou art false as hell.
paragraphs.translated: Heaven knows you're as unfaithful as hell.

paragraphs.original: To whom, my lord? With whom? How am I false?
paragraphs.translated: Unfaithful, my lord? With whom? How am I unfaithful?

paragraphs.original: Ah, Desdemona, away, away, away!
paragraphs.translated: Leave me alone, Desdemona, go away!

paragraphs.original:
Alas the heavy day, why do you weep?
Am I the motive of these tears, my lord?
If haply you my father do suspect
An instrument of this your calling back,
Lay not your blame on me. If you have lost him,
Why, I have lost him too.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, what a horrible day! Why are you crying? Because of me? If you've been ordered back to Venice because of my father, don't blame me. You may have lost his respect, but so have I.

paragraphs.original:
Had it pleased heaven
To try me with affliction, had they rained
All kinds of sores and shames on my bare head,
Steeped me in poverty to the very lips,
Given to captivity me and my utmost hopes,
I should have found in some place of my soul
A drop of patience. But, alas, to make me
paragraphs.translated: If God had decided to treat me like Job, making me sick and covered with sores, reducing me to abject poverty, selling me into slavery and destroying all my hopes, I would have found some way to accept it with patience. But instead He's made me a laughingstock for everyone in our time to point at and scorn! Even that I could put up with. But instead, my wife, who's supposed to

paragraphs.original:
The fixèd figure for the time of scorn
To point his slow and moving finger at!
Yet could I bear that too, well, very well.
But there where I have garnered up my heart,
Where either I must live or bear no life,
The fountain from the which my current runs
Or else dries up - to be discarded thence!
Or keep it as a cistern for foul toads
To knot and gender in! Turn thy complexion there,
Patience, thou young and rose-lipped cherubin, - 
Ay, there, look grim as hell!
paragraphs.translated: be like the fountain that my children and all my descendants flow from, has rejected me! Worse than that, she's polluted herself, so that the fountain is a place where disgusting toads copulate and reproduce! Even the goddess of patience couldn't look at this and be patient - it's too horrifying!

paragraphs.original: I hope my noble lord esteems me honest.
paragraphs.translated: I hope you think I'm faithful to you.

paragraphs.original:
Oh, ay, as summer flies are in the shambles,
That quicken even with blowing. O thou weed,
Who art so lovely fair and smell'st so sweet
That the sense aches at thee, would thou hadst ne'er been born!
paragraphs.translated: As faithful as flies in rotting meat, which give birth to maggots every time the wind blows. You're like a weed pretending to be a flower, so beautiful and sweet-smelling that I ache when I look at you. Oh, I wish you'd never been born!

paragraphs.original: Alas, what ignorant sin have I committed?
paragraphs.translated: Have I done something to offend you without knowing it?

paragraphs.original:
Was this fair paper, this most goodly book,
Made to write "whore" upon? What committed?
Committed? O thou public commoner!
I should make very forges of my cheeks
That would to cinders burn up modesty
Did I but speak thy deeds. What committed?
Heaven stops the nose at it and the moon winks,
The bawdy wind that kisses all it meets
Is hushed within the hollow mine of earth
And will not hear 't. What committed!
Impudent strumpet!
paragraphs.translated: Was someone as beautiful as you meant to be a whore? What have you done? What have you done? Oh, you streetwalker! If I said out loud what you've done, you'd burn up with shame. What have you done? Heaven has to hold its nose when it sees you! The pure moon in the sky has to shut its eyes when you go by! Even the wind that blows over everything on earth is ashamed to visit you. You brazen whore!

paragraphs.original: By heaven, you do me wrong!
paragraphs.translated: I swear to God you're accusing me wrongly!

paragraphs.original: Are you not a strumpet?
paragraphs.translated: So you're saying you're not a whore?

paragraphs.original:
No, as I am a Christian.
If to preserve this vessel for my lord
From any other foul unlawful touch
Be not to be a strumpet, I am none.
paragraphs.translated: No, I'm as honest as I am Christian. If only letting my husband touch my body means I'm not a whore, I'm not a whore.

paragraphs.original: What, not a whore?
paragraphs.translated: What, you're not a whore?

paragraphs.original: No, as I shall be saved.
paragraphs.translated: No, I swear it.

paragraphs.original: Is 't possible?
paragraphs.translated: Is that possible?

paragraphs.original: Oh, heaven forgive us!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, heaven help us!

paragraphs.original:
I cry you mercy, then,
I took you for that cunning whore of Venice
That married with Othello. - You, mistress,
That have the office opposite to Saint Peter
And keep the gate of hell!
paragraphs.translated: I beg your pardon then. I must have the wrong woman. I mistook you for that sly Venetian woman who married Othello. - You whorehouse-keeper.

paragraphs.original: Enter EMILIA
paragraphs.translated: EMILIA enters.

paragraphs.original:
You, you, ay, you!
We have done our course. There's money for your pains.
I pray you, turn the key and keep our counsel.
paragraphs.translated: You're in charge of this hell! You! We've finished our business. Here's some money for you. Please lock the door and keep quiet.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: OTHELLO exits.

paragraphs.original:
Alas, what does this gentleman conceive?
How do you, madam? How do you, my good lady?
paragraphs.translated: What's he talking about? How are you, madam?

paragraphs.original: Faith, half asleep.
paragraphs.translated: I'm stunned, to tell you the truth.

paragraphs.original: Good madam, what's the matter with my lord?
paragraphs.translated: My lady, what's wrong with your husband?

paragraphs.original: With who?
paragraphs.translated: With who?

paragraphs.original: Why, with my lord, madam.
paragraphs.translated: Why, with your husband, madam. My lord.

paragraphs.original: Who is thy lord?
paragraphs.translated: Who's your lord?

paragraphs.original: He that is yours, sweet lady.
paragraphs.translated: My lord is your lord.

paragraphs.original:
I have none. Do not talk to me, Emilia.
I cannot weep, nor answers have I none,
But what should go by water. Prithee, tonight
Lay on my bed my wedding sheets. Remember,
And call thy husband hither.
paragraphs.translated: I don't have a lord. Don't talk to me, Emilia. I can't even cry, though tears are the only answers I could give to all your questions. Tonight put my wedding sheets on my bed, and tell your husband to come to me now.

paragraphs.original: Here's a change indeed!
paragraphs.translated: Things have certainly changed!

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: EMILIA exits.

paragraphs.original:
'Tis meet I should be used so, very meet.
How have I been behaved that he might stick
The small'st opinion on my least misuse?
paragraphs.translated: It's fair for him to treat me like this, very fair. What have I ever done that he has anything to complain about?

paragraphs.original: Enter EMILIA with IAGO
paragraphs.translated: IAGO and EMILIA enter.

paragraphs.original: What is your pleasure, madam? How is 't with you?
paragraphs.translated: What can I do for you, madam? How are you?

paragraphs.original:
I cannot tell. Those that do teach young babes
Do it with gentle means and easy tasks.
He might have chid me so, for, in good faith,
I am a child to chiding.
paragraphs.translated: I don't know. When grown-ups teach little children, they do it gently and easily. He might have treated me like that, because I'm as unused to abuse as a little child.

paragraphs.original: What is the matter, lady?
paragraphs.translated: What's the matter, lady?

paragraphs.original:
Alas, Iago, my lord hath so bewhored her,
Thrown such despite and heavy terms upon her,
That true hearts cannot bear it.
paragraphs.translated: He called her a whore so many times, and heaped up so much abuse on her that good people can't stand to hear it.

paragraphs.original: Am I that name, Iago?
paragraphs.translated: Am I that name, Iago?

paragraphs.original: What name, fair lady?
paragraphs.translated: What name, madam?

paragraphs.original: Such as she says my lord did say I was.
paragraphs.translated: What my lord said I was.

paragraphs.original:
He called her "whore." A beggar in his drink
Could not have laid such terms upon his callet.
paragraphs.translated: He called her a whore. A beggar couldn't have called his slut worse names.

paragraphs.original: Why did he so?
paragraphs.translated: Why did he do that?

paragraphs.original: I do not know. I am sure I am none such.
paragraphs.translated: I don't know. I just know I'm not one.

paragraphs.original: Do not weep, do not weep. Alas the day!
paragraphs.translated: Don't cry, don't cry. What a day this is!

paragraphs.original:
Hath she forsook so many noble matches,
Her father and her country, and her friends,
To be called "whore"? Would it not make one weep?
paragraphs.translated: Did she give up all those chances to marry noblemen, give up her father and country and friends, just to be called a whore? Doesn't that make you want to cry?

paragraphs.original: It is my wretched fortune.
paragraphs.translated: It's just my bad luck.

paragraphs.original:
Beshrew him for 't!
How comes this trick upon him?
paragraphs.translated: Damn him! How did he get such an idea?

paragraphs.original: Nay, heaven doth know.
paragraphs.translated: Heaven knows.

paragraphs.original:
I will be hanged, if some eternal villain,
Some busy and insinuating rogue,
Some cogging, cozening slave, to get some office,
Have not devised this slander. I will be hanged else!
paragraphs.translated: I bet my life some evil busybody, some meddling, lying jerk made up this rumor to get some position. I bet my life on it.

paragraphs.original: Fie, there is no such man. It is impossible.
paragraphs.translated: Nobody's that bad. It's impossible.

paragraphs.original: If any such there be, heaven pardon him!
paragraphs.translated: If there is, then heaven help him!

paragraphs.original:
A halter pardon him and hell gnaw his bones!
Why should he call her "whore"? Who keeps her company?
What place? What time? What form? What likelihood?
The Moor's abused by some most villainous knave,
Some base notorious knave, some scurvy fellow.
O heavens, that such companions thou'dst unfold,
And put in every honest hand a whip
To lash the rascals naked through the world
Even from the east to th' west!
paragraphs.translated: A hangman's noose will help him! Let hell chew him up! Why should he call her a whore? Who's been with her? When has she had the time, the place, or the means to sleep with anyone? How is this at all likely? The Moor is being tricked by some crook, some terrible villain, some rotten bastard. Oh, I wish we could unmask scoundrels like that, and give a whip to every good man to beat them senseless with!

paragraphs.original: Speak within door.
paragraphs.translated: Keep your voice down.

paragraphs.original:
Oh, fie upon them! Some such squire he was
That turned your wit the seamy side without
And made you to suspect me with the Moor.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, to hell with those people! It's the same kind of guy who got you upset and made you suspect I'd cheated on you with the Moor.

paragraphs.original: You are a fool. Go to.
paragraphs.translated: You're a fool. Shut up.

paragraphs.original:
Alas Iago,
What shall I do to win my lord again?
Good friend, go to him. For, by this light of heaven,
I know not how I lost him. Here I kneel:
If e'er my will did trespass 'gainst his love,
Either in discourse of thought or actual deed,
Or that mine eyes, mine ears, or any sense,
Delighted them, or any other form,
Or that I do not yet, and ever did,
paragraphs.translated: Oh God, Iago, what can I do to win my husband back again? Please go to him, my friend. I swear I have no idea why he stopped loving me. Here I'm kneeling to swear that if I ever did anything to destroy his love for me, either by thoughts or actions, or if I ever took pleasure in anyone else, or if I never did love him, or don't love him now - even though he tries to shake me off -

paragraphs.original:
And ever will - though he do shake me off
To beggarly divorcement - love him dearly,
Comfort forswear me! Unkindness may do much,
And his unkindness may defeat my life,
But never taint my love. I cannot say "whore,"
It does abhor me now I speak the word.
To do the act that might the addition earn
Not the world's mass of vanity could make me.
paragraphs.translated: then I hope I have a life of misery! Unkindness is powerful, and his unkindness may kill me, but it'll never destroy my love. I can't say "whore." It makes me sick to say the word even now. I wouldn't do the thing that would make me a whore for all the money in the world.

paragraphs.original:
I pray you, be content, 'tis but his humor.
The business of the state does him offence,
And he does chide with you.
paragraphs.translated: Please calm down. He's just in a bad mood. Political business is bothering him, and he's just taking it out on you.

paragraphs.original: If 'twere no other -
paragraphs.translated: If only that were all it is -

paragraphs.original: 'Tis but so, I warrant.
paragraphs.translated: It is, I promise.

paragraphs.original: Trumpets sound
paragraphs.translated: Trumpets sound.

paragraphs.original:
Hark, how these instruments summon to supper.
The messengers of Venice stays the meat.
Go in, and weep not. All things shall be well.
paragraphs.translated: Those trumpets are calling us in to dinner. The Venetians are waiting for their food. Go in, and don't cry. Everything will be all right.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt DESDEMONA and EMILIA
paragraphs.translated: DESDEMONA and EMILIA exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter RODERIGO
paragraphs.translated: RODERIGO enters.

paragraphs.original: How now, Roderigo!
paragraphs.translated: How are you, Roderigo?

paragraphs.original: I do not find that thou deal'st justly with me.
paragraphs.translated: I don't think you're treating me fairly.

paragraphs.original: What in the contrary?
paragraphs.translated: What makes you say that?

paragraphs.original: Every day thou daff'st me with some device, Iago, and rather, as it seems to me now, keep'st from me all conveniency than suppliest me with the least advantage of hope.
paragraphs.translated: Every day you put me off with some trick. Instead of finding opportunities for me, you seem to be preventing me from making any progress.

paragraphs.original: I will indeed no longer endure it, nor am I yet persuaded to put up in peace what already I have foolishly suffered.
paragraphs.translated: Well, I won't take it any longer. And I'm not going to sit back and accept what you've done.

paragraphs.original: Will you hear me, Roderigo?
paragraphs.translated: Will you listen to me, Roderigo?

paragraphs.original: I have heard too much, and your words and performances are no kin together.
paragraphs.translated: I've listened to you too much already. Your words and actions don't match up.

paragraphs.original: You charge me most unjustly.
paragraphs.translated: That's not fair.

paragraphs.original: With naught but truth. I have wasted myself out of my means. The jewels you have had from me to deliver Desdemona would half have corrupted a votaress. You have told me she hath received them and returned me expectations and comforts of sudden respect and acquaintance, but I find none.
paragraphs.translated: It's the truth. I've got no money left. The jewels you took from me to deliver to Desdemona would've made even a nun want to sleep with me. You told me she got them, and that she promised to give me a little something in return soon, but nothing like that ever happens.

paragraphs.original: Well, go to. Very well.
paragraphs.translated: Well, all right then. Fine.

paragraphs.original: "Very well," "go to"! I cannot go to, man, nor 'tis not very well. Nay, I think it is scurvy, and begin to find myself fopped in it.
paragraphs.translated: "Fine!" he says. "All right!" It's not fine, and I'm not all right! It's wrong, and I'm starting to realize I'm being cheated!

paragraphs.original: Very well.
paragraphs.translated: Okay.

paragraphs.original: I tell you 'tis not very well. I will make myself known to Desdemona. If she will return me my jewels I will give over my suit and repent my unlawful solicitation. If not, assure yourself I will seek satisfaction of you.
paragraphs.translated: It's not okay! I'm going to tell Desdemona my feelings. If she returns my jewels, I'll stop pursuing her and apologize to her. If not, I'll challenge you to a duel.

paragraphs.original: You have said now.
paragraphs.translated: You've said what you have to say now.

paragraphs.original: Ay, and said nothing but what I protest intendment of doing.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, and I'll do everything I just said.

paragraphs.original: Why, now I see there's mettle in thee, and even from this instant to build on thee a better opinion than ever before. Give me thy hand, Roderigo. Thou hast taken against me a most just exception, but yet I protest I have dealt most directly in thy affair.
paragraphs.translated: Well, all right then. Now I see that you have some guts. From this moment on I have a higher opinion of you than before. Give me your hand, Roderigo. Your complaint against me is perfectly understandable, but I still insist I've done everything I could to help you.

paragraphs.original: It hath not appeared.
paragraphs.translated: It doesn't look that way to me.

paragraphs.original: I grant indeed it hath not appeared, and your suspicion is not without wit and judgment. But, Roderigo, if thou hast that in thee indeed, which I have greater reason to believe now than ever - I mean purpose, courage and valor - this night show it. If thou the next night following enjoy not Desdemona, take me from this world with treachery and devise engines for my life.
paragraphs.translated: I admit it doesn't look that way to me, and the fact that you suspect me shows that you're smart. But Roderigo, if you're as courageous and determined as I think you are, then wait just a bit longer. If you're not having sex with Desdemona tomorrow night, then I suggest you find some way to stab me in the back and kill me.

paragraphs.original: Well, what is it? Is it within reason and compass?
paragraphs.translated: Well, what's your plan? Is it feasible?

paragraphs.original: Sir, there is especial commission come from Venice to depute Cassio in Othello's place.
paragraphs.translated: Venice has made Cassio governor here on Cyprus.

paragraphs.original: Is that true? Why, then Othello and Desdemona return again to Venice.
paragraphs.translated: Is that true? Then Desdemona and Othello will go back to Venice.

paragraphs.original: Oh, no, he goes into Mauritania and taketh away with him the fair Desdemona, unless his abode be lingered here by some accident - wherein none can be so determinate as the removing of Cassio.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, no. He'll go to Mauritania and take the beautiful Desdemona with him, unless he gets stuck here for some reason. The best way to extend his stay here is to get rid of Cassio.

paragraphs.original: How do you mean, removing of him?
paragraphs.translated: What do you mean, get rid of him?

paragraphs.original: Why, by making him uncapable of Othello's place: knocking out his brains.
paragraphs.translated: I mean knock his brains out, so he can't take Othello's place.

paragraphs.original: And that you would have me to do!
paragraphs.translated: And that's what you want me to do!

paragraphs.original: Ay, if you dare do yourself a profit and a right. He sups tonight with a harlotry, and thither will I go to him. He knows not yet of his honorable fortune. If you will watch his going thence (which I will fashion to fall out between twelve and one) you may take him at your pleasure. I will be near to second your attempt, and he shall fall between us. Come, stand not amazed at it, but go along with me. I will show you such a necessity in his death that you shall think yourself bound to put it on him. It is now high suppertime, and the night grows to waste. About it!
paragraphs.translated: Yes, if you want to help yourself. He's having dinner tonight with a prostitute, and I'll go visit him. He doesn't know he's been appointed governor yet. When you see him walking by here (as I'll make sure he does between twelve and one) you can nab him. I'll be nearby to help you, and between the two of us we can handle him. Come on, don't stand there in a daze. Come along with me. I'll give you such reasons for killing him that you'll feel obliged to snuff him out. It's nearly dinner time, and the night's going to be wasted. Let's go!

paragraphs.original: I will hear further reason for this.
paragraphs.translated: I want to hear more about this.

paragraphs.original: And you shall be satisfied.
paragraphs.translated: You will. You'll hear all you want to hear.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter OTHELLO, LODOVICO, DESDEMONA, EMILIA and attendants
paragraphs.translated: OTHELLO, LODOVICO, DESDEMONA and EMILIA enter, with attendants.

paragraphs.original: I do beseech you, sir, trouble yourself no further.
paragraphs.translated: Please, sir, don't trouble yourself.

paragraphs.original: Oh, pardon me, 'twill do me good to walk.
paragraphs.translated: I beg your pardon; walking will make me feel better.

paragraphs.original: Madam, good night. I humbly thank your ladyship.
paragraphs.translated: Good night, madam. Thank you.

paragraphs.original: Your honor is most welcome.
paragraphs.translated: You're most welcome.

paragraphs.original: Will you walk, sir? - O Desdemona -
paragraphs.translated: Would you walk out with me, sir? - Oh, Desdemona -

paragraphs.original: My lord?
paragraphs.translated: Yes, my lord?

paragraphs.original:
Get you to bed on th' instant, I will be returned
Forthwith. Dismiss your attendant there, look 't be done.
paragraphs.translated: Go to bed right this minute. I'll be there shortly. Send your maid Emilia away. Make sure you do what I say.

paragraphs.original: I will, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: I will, my lord.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt OTHELLO, LODOVICO, and attendants
paragraphs.translated: OTHELLO, LODOVICO, and attendants exit.

paragraphs.original: How goes it now? He looks gentler than he did.
paragraphs.translated: How are things now? He looks calmer than he did before.

paragraphs.original:
He says he will return incontinent,
And hath commanded me to go to bed
And bid me to dismiss you.
paragraphs.translated: He says he'll come back right away. He asked me to go to bed and to send you away.

paragraphs.original: Dismiss me?
paragraphs.translated: Send me away?

paragraphs.original:
It was his bidding. Therefore, good Emilia,
Give me my nightly wearing, and adieu.
We must not now displease him.
paragraphs.translated: That's what he said. So give me my nightgown, Emilia, and I'll say goodnight. We shouldn't displease him.

paragraphs.original: Ay. Would you had never seen him!
paragraphs.translated: Yes. I wish you'd never met him.

paragraphs.original:
So would not I. My love doth so approve him
That even his stubbornness, his checks, his frowns - 
Prithee, unpin me - have grace and favor.
paragraphs.translated: That's not what I wish. I love him even when he's harsh and mean - Help me unpin this, would you? - I love even his stubbornness, his frowns, his bad moods.

paragraphs.original: I have laid those sheets you bade me on the bed.
paragraphs.translated: I put those wedding sheets on your bed, as you asked.

paragraphs.original:
All's one. Good Father, how foolish are our minds!
If I do die before thee, prithee, shroud me
In one of these same sheets.
paragraphs.translated: It doesn't matter. Oh, how silly we are! If I die before you do make sure I'm wrapped in those sheets in my coffin.

paragraphs.original: Come, come! You talk!
paragraphs.translated: Listen to you! Don't be silly!

paragraphs.original:
My mother had a maid called Barbary,
She was in love, and he she loved proved mad
And did forsake her. She had a song of "Willow,"
An old thing 'twas, but it expressed her fortune
And she died singing it. That song tonight
Will not go from my mind. I have much to do
But to go hang my head all at one side
And sing it like poor Barbary. Prithee, dispatch.
paragraphs.translated: My mother had a maid named Barbary. She was in love, and her lover turned out to be wild and left her. She knew an old song called "Willow" that reminded her of her own story, and she died singing it. I can't get that song out of my head tonight. It's all I can do to keep myself from hanging my head down in despair and singing it like poor Barbary. Please, hurry up.

paragraphs.original: Shall I go fetch your nightgown?
paragraphs.translated: Should I get your nightgown?

paragraphs.original:
No, unpin me here.
This Lodovico is a proper man.
paragraphs.translated: No, just help me unpin this. That Lodovico is a good-looking man.

paragraphs.original: A very handsome man.
paragraphs.translated: He's very handsome.

paragraphs.original: He speaks well.
paragraphs.translated: He speaks well.

paragraphs.original: I know a lady in Venice would have walked barefoot to Palestine for a touch of his nether lip.
paragraphs.translated: I know a lady in Venice who'd walk all the way to Palestine for a kiss from him.

paragraphs.original:
(singing)
(singing)
The poor soul sat sighing by a sycamore tree,
The poor soul sat sighing by a sycamore tree,
Sing all a green willow.
Sing all a green willow.
Her hand on her bosom, her head on her knee,
Her hand on her bosom, her head on her knee,
Sing willow, willow, willow.
Sing willow, willow, willow.
The fresh streams ran by her, and murmured her moans,
The fresh streams ran by her, and murmured her moans,
Sing willow, willow, willow.
Sing willow, willow, willow.
Her salt tears fell from her, and softened the stones
Her salt tears fell from her, and softened the stones
Sing willow, willow, willow - 
Sing willow, willow, willow - 
Lay by these - 
Lay by these - 
Willow, willow - 
Willow, willow - 
Prithee, hie thee, he'll come anon - 
Prithee, hie thee, he'll come anon - 
Sing all a green willow must be my garland.
Sing all a green willow must be my garland.
Let nobody blame him, his scorn I approve - 
Let nobody blame him, his scorn I approve - 
Nay, that's not next - Hark! Who is 't that knocks?
paragraphs.translated:
(singing)
(singing)
The poor soul sat singing by the sycamore tree,
The poor soul sat singing by the sycamore tree
Everyone sing the green willow,
Everyone sing the green willow
She had her hand on her breast and her head on her knee,
She had her hand on her breast and her head on her knee
Sing willow, willow, willow.
Sing willow, willow, willow
The fresh streams ran by her and murmured her moans,
The fresh streams ran by her and murmured her moans
Sing willow, willow, willow.
Sing willow, willow, willow
Her salt tears fell from her and softened the stones,
Her salt tears fell from her and softened the stones
Sing willow, willow, willow. - 
Sing willow, willow, willow
Put these things over there. - 
Put these things over there
Please, hurry, he'll come right away. - 
Please, hurry, he'll come right away
Everyone sing, a green willow must be my garland.
Everyone sing, a green willow must be my garland
Nobody blame him, he's right to hate me - 
Nobody blame him, he's right to hate me
No, that's not how it goes. - Who's knocking?

paragraphs.original: It's the wind.
paragraphs.translated: It's the wind.

paragraphs.original:
(sings)
(sings)
I called my love false love but what said he then?
I called my love false love but what said he then?
Sing willow, willow, willow.
Sing willow, willow, willow.
If I court more women you'll couch with more men - 
So, get thee gone, good night. Mine eyes do itch,
Doth that bode weeping?
paragraphs.translated:
(singing) I told my lover he didn't love me, but what did he say? Sing willow, willow, willow.
(singing) I told my lover he didn't love me, but what did he say? Sing willow, willow, willow
If I chase more women, you'll sleep with more men - Okay, go away now. Good night. My eyes itch - is that an omen I'll be crying soon?

paragraphs.original: 'Tis neither here nor there.
paragraphs.translated: No, it doesn't mean anything.

paragraphs.original:
I have heard it said so. Oh, these men, these men!
Dost thou in conscience think - tell me, Emilia - 
That there be women do abuse their husbands
In such gross kind?
paragraphs.translated: I heard someone say that's what it means. Oh, these men, these men! Do you honestly think - tell me, Emilia - there are women who'd cheat on their husbands in such a disgusting manner?

paragraphs.original: There be some such, no question.
paragraphs.translated: There are women like that out there, no question.

paragraphs.original: Wouldst thou do such a deed for all the world?
paragraphs.translated: Would you ever do such a thing for all the world?

paragraphs.original: Why, would not you?
paragraphs.translated: Why, wouldn't you?

paragraphs.original: No, by this heavenly light!
paragraphs.translated: By the light of heaven, no, I would not!

paragraphs.original:
Nor I neither, by this heavenly light.
I might do 't as well i' th' dark.
paragraphs.translated: I wouldn't either, by daylight. It would be easier to do it in the dark.

paragraphs.original: Wouldst thou do such a deed for all the world?
paragraphs.translated: Could you really do such a thing, for all the world?

paragraphs.original: The world's a huge thing. It is a great price for a small vice.
paragraphs.translated: The world's huge. It's a big prize for such a small sin.

paragraphs.original: In troth, I think thou wouldst not.
paragraphs.translated: I don't think you would.

paragraphs.original: In troth, I think I should, and undo 't when I had done. Marry, I would not do such a thing for a joint-ring, nor for measures of lawn, nor for gowns, petticoats, nor caps, nor any petty exhibition. But for the whole world? Why, who would not make her husband a cuckold to make him a monarch? I should venture purgatory for 't.
paragraphs.translated: Actually I think I would, and then I'd undo it after I did it. I wouldn't do it for a nice ring, or fine linen, or pretty gowns or petticoats or hats. But for the whole world? Who wouldn't cheat on her husband to make him king? I'd risk my soul for that.

paragraphs.original:
Beshrew me, if I would do such a wrong
For the whole world.
paragraphs.translated: I'd never do such a bad thing, not for the whole world!

paragraphs.original: Why the wrong is but a wrong i' th' world, and having the world for your labor, 'tis a wrong in your own world, and you might quickly make it right.
paragraphs.translated: Why, a bad action is just a wrong in this world, but when you've won the whole world, it's a wrong in your own world, so you can make it right then.

paragraphs.original: I do not think there is any such woman.
paragraphs.translated: I don't think any woman like that exists.

paragraphs.original:
Yes, a dozen, and as many to th' vantage as would store the world they played for.
But I do think it is their husbands' faults
If wives do fall. Say that they slack their duties
paragraphs.translated: Yes, a dozen of them - as many as there are women in the world, in fact. But I do think it's the husband's fault if we wives cheat on them. For instance, our husbands

paragraphs.original:
And pour our treasures into foreign laps,
Or else break out in peevish jealousies,
Throwing restraint upon us. Or say they strike us,
Or scant our former having in despite.
Why, we have galls, and though we have some grace,
Yet have we some revenge. Let husbands know
Their wives have sense like them. They see and smell
And have their palates both for sweet and sour,
As husbands have. What is it that they do
When they change us for others? Is it sport?
I think it is. And doth affection breed it?
I think it doth. Is 't frailty that thus errs?
It is so too. And have not we affections,
Desires for sport, and frailty, as men have?
Then let them use us well, else let them know,
The ills we do, their ills instruct us so.
paragraphs.translated: may stop sleeping with us, and give it out to other women instead. Or they may get insanely jealous, and keep us from going anywhere. Or let's say they hit us, or cut back on the money they give us out of spite. We have feelings. We may be able to forgive them, but we want to get back at them too. Husbands need to know that their wives are human beings too. They see, smell, and taste sweet and sour just like their husbands. Why do they replace us with other women? Do they do it for fun? I think they do. Is it out of lust? I think so. Is it a weakness? It is. And don't we have passions, and a taste for fun, and weaknesses, just like men? Then tell them to treat us well. Or let them figure out that the bad things we do are just what we learned from them.

paragraphs.original:
Good night, good night. Heaven me such uses send,
Not to pick bad from bad, but by bad mend!
paragraphs.translated: Good night, good night. I pray that God will let me learn from women like that - not to follow their bad example, but to avoid it!

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter IAGO and RODERIGO
paragraphs.translated: IAGO and RODERIGO enter.

paragraphs.original:
Here, stand behind this bulk, straight will he come.
Wear thy good rapier bare, and put it home.
Quick, quick! Fear nothing. I'll be at thy elbow.
It makes us, or it mars us. Think on that,
And fix most firm thy resolution.
paragraphs.translated: Here, stand behind this wall; he'll come right away. Keep your sword out, and then stick it in as far as it'll go. Quick, quick. Don't be afraid. I'll be right next to you. This will either make us or break us. Keep that in mind, and be steady.

paragraphs.original: Be near at hand, I may miscarry in 't.
paragraphs.translated: Stay right near me. I may mess it up.

paragraphs.original: Here, at thy hand. Be bold, and take thy stand.
paragraphs.translated: I'm right behind you. Be bold, and get ready.

paragraphs.original: Withdraws
paragraphs.translated: IAGO moves aside.

paragraphs.original:
I have no great devotion to the deed
And yet he hath given me satisfying reasons.
'Tis but a man gone. Forth, my sword: he dies.
paragraphs.translated: I don't really want to do this, but he's given me good reasons. I guess it's only one man - no big deal. My sword comes out, and he dies.

paragraphs.original:
(aside) I have rubbed this young quat almost to the sense,
(aside)
And he grows angry. Now, whether he kill Cassio
Or Cassio him, or each do kill the other,
Every way makes my gain. Live Roderigo,
He calls me to a restitution large
Of gold and jewels that I bobbed from him
As gifts to Desdemona.
It must not be. If Cassio do remain
He hath a daily beauty in his life
That makes me ugly. And besides, the Moor
May unfold me to him - there stand I in much peril.
No, he must die. But so, I hear him coming.
paragraphs.translated:
(to himself) I've rubbed this young pimple until he's ready to pop, and now he's angry. Whether he kills Cassio, or Cassio kills him, or they kill each other, it all works in my favor. If Roderigo survives, though, he'll ask me for all the gold and jewelry that I stole from him and said I gave to Desdemona. I can't let that happen. If Cassio survives,he's so handsome and well-spoken that he makes me look ugly. And besides, the Moor might tell him about my lies about him. - That would be very dangerous for me. No, he's got to die. Let it be so. I hear him coming.
(to himself)

paragraphs.original: Enter CASSIO
paragraphs.translated: CASSIO enters.

paragraphs.original: I know his gait, 'tis he. - Villain, thou diest!
paragraphs.translated: I know the sound of his walk. - Die, villain!

paragraphs.original: Thrusts at CASSIO
paragraphs.translated: RODERIGO thrusts his sword at CASSIO.

paragraphs.original:
That thrust had been mine enemy indeed
But that my coat is better than thou know'st
I will make proof of thine.
paragraphs.translated: That thrust might really have hurt me if I didn't have this armor on under my cloak. Now let's see what you've got on.

paragraphs.original: Draws, and wounds RODERIGO
paragraphs.translated:
CASSIOdraws his sword and stabs Roderigo.

Roderigo

paragraphs.original: Oh, I am slain!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, I'm dead!

paragraphs.original: IAGO from behind wounds CASSIO in the legs, exits
paragraphs.translated: From behind, IAGO stabs CASSIO in the leg and then exits.

paragraphs.original: I am maimed for ever. Help, ho! Murder! Murder!
paragraphs.translated: I'll be crippled forever! Help! Murder! murder!

paragraphs.original: Enter OTHELLO
paragraphs.translated: OTHELLO enters.

paragraphs.original: The voice of Cassio. Iago keeps his word.
paragraphs.translated: That's Cassio's voice. Iago has kept his word.

paragraphs.original: Oh, villain that I am!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, what a villain I am!

paragraphs.original: It is even so.
paragraphs.translated: That's the truth.

paragraphs.original: Oh, help, ho! Light! A surgeon!
paragraphs.translated: Help me! Get some light! Get me a surgeon!

paragraphs.original:
'Tis he. Oh, brave Iago, honest and just,
That hast such noble sense of thy friend's wrong!
paragraphs.translated: It's him! Brave Iago, how honest and trustworthy you are! You even went as far as murder to help your friend in his misfortune. You teach me how I should act.

paragraphs.original:
Thou teachest me. Minion, your dear lies dead,
And your unblest fate hies. Strumpet, I come.
For, of my heart, those charms, thine eyes, are blotted.
Thy bed, lust-stained, shall with lust's blood be spotted.
paragraphs.translated: Whore, your lover's dead now, and you'll be going to hell soon. I'm coming, slut! I've shut the memory of your beautiful eyes out of my heart. You've already stained our sheets with your lust; now I'll stain them with your whore's blood.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: OTHELLO exits.

paragraphs.original: Enter LODOVICO and GRATIANO
paragraphs.translated: LODOVICO and GRATIANO enter.

paragraphs.original: What, ho! No watch? No passage? Murder! Murder!
paragraphs.translated: Help! Isn't there a guard around? No one passing by? Murder! Murder!

paragraphs.original: 'Tis some mischance, the cry is very direful.
paragraphs.translated: Something's wrong, the man sounds panicked.

paragraphs.original: Oh, help!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, help!

paragraphs.original: Hark!
paragraphs.translated: Listen!

paragraphs.original: Oh, wretched villain!
paragraphs.translated: I've acted like such a villain!

paragraphs.original:
Two or three groan. 'Tis heavy night,
These may be counterfeits. Let's think 't unsafe
To come in to the cry without more help.
paragraphs.translated: Two or three men are groaning. But it's dark out, and it could be a trap. It's not safe to go near them till we get more help.

paragraphs.original: Nobody come? Then shall I bleed to death.
paragraphs.translated: Nobody's coming? I'll bleed to death.

paragraphs.original: Hark!
paragraphs.translated: Look!

paragraphs.original: Enter IAGO
paragraphs.translated: IAGO enters.

paragraphs.original: Here's one comes in his shirt, with light and weapons.
paragraphs.translated: Here's someone coming in his pajamas, with a candle and weapons.

paragraphs.original: Who's there? Whose noise is this that ones on murder?
paragraphs.translated: Who's there? Who's shouting "murder"?

paragraphs.original: We do not know.
paragraphs.translated: We don't know.

paragraphs.original: Do not you hear a cry?
paragraphs.translated: Didn't you hear someone shouting?

paragraphs.original: Here, here! For heaven's sake, help me!
paragraphs.translated: I'm here, here! For heaven's sake, help me!

paragraphs.original: What's the matter?
paragraphs.translated: What's the matter?

paragraphs.original: The same indeed, a very valiant fellow.
paragraphs.translated: It is. He's a good man.

paragraphs.original:
Iago? Oh, I am spoiled, undone by villains!
Give me some help.
paragraphs.translated: Is that you, Iago? I'm here, I've been destroyed by villains! Help me.

paragraphs.original: Oh, me, lieutenant! What villains have done this?
paragraphs.translated: Oh, lieutenant! What villains did this to you?

paragraphs.original:
I think that one of them is hereabout,
And cannot make away.
paragraphs.translated: I think one of them is nearby and can't get away.

paragraphs.original:
Oh, treacherous villains! - 
(to LODOVICO and GRATIANO)
(to
and
)
What are you there? Come in, and give some help.
paragraphs.translated:
The treacherous criminals! - (to LODOVICO and GRATIANO) Who's there? Come here and help!
(to
and
)

paragraphs.original: Oh, help me there!
paragraphs.translated: Somebody help me over here!

paragraphs.original: That's one of them.
paragraphs.translated: That's one of them.

paragraphs.original: O murd'rous slave! O villain!
Stabs RODERIGO
paragraphs.translated: IAGO stabs RODERIGO.

paragraphs.original: O damned Iago! O inhuman dog!
paragraphs.translated: Damned Iago! You inhuman dog!

paragraphs.original:
Kill men i' th' dark! Where be these bloody thieves?
How silent is this town! - Ho! murder! murder! - 
What may you be? Are you of good or evil?
paragraphs.translated: Killing men in the dark? Where are these murderers? This is such a quiet, sleepy town! - Murder, murder! - Who's that coming? Are you good or evil?

paragraphs.original: As you shall prove us, praise us.
paragraphs.translated: Judge for yourself.

paragraphs.original: Signior Lodovico?
paragraphs.translated: Signor Lodovico?

paragraphs.original: He, sir.
paragraphs.translated: That's me.

paragraphs.original: I cry you mercy. Here's Cassio hurt by villains.
paragraphs.translated: I beg your pardon. Cassio's been wounded.

paragraphs.original: Cassio!
paragraphs.translated: Cassio!

paragraphs.original: How is 't, brother!
paragraphs.translated: How are you doing, brother?

paragraphs.original: My leg is cut in two.
paragraphs.translated: My leg's been cut in two.

paragraphs.original:
Marry, heaven forbid!
Light, gentlemen, I'll bind it with my shirt.
paragraphs.translated: God forbid! Bring me some light, gentlemen, I'll bind the wound with my shirt.

paragraphs.original: Enter BIANCA
paragraphs.translated: BIANCA enters.

paragraphs.original: What is the matter, ho? Who is 't that cried?
paragraphs.translated: What's the matter? Who's shouting?

paragraphs.original: Who is 't that cried?
paragraphs.translated: Who's shouting?

paragraphs.original:
Oh, my dear Cassio!
My sweet Cassio! O Cassio, Cassio, Cassio!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, my dear Cassio! My sweet Cassio! Oh, Cassio, Cassio, Cassio!

paragraphs.original:
O notable strumpet! Cassio, may you suspect
Who they should be that have thus mangled you?
paragraphs.translated: You notorious whore! Cassio, do you know who might have stabbed you like this?

paragraphs.original: No.
paragraphs.translated: No.

paragraphs.original: I am sorry to find you thus. I have been to seek you.
paragraphs.translated: I'm sorry to find you like this. I've been looking all over for you.

paragraphs.original:
Lend me a garter. So. - Oh, for a chair,
To bear him easily hence!
paragraphs.translated: Lend me your sash - Oh, if we only had a stretcher to carry him out of here!

paragraphs.original: Alas, he faints! O Cassio, Cassio, Cassio!
paragraphs.translated: He's fainted! Oh Cassio, Cassio, Cassio!

paragraphs.original:
Gentlemen all, I do suspect this trash
To be a party in this injury. - 
Patience awhile, good Cassio. - Come, come,
Lend me a light. Know we this face or no?
Alas, my friend and my dear countryman
Roderigo! No - yes, sure! Yes, 'tis Roderigo.
paragraphs.translated: Sir, I believe this piece of trash, Bianca, has something to do with all this trouble. - Hang in there, Cassio. - Come here, bring the light. Do you recognize this face? Oh, no, it's my friend and countryman, Roderigo. - Yes, it's Roderigo!

paragraphs.original: What, of Venice?
paragraphs.translated: What, Roderigo from Venice?

paragraphs.original: Even he, sir. Did you know him?
paragraphs.translated: That's the one, sir. Do you know him?

paragraphs.original: Know him? Ay.
paragraphs.translated: Know him? Yes.

paragraphs.original:
Signior Gratiano? I cry you gentle pardon,
These bloody accidents must excuse my manners
That so neglected you.
paragraphs.translated: Signor Gratiano, I beg your pardon. I didn't mean to ignore you - it's just because of this bloody uproar.

paragraphs.original: I am glad to see you.
paragraphs.translated: I'm glad to see you.

paragraphs.original: How do you, Cassio? - Oh, a chair, a chair!
paragraphs.translated: How are you doing, Cassio? - Someone bring me a stretcher!

paragraphs.original: Roderigo!
paragraphs.translated: Roderigo!

paragraphs.original: He, he, 'tis he.
paragraphs.translated: It's him, it's him.

paragraphs.original: A chair is brought in
paragraphs.translated: A stretcher is brought in.

paragraphs.original:
Oh, that's well said - the chair!
Some good man bear him carefully from hence.
I'll fetch the general's surgeon. - (to BIANCA) For you, mistress,
(to
)
Save you your labor. - He that lies slain here, Cassio,
Was my dear friend. What malice was between you?
None in the world, nor do I know the man.
paragraphs.translated: There wasn't any problem. I don't even know him.

paragraphs.original:
(to BIANCA)
(to
)
What, look you pale? - Oh, bear him out o' the air. -
CASSIO and RODERIGO are borne off
paragraphs.translated: CASSIO and RODERIGO are carried away.

paragraphs.original:
Do you perceive the gastness of her eye? - Stay you, good gentlemen. - Look you pale, mistress? - 
Nay, if you stare, we shall hear more anon. - 
Behold her well. I pray you, look upon her.
Do you see, gentlemen? Nay, guiltiness
Will speak, though tongues were out of use.
paragraphs.translated: Do you see how afraid she is? Watch her, we'll get the whole story. Keep an eye on her. Do you see? The guilty speak volumes even when they're silent.

paragraphs.original: Enter EMILIA
paragraphs.translated: EMILIA enters.

paragraphs.original: Alas, what is the matter? What is the matter, husband?
paragraphs.translated: What's the matter? What's the matter, husband?

paragraphs.original:
Cassio hath here been set on in the dark
By Roderigo and fellows that are 'scaped.
He's almost slain, and Roderigo dead.
paragraphs.translated: Cassio was attacked here in the dark by Roderigo and men who escaped. He's near death, and Roderigo's dead already.

paragraphs.original: Alas, good gentleman! Alas, good Cassio!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, no, good gentleman! Oh no, good Cassio!

paragraphs.original:
This is the fruits of whoring. Prithee, Emilia,
Go know of Cassio where he supped tonight. - 
(to BIANCA) What, do you shake at that?
(to
)
He supped at my house, but I therefore shake not.
paragraphs.translated: He ate at my house, but that doesn't make me nervous.

paragraphs.original: Oh, did he so? I charge you, go with me.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, did he? I order you to come with me.

paragraphs.original: Oh, fie upon thee, strumpet!
paragraphs.translated: Go to hell, you whore!

paragraphs.original:
I am no strumpet, but of life as honest
As you that thus abuse me.
paragraphs.translated: I'm no whore. I'm as moral as you are.

paragraphs.original: As I! Fie upon thee!
paragraphs.translated: As moral as me! Damn you!

paragraphs.original:
Kind gentlemen, let's go see poor Cassio dressed. - 
Come, mistress, you must tell 's another tale.
Emilia, run you to the citadel
And tell my lord and lady what hath happed. - 
Will you go on afore?
(aside)
(aside)
This is the night
That either makes me or fordoes me quite.
paragraphs.translated:
Gentlemen, let's go make sure Cassio's wounds are properly dressed. - Come on, ma'am, you can tell us another story. Emilia, go to the castle and tell Othello and Desdemona what happened. - Will you please go now? (to himself) This is the night that'll either make me or break me.
(to himself)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: DESDEMONA asleep in bed Enter OTHELLO with a light
paragraphs.translated: DESDEMONA is asleep in bed. OTHELLO enters with a candle.

paragraphs.original:
It is the cause, it is the cause, my soul.
Let me not name it to you, you chaste stars,
It is the cause. Yet I'll not shed her blood,
Nor scar that whiter skin of hers than snow
And smooth as monumental alabaster.
Yet she must die, else she'll betray more men.
Put out the light, and then put out the light.
If I quench thee, thou flaming minister,
I can again thy former light restore
Should I repent me. But once put out thy light,
Thou cunning'st pattern of excelling nature,
I know not where is that Promethean heat
That can thy light relume. When I have plucked thy rose
I cannot give it vital growth again,
It must needs wither. I'll smell thee on the tree.
Oh, balmy breath, that dost almost persuade
Justice to break her sword! One more, one more.
Be thus when thou art dead and I will kill thee
And love thee after. (kissing her) One more, and that's the last.
(kissing her)
So sweet was ne'er so fatal. I must weep,
But they are cruel tears. This sorrow's heavenly,
It strikes where it doth love. She wakes.
paragraphs.translated:
I have to do it, I have to do it. I have to keep my reason in mind. I won't say out loud what my reason is, but I have to do it. But I won't shed any of her blood or scar that beautiful skin, whiter than snow and smooth as the finest marble. But she's got to die, or she'll cheat on other men. Put out the light of the candle, and then put out the light of her heart. If I extinguish the candle, I can light it again if I regret it. But once I kill you, you beautiful, fake woman, I do not know the magic that could bring you back. When I've plucked this rose, I can't make it grow again; it will have no choice but to wither and die. Let me smell you while you're still on the tree. (he kisses her) Oh, that sweet breath almost convinces me not to kill you and carry out justice. One more, one more kiss. If you're this beautiful when you're dead, I'll kill you and then love you afterward. (kissing her) One more, and this is the last. Such a sweet kiss was never so deadly. I have to cry, but I have to be cruel too. I'm acting like God in the Old Testament - I have to punish the one I love. She's waking up.
(he kisses her)
(kissing her)

paragraphs.original: Who's there? Othello?
paragraphs.translated: Who's there? Othello?

paragraphs.original: Ay, Desdemona.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, Desdemona.

paragraphs.original: Will you come to bed, my lord?
paragraphs.translated: Will you come to bed, my lord?

paragraphs.original: Have you prayed tonight, Desdemon?
paragraphs.translated: Have you said your prayers tonight, Desdemona?

paragraphs.original: Ay, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, my lord.

paragraphs.original:
If you bethink yourself of any crime
Unreconciled as yet to heaven and grace,
Solicit for it straight.
paragraphs.translated: If you can think of any crime you haven't confessed, then pray for forgiveness right away.

paragraphs.original: Alack, my lord, what do you mean by that?
paragraphs.translated: Oh, my lord, what do you mean by that?

paragraphs.original:
Well, do it, and be brief. I will walk by.
I would not kill thy unpreparèd spirit.
No, heavens forfend, I would not kill thy soul!
paragraphs.translated: Well, hurry up and confess. Be quick about it. I'll wait over here. I don't want to kill you before you've readied your soul. No, I don't want to send your soul to hell when I kill you.

paragraphs.original: Talk you of killing?
paragraphs.translated: You're talking about killing?

paragraphs.original: Ay, I do.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, I am.

paragraphs.original:
Then heaven
Have mercy on me!
paragraphs.translated: Then heaven have mercy on me.

paragraphs.original: Amen, with all my heart.
paragraphs.translated: Amen to that, from the bottom of my heart.

paragraphs.original: If you say, I hope you will not kill me.
paragraphs.translated: If you really feel that way, then I hope you won't kill me.

paragraphs.original: Humh!
paragraphs.translated: Hmmph!

paragraphs.original:
And yet I fear you, for you're fatal then
When your eyes roll so. Why I should fear I know not,
Since guiltiness I know not. But yet I feel I fear.
paragraphs.translated: You're scaring me. You terrify me when you have that look in your eyes. I don't know why I should be afraid, since I haven't done anything wrong. But I'm still afraid.

paragraphs.original: Think on thy sins.
paragraphs.translated: Think of your sins.

paragraphs.original: They are loves I bear to you.
paragraphs.translated: My only sin was loving you too much.

paragraphs.original: Ay, and for that thou diest.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, that's why you have to die.

paragraphs.original:
That death's unnatural that kills for loving.
Alas, why gnaw you so your nether lip?
Some bloody passion shakes your very frame.
These are portents, but yet I hope, I hope
They do not point on me.
paragraphs.translated: You're wrong to kill me for loving you. Why are you chewing on your lower lip like that? You're shaking with emotion. These are bad omens, but I hope, I hope, they don't predict my future.

paragraphs.original: Peace, and be still.
paragraphs.translated: Quiet. Stay still.

paragraphs.original: I will so. What's the matter?
paragraphs.translated: I will. What's this all about?

paragraphs.original:
That handkerchief
Which I so loved and gave thee, thou gav'st
To Cassio.
paragraphs.translated: You gave that handkerchief, the one I loved and gave to you, to Cassio.

paragraphs.original:
No, by my life and soul!
Send for the man and ask him.
paragraphs.translated: No, I swear by my life and soul! Bring him here and ask him.

paragraphs.original:
Sweet soul, take heed, take heed of perjury.
Thou art on thy deathbed.
paragraphs.translated: My sweet darling, don't lie. You're on your deathbed.

paragraphs.original: Ay - but not yet to die!
paragraphs.translated: I am? But I'm not dying yet!

paragraphs.original:
Presently.
Therefore confess thee freely of thy sin,
For to deny each article with oath
Cannot remove nor choke the strong conception
That I do groan withal. Thou art to die.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, right now. So confess your sin freely now. Even if you swear you're innocent of every accusation, you won't change my mind or remove the thought that's tormenting me. You're going to die.

paragraphs.original: Oh, heaven have mercy on me!
paragraphs.translated: Then heaven have mercy on me!

paragraphs.original: I say "amen."
paragraphs.translated: Amen to that.

paragraphs.original:
And have you mercy too! I never did
Offend you in my life, never loved Cassio
But with such general warranty of heaven
As I might love. I never gave him token.
paragraphs.translated: And you have mercy on me too! I never did anything wrong to you in my life. I never loved Cassio, except with the pure love that I feel for humankind. I never gave him any token of romantic love.

paragraphs.original:
By heaven, I saw my handkerchief in 's hand.
O perjured woman, thou dost stone my heart,
And mak'st me call what I intend to do
A murder, which I thought a sacrifice!
I saw the handkerchief.
paragraphs.translated: I saw him holding the handkerchief! You liar, you're turning my heart to stone, and making me call what I'll do murder, when I had been thinking of it as a sacrifice! I saw the handkerchief.

paragraphs.original:
He found it then,
I never gave it him. Send for him hither,
Let him confess a truth.
paragraphs.translated: He found it somewhere, then. I never gave it to him. Tell him to come here. He'll tell the truth.

paragraphs.original: He hath confessed.
paragraphs.translated: He's already done so.

paragraphs.original: What, my lord?
paragraphs.translated: What, my lord?

paragraphs.original: That he hath usèd thee.
paragraphs.translated: That he had sex with you.

paragraphs.original: How? Unlawfully?
paragraphs.translated: What? Had sex with me?

paragraphs.original: Ay.
paragraphs.translated: Yes.

paragraphs.original: He will not say so.
paragraphs.translated: He wouldn't say that.

paragraphs.original:
No, his mouth is stopped. Honest Iago
Hath ta'en order for 't.
paragraphs.translated: No. He won't say anything anymore. Honest Iago's arranged that.

paragraphs.original: Oh! My fear interprets. What, is he dead?
paragraphs.translated: Oh, I'm scared. What, is he dead?

paragraphs.original:
Had all his hairs been lives
My great revenge had stomach for them all.
paragraphs.translated: If he had as many lives as he's got hairs on his head, I would've killed them all in revenge.

paragraphs.original: Alas, he is betrayed and I undone.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, he's been betrayed, and I've been ruined.

paragraphs.original: Out, strumpet! weep'st thou for him to my face?
paragraphs.translated: What, you whore, are you crying for him right in front of me?

paragraphs.original: Oh, banish me, my lord, but kill me not!
paragraphs.translated: Send me away, my lord, but don't kill me!

paragraphs.original: Down, strumpet!
paragraphs.translated:
Down, whore!
Down

paragraphs.original: Kill me tomorrow - let me live tonight!
paragraphs.translated: Kill me tomorrow - but let me live tonight.

paragraphs.original: Nay, if you strive -
paragraphs.translated: No, if you struggle with me -

paragraphs.original: But half an hour!
paragraphs.translated: Just half an hour!

paragraphs.original: Being done, there is no pause.
paragraphs.translated: While I'm doing this, I can't pause for a moment.

paragraphs.original: But while I say one prayer!
paragraphs.translated: Just let me say one prayer!

paragraphs.original:
It is too late. (he smothers her)
(he smothers her)
paragraphs.translated:
It's too late. (he smothers her)
(he smothers her)

paragraphs.original:
(within) My lord , my lord! What, ho! My lord, my lord!
(within)
paragraphs.translated:
(offstage) My lord, my lord! Hello! My lord, my lord!
(offstage)

paragraphs.original:
What noise is this? - Not dead? Not yet quite dead?
I that am cruel am yet merciful,
I would not have thee linger in thy pain.
So, so.
paragraphs.translated: What's that noise? Aren't you dead yet? I know I'm cruel, but I'm merciful too. I don't want you to linger in pain.

paragraphs.original:
(within) What, ho! My lord, my lord!
(within)
paragraphs.translated:
(offstage) Hello! My lord, my lord!
(offstage)

paragraphs.original: Who's there?
paragraphs.translated: Who's there?

paragraphs.original:
(within) O good my lord, I would speak a word with you!
(within)
paragraphs.translated:
(offstage) Oh my lord, I need to speak to you!
(offstage)

paragraphs.original:
Yes, 'tis Emilia. - (to EMILIA) By and by. - She's dead. - 
(to
)
'Tis like she comes to speak of Cassio's death,
The noise was high. Ha! No more moving?
Still as the grave. Shall she come in? Were 't good?
I think she stirs again - No. What's best to do?
If she come in, she'll sure speak to my wife - 
My wife! my wife! what wife? I have no wife.
Oh, insupportable! Oh, heavy hour!
Methinks it should be now a huge eclipse
Of sun and moon, and that th' affrighted globe
Should yawn at alteration.

(within)
(within)
I do beseech you
That I may speak with you, O good my lord!
paragraphs.translated:
(offstage) Please, my lord. I need to speak with you. Oh, my good lord!
(offstage)

paragraphs.original:
I had forgot thee - Oh, come in, Emilia.
Soft, by and by. Let me the curtains draw.
Where art thou?
paragraphs.translated:
I'd forgotten about you - Emilia, wait a moment, let me draw the curtains. (closes the bed curtains) Where are you? (unlocks the door)
(closes the bed curtains)
(unlocks the door)

paragraphs.original: Unlocks the door. Enter EMILIA
paragraphs.translated: EMILIA enters.

paragraphs.original: What's the matter with thee now?
paragraphs.translated: What's the matter with you now?

paragraphs.original: O my good lord, yonder's foul murders done!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, my lord, terrible murders have been committed over there!

paragraphs.original: What, now?
paragraphs.translated: What? Just now?

paragraphs.original: But now, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, just now, my lord.

paragraphs.original:
It is the very error of the moon,
She comes more nearer earth than she was wont
And makes men mad.
paragraphs.translated: It's because of the full moon. It comes too close to the earth and drives men crazy.

paragraphs.original:
Cassio, my lord, hath killed a young Venetian
Called Roderigo.
paragraphs.translated: Cassio's killed a young Venetian named Roderigo.

paragraphs.original: Roderigo killed? And Cassio killed!
paragraphs.translated: Roderigo's been killed? And Cassio's killed?

paragraphs.original: No, Cassio is not killed.
paragraphs.translated: No, Cassio wasn't killed.

paragraphs.original:
Not Cassio killed! Then murder's out of tune,
And sweet revenge grows harsh.
paragraphs.translated: Cassio's not dead? Then the wrong man is dead, and sweet revenge has gone wrong.

paragraphs.original: Oh, falsely, falsely murdered!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, I've been murdered unfairly!

paragraphs.original: Alas, what cry is that?
paragraphs.translated: Oh Lord, who's that crying?

paragraphs.original: That? What?
paragraphs.translated: That? What?

paragraphs.original: Out and alas, that was my lady's voice.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, no, that was my lady's voice.

paragraphs.original: Opens the bedcurtains
paragraphs.translated: EMILIA opens the bedcurtains.

paragraphs.original:
Help! Help, ho, help! O lady, speak again!
Sweet Desdemona! O sweet mistress, speak!
paragraphs.translated:
Help! Help! Oh, lady, speak again.
Sweet Desdemona! Oh sweet mistress, speak!

paragraphs.original: A guiltless death I die.
paragraphs.translated: I'm dying an innocent woman.

paragraphs.original: Oh, who hath done this deed?
paragraphs.translated: Oh, who did this thing?

paragraphs.original:
Nobody. I myself. Farewell.
Commend me to my kind lord. Oh, farewell!
paragraphs.translated: No one. I did it myself. Give my love to my kind husband. Oh, goodbye!

paragraphs.original: Dies
paragraphs.translated: DESDEMONA dies.

paragraphs.original: Why, how should she be murdered?
paragraphs.translated: Why, how could she have been murdered?

paragraphs.original: Alas, who knows?
paragraphs.translated: My God, who knows?

paragraphs.original: You heard her say herself it was not I.
paragraphs.translated: You heard her say it wasn't me.

paragraphs.original: She said so. I must needs report the truth.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, she said that. I must go report what happened.

paragraphs.original:
She's like a liar gone to burning hell.
'Twas I that killed her.
paragraphs.translated: She was lying even as she was going down to hell. I did kill her.

paragraphs.original:
Oh, the more angel she,
And you the blacker devil!
paragraphs.translated: Then she was even more an angel, and you're an even blacker devil!

paragraphs.original: She turned to folly, and she was a whore.
paragraphs.translated: She cheated on me, and she was a whore.

paragraphs.original: Thou dost belie her, and thou art a devil.
paragraphs.translated: You slander her, you devil.

paragraphs.original: She was false as water.
paragraphs.translated: She was fickle and unfaithful, like water.

paragraphs.original:
Thou art rash as fire,
To say that she was false. Oh, she was heavenly true!
paragraphs.translated: You've lost your mind to accuse her of cheating. She was utterly true to you!

paragraphs.original:
Cassio did top her, ask thy husband else.
Oh, I were damned beneath all depth in hell,
But that I did proceed upon just grounds
To this extremity. Thy husband knew it all.
paragraphs.translated: Cassio had sex with her. Ask your husband if you doubt me. If I didn't have a good reason to do this, damn me to the very bottom of hell. Your husband knew about everything.

paragraphs.original: My husband!
paragraphs.translated: My husband!

paragraphs.original: Thy husband.
paragraphs.translated: Your husband.

paragraphs.original: That she was false to wedlock?
paragraphs.translated: He said she was unfaithful?

paragraphs.original:
Ay, with Cassio. Had she been true,
If heaven would make me such another world
Of one entire and perfect chrysolite,
I'd not have sold her for it.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, with Cassio. If she'd been faithful to me, I never would have given her up, not even if God himself offered me a jewel as big as a planet in exchange for her.

paragraphs.original: My husband?
paragraphs.translated: My husband.

paragraphs.original:
Ay, 'twas he that told me on her first.
An honest man he is, and hates the slime
That sticks on filthy deeds.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, he's the one who first told me about her. He's an honest man who detests evil actions.

paragraphs.original: My husband!
paragraphs.translated: My husband?

paragraphs.original: What needs this iterance, woman? I say thy husband.
paragraphs.translated: Why do you keep repeating that, woman? I'm telling you, your husband.

paragraphs.original:
O mistress, villainy hath made mocks with love!
My husband say that she was false!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, my mistress, a villain has made a mockery of your love! My husband said she was unfaithful!

paragraphs.original:
He, woman.
I say "thy husband" - dost understand the word?
My friend, thy husband, honest, honest Iago.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, him, woman. I said "your husband." - Do you understand that word? My friend, your husband, the honest, honest Iago.

paragraphs.original:
If he say so, may his pernicious soul
Rot half a grain a day! He lies to th' heart.
She was too fond of her most filthy bargain.
paragraphs.translated: If he said that, then I hope his malicious soul rots in hell forever. He's lying through his teeth! She was too attached to her filthy marriage ever to do a thing like that!

paragraphs.original: OTHELLO draws his sword
paragraphs.translated: OTHELLO draws his sword.

paragraphs.original: Ha!
paragraphs.translated: Ha!

paragraphs.original:
Do thy worst.
This deed of thine is no more worthy heaven
Than thou wast worthy her.
paragraphs.translated: Go ahead, do your worst. Killing me won't send you to heaven. You weren't good enough for her.

paragraphs.original: Peace, you were best.
paragraphs.translated: You'd better shut up!

paragraphs.original:
Thou hast not half that power to do me harm
As I have to be hurt. O gull! O dolt!
As ignorant as dirt! Thou hast done a deed - 
I care not for thy sword, I'll make thee known
paragraphs.translated: I can endure far more pain than you could ever give me! Oh, you idiot! You stupid fool! As dumb as dirt! You've committed a terrible evil - I'm not afraid of your sword. I'll tell everyone what you did, even if it

paragraphs.original:
Though I lost twenty lives. - Help! Help, ho! Help!
The Moor hath killed my mistress! Murder, murder!
paragraphs.translated: costs me my life twenty times over. - Help, help, help! The Moor's killed my mistress! Murder, murder!

paragraphs.original: Enter MONTANO, GRATIANO, and IAGO
paragraphs.translated: MONTANO, GRATIANO, and IAGO enter.

paragraphs.original: What is the matter? How now, general?
paragraphs.translated: What's the matter? What's going on here, general?

paragraphs.original:
Oh, are you come, Iago? You have done well,
That men must lay their murders on your neck.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, are you here, Iago? You've done a good job, that other men can attribute their murders to you!

paragraphs.original: What is the matter?
paragraphs.translated: What's the matter?

paragraphs.original:
(to IAGO) Disprove this villain, if thou be'st a man.
(to
)
He says thou told'st him that his wife was false.
I know thou didst not, thou'rt not such a villain.
Speak, for my heart is full.

I told him what I thought, and told no more
Than what he found himself was apt and true.
paragraphs.translated: I told him what I thought. I didn't tell him anything that didn't make sense or ring true to him.

paragraphs.original: But did you ever tell him she was false?
paragraphs.translated: But did you tell him she cheated on him?

paragraphs.original: I did.
paragraphs.translated: I did.

paragraphs.original:
You told a lie, an odious, damnèd lie.
Upon my soul, a lie, a wicked lie.
She false with Cassio! Did you say with Cassio?
paragraphs.translated: Then you told a lie, a sick, wicked lie. I swear on my soul it was a lie. You said she slept with Cassio. Did you say Cassio?

paragraphs.original: With Cassio, mistress. Go to, charm your tongue.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, with Cassio. Now be quiet.

paragraphs.original:
I will not charm my tongue, I am bound to speak.
My mistress here lies murdered in her bed -
paragraphs.translated: I will not be quiet! I have to speak. My mistress here lies murdered in her bed -

paragraphs.original: Oh, heavens forfend!
paragraphs.translated: No, heaven forbid!

paragraphs.original: And your reports have set the murder on.
paragraphs.translated: And your lies caused this murder.

paragraphs.original: Nay, stare not, masters, it is true, indeed.
paragraphs.translated: Don't stand there gaping, everyone. It's true.

paragraphs.original: 'Tis a strange truth.
paragraphs.translated: It may be true, but it's unbelievable.

paragraphs.original: Oh, monstrous act!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, what a horrible deed!

paragraphs.original:
Villainy, villainy, villainy!
I think upon 't, I think I smell 't, Oh, villainy!
I thought so then, I'll kill myself for grief.
Oh, villainy, villainy!
paragraphs.translated: Evil, evil, evil! I can smell it! I suspected it earlier. I'll kill myself out of grief! Oh, evil, evil!
