paragraphs.original: What, are you mad? I charge you, get you home.
paragraphs.translated: Are you crazy? I'm ordering you, go home.

paragraphs.original:
Good gentlemen, let me have leave to speak.
'Tis proper I obey him, but not now.
Perchance, Iago, I will ne'er go home.
paragraphs.translated: Good gentlemen, give me permission to speak. I know I ought to obey my husband, but not now. Maybe I'll never go home again, Iago!

paragraphs.original: Oh! Oh! Oh!
paragraphs.translated: Oh! Oh! Oh!

paragraphs.original:
Nay, lay thee down and roar,
For thou hast killed the sweetest innocent
That e'er did lift up eye.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, go ahead and moan, because you killed the sweetest, most innocent woman who ever lived!

paragraphs.original:
Oh, she was foul! - 
I scarce did know you, uncle. There lies your niece,
Whose breath, indeed, these hands have newly stopped.
I know this act shows horrible and grim.
paragraphs.translated:
She was filthy! I barely knew you, Uncle
Gratiano. Here's your niece lying here dead. I killed her with these hands. I know this looks horrible.
Gratiano

paragraphs.original:
Poor Desdemon! I am glad thy father's dead,
Thy match was mortal to him, and pure grief
Shore his old thread in twain. Did he live now,
paragraphs.translated: Poor Desdemona! I'm glad your father isn't alive to see this. Your marriage made him die of grief before his time. If he was alive now, this sight would hurt

paragraphs.original:
This sight would make him do a desperate turn,
Yea, curse his better angel from his side
And fall to reprobation.
paragraphs.translated: him terribly. It would make him curse the heavens and be damned to hell.

paragraphs.original:
'Tis pitiful, but yet Iago knows
That she with Cassio hath the act of shame
A thousand times committed. Cassio confessed it,
And she did gratify his amorous works
With that recognizance and pledge of love
Which I first gave her. I saw it in his hand,
It was a handkerchief, an antique token
My father gave my mother.
paragraphs.translated:
It's sad, but Iago knows she had sex with Cassio a thousand times. Cassio confessed it, and she pledged her love to him by giving him the handkerchief I'd given her. I saw it in his hand.
It was an old memento that my father gave to my mother.

paragraphs.original: Oh, heaven! Oh, heavenly powers!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, God! Dear God in heaven!

paragraphs.original: Zounds, hold your peace.
paragraphs.translated: Damn it, shut your mouth.

paragraphs.original:
'Twill out, 'twill out. - I peace?
No, I will speak as liberal as the north.
Let heaven and men and devils, let them all,
All, all cry shame against me, yet I'll speak.
paragraphs.translated: No, the truth will come out - Me, shut my mouth? Let heaven and men and devils tell me to shut me up. I'll say what I have to say.

paragraphs.original: Be wise, and get you home.
paragraphs.translated: If you're smart, you'll go home.

paragraphs.original: Draws his sword
paragraphs.translated: IAGO draws his sword.

paragraphs.original: I will not.
paragraphs.translated: I won't.

paragraphs.original: Fie! Your sword upon a woman?
paragraphs.translated: Shame on you! Drawing your sword on a woman?

paragraphs.original:
O thou dull Moor! That handkerchief thou speak'st of
I found by fortune and did give my husband.
For often, with a solemn earnestness - 
More than indeed belonged to such a trifle - 
He begged of me to steal it.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, you stupid Moor! I found that handkerchief by accident and gave it to my husband. He'd begged me to steal it many times.

paragraphs.original: Villainous whore!
paragraphs.translated: You evil whore!

paragraphs.original:
She give it Cassio? No, alas, I found it
And I did give 't my husband.
paragraphs.translated: You think she gave it to Cassio? No, I found it and gave it to my husband.

paragraphs.original: Filth, thou liest!
paragraphs.translated: You piece of filth, you're lying!

paragraphs.original:
By heaven, I do not, I do not, gentlemen. - 
(to OTHELLO)
(to
)
O murderous coxcomb! What should such a fool
Do with so good a wife?

Are there no stones in heaven
But what serve for the thunder? - Precious villain!
paragraphs.translated: Won't heaven strike this Iago dead? You absolute villain!

paragraphs.original: He runs at IAGO IAGO stabs EMILIA
paragraphs.translated: OTHELLO runs at IAGO. IAGO stabs EMILIA.

paragraphs.original: The woman falls! Sure he hath killed his wife.
paragraphs.translated: The woman's falling down! He's killed his wife!

paragraphs.original: Ay, ay. Oh, lay me by my mistress' side.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, yes! Lay me next to my mistress.

paragraphs.original: Exit IAGO
paragraphs.translated: IAGO exits.

paragraphs.original: He's gone, but his wife's killed.
paragraphs.translated: He's gone, and his wife's dead.

paragraphs.original:
'Tis a notorious villain. Take you this weapon,
Which I have recovered from the Moor.
Come, guard the door without. Let him not pass,
But kill him rather. I'll after that same villain,
For 'tis a damnèd slave.
paragraphs.translated: He's a wicked, horrible criminal. Take the Moor's sword and guard the door from the outside. Kill him rather than let him leave this room. I'm going after Iago. He's a horrid criminal.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt MONTANO and GRATIANO
paragraphs.translated: MONTANO and GRATIANO exit.

paragraphs.original:
I am not valiant neither,
But ever puny whipster gets my sword.
But why should honor outlive honesty?
Let it go all.
paragraphs.translated: I'm not that strong, if a puny nobody can grab my sword. But why should my reputation for honor last longer than my honor did? Let it all go.

paragraphs.original:
What did thy song bode, lady?
Hark, canst thou hear me? I will play the swan.
And die in music.
(singing)  Willow, willow, willow - 
(singing)
Willow, willow, willow
Moor, she was chaste, she loved thee, cruel Moor.
So come my soul to bliss, as I speak true.
So speaking as I think, alas, I die.
paragraphs.translated:
What did your song mean, lady? Can you hear me? I'll die like a swan. They sing when they die.
(singing) Willow, willow, willow. - 
(singing) Willow, willow, willow
Moor, she never cheated on you. She loved you, you cruel man. I swear on my soul I'm telling the truth, and as I say this, I die.

paragraphs.original: Dies
paragraphs.translated: EMILIA dies.

paragraphs.original:
I have another weapon in this chamber,
It was a sword of Spain, the ice-brook's temper.
Oh, here it is. Uncle, I must come forth.
paragraphs.translated: I've got another weapon in the room. It's a Spanish sword, hardened in ice cold water and razor sharp. Here it is. Uncle, I'm coming out!

paragraphs.original:
(within) If thou attempt it, it will cost thee dear.
(within)
Thou hast no weapon, and perforce must suffer.
paragraphs.translated:
(offstage) If you try that, you'll pay for it. You've got no weapon, so you'll have to suffer.
(offstage)

paragraphs.original:
Look in upon me then and speak with me,
Or, naked as I am, I will assault thee.
paragraphs.translated: Look in on me, and talk with me, or I'll attack even without a weapon.

paragraphs.original: Enter GRATIANO
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO enters.

paragraphs.original: What is the matter?
paragraphs.translated: What's the matter?

paragraphs.original:
Behold, I have a weapon.
A better never did itself sustain
Upon a soldier's thigh. I have seen the day
paragraphs.translated: Look, I have a weapon, the best sword a soldier could have. I've fought my way through obstacles twenty times more terrifying than you with this weapon. But

paragraphs.original:
That with this little arm and this good sword
I have made my way through more impediments
Than twenty times your stop. But, oh, vain boast!
Who can control his fate? 'tis not so now.
Be not afraid, though you do see me weaponed.
Here is my journey's end, here is my butt,
And very sea-mark of my utmost sail.
Do you go back dismayed? 'tis a lost fear.
Man but a rush against Othello's breast,
And he retires. Where should Othello go? - 
Now, how dost thou look now? O ill-starred wench,
Pale as thy smock! When we shall meet at compt
This look of thine will hurl my soul from heaven
And fiends will snatch at it. Cold, cold, my girl,
Even like thy chastity. O cursed, cursed slave!
Whip me, ye devils,
From the possession of this heavenly sight!
Blow me about in winds, roast me in sulfur,
Wash me in steep-down gulfs of liquid fire! - 
Oh, Desdemona! Desdemona! dead! Oh! Oh!
paragraphs.translated: who can control his fate? I'm not like that now. Don't be afraid, even though you see me with a weapon. This is the end of my journey, the end of my life. Are you backing away in fear? There's no reason to be afraid. You could tap me with a feather and I'd back away. Where would Othello go? - Oh, look at you! Such cruel luck! You're as pale as your nightgown! When we meet on Judgment Day, that look of yours will send me from heaven to hell, where devils will grab me. You're cold, cold, and you were never hot with lust. Oh you damned villain! Whip me, you devils, so I don't have to look at this heavenly sight! Blow on me with hot winds, roast me in lava, drown me in liquid fire! Oh, Desdemona! Dead Desdemona! Oh, oh!

paragraphs.original: Enter LODOVICO, MONTANO, CASSIO carried in a chair, and officers with IAGO, prisoner
paragraphs.translated: LODOVICO and MONTANO enter, followed by CASSIO on a stretcher, and officers with IAGO, prisoner.

paragraphs.original: Where is this rash and most unfortunate man?
paragraphs.translated: Where is that poor rash man?

paragraphs.original: That's he that was Othello. Here I am.
paragraphs.translated: You mean the man who used to be Othello? Here I am.

paragraphs.original: Where is that viper? Bring the villain forth.
paragraphs.translated: Where's that snake? Bring the villain forward.

paragraphs.original: IAGO is brought forward
paragraphs.translated: IAGO is brought forward.

paragraphs.original:
I look down towards his feet, but that's a fable.
If that thou be'st a devil, I cannot kill thee.
paragraphs.translated: I'm looking to see if you have cloven hooves like the devil. But that's just a fairy tale. If you are a devil, I won't be able to kill you.

paragraphs.original: Stabs IAGO
paragraphs.translated: OTHELLO stabs IAGO.

paragraphs.original: Wrench his sword from him.
paragraphs.translated: Take his sword away from him.

paragraphs.original: They take OTHELLO 's sword
paragraphs.translated: They take OTHELLO 's sword away.

paragraphs.original: I bleed, sir, but not killed.
paragraphs.translated: I'm bleeding, but you didn't kill me.

paragraphs.original:
I am not sorry neither. I'd have thee live,
For in my sense 'tis happiness to die.
paragraphs.translated: I'm not sorry, either. I want you to live, since to me, death is happiness.

paragraphs.original:
O thou Othello, thou was once so good,
Fall'n in the practice of a cursèd slave,
What shall be said to thee?
paragraphs.translated: Oh Othello, you were once so good, then you were tricked by this villain. What can I say to you?

paragraphs.original:
Why, anything.
An honorable murderer, if you will,
For naught I did in hate, but all in honor.
paragraphs.translated: Say anything. Call me an honorable murderer if you like. I did nothing out of hate, only out of honor.

paragraphs.original:
This wretch hath part confessed his villainy.
Did you and he consent in Cassio's death?
paragraphs.translated: This poor guy's partly confessed his plan. Did you plan Cassio's death with him?

paragraphs.original: Ay.
paragraphs.translated: Yes.

paragraphs.original: Dear general, I never gave you cause.
paragraphs.translated: Dear general, I never gave you any reason to hate me.

paragraphs.original:
I do believe it, and I ask your pardon.
Will you, I pray, demand that demi-devil
Why he hath thus ensnared my soul and body?
paragraphs.translated: I believe you, and I ask you to forgive me. Will you please make this half-devil say why he tricked me and damned my soul?

paragraphs.original:
Demand me nothing. What you know, you know.
From this time forth I never will speak word.
paragraphs.translated: Don't ask me anything. You know what you know. From this moment on, I'll never say another word.

paragraphs.original: What, not to pray?
paragraphs.translated: What, not even to pray?

paragraphs.original: Torments will ope your lips.
paragraphs.translated: Torture will make you talk.

paragraphs.original: Well, thou dost best.
paragraphs.translated: Well, do your best.

paragraphs.original:
Sir, you shall understand what hath befall'n,
Which, as I think, you know not. Here is a letter
Found in the pocket of the slain Roderigo,
And here another. The one of them imports
The death of Cassio to be undertook
By Roderigo.
paragraphs.translated: Sir, you'll understand everything that has happened. I don't think you know now. Here is a letter we found in Roderigo's pocket. And here's another. This one talks about how Roderigo should kill Cassio.

paragraphs.original: Oh, villain!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, you villain!

paragraphs.original: Most heathenish and most gross!
paragraphs.translated: Ungodly and monstrous!

paragraphs.original:
Now here's another discontented paper
Found in his pocket too, and this, it seems,
Roderigo meant to have sent this damnèd villain
But that, belike, Iago in the interim
Came in and satisfied him.
paragraphs.translated: Here's another letter from his pocket, addressed to Iago and full of complaints. We think he was going to send it to Iago, but then Iago stepped in and answered his complaints by killing him.

paragraphs.original:
O thou pernicious caitiff!
How came you, Cassio, by that handkerchief
That was my wife's?
paragraphs.translated: Oh, you wicked scoundrel! Cassio, how did you get my wife's handkerchief?

paragraphs.original:
I found it in my chamber,
And he himself confessed but even now
That there he dropped it for a special purpose
Which wrought to his desire.
paragraphs.translated: I found it in my room, and Iago just confessed that he put it there for his own purposes.

paragraphs.original: O fool! fool! fool!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, what a fool I am!

paragraphs.original:
There is besides in Roderigo's letter
How he upbraids Iago, that he made him
Brave me upon the watch, whereon it came
That I was cast. And even but now he spake,
After long seeming dead - Iago hurt him,
Iago set him on.
paragraphs.translated: Also, in his letter to Iago, Roderigo criticizes Iago for telling him to get me angry while I was on guard duty, and get me demoted. And just now he admitted it, even though he'd seemed to be dead for a long while - Iago tricked him, Iago urged him to do it.

paragraphs.original:
(to OTHELLO) You must forsake this room and go with us.
(to
)
Your power and your command is taken off
And Cassio rules in Cyprus. For this slave,
If there be any cunning cruelty
That can torment him much and hold him long,
It shall be his. You shall close prisoner rest
Till that the nature of your fault be known
To the Venetian state. - Come, bring him away.
paragraphs.translated:
(to OTHELLO)
(to
)
You'll have to leave this room and come with us. You're stripped of your power and your command, and Cassio will govern Cyprus. As for this slave, Iago, if we can think of any torture that will hurt him a lot but keep him alive a long time, he'll have it. You'll remain a prisoner until we bring your crimes to the Venetian government. - Okay, take him away.

paragraphs.original:
Soft you, a word or two before you go.
I have done the state some service, and they know 't.
No more of that. I pray you, in your letters,
When you shall these unlucky deeds relate,
Speak of me as I am. Nothing extenuate,
Nor set down aught in malice. Then must you speak
Of one that loved not wisely, but too well.
Of one not easily jealous, but being wrought,
Perplexed in the extreme. Of one whose hand,
Like the base Indian, threw a pearl away
Richer than all his tribe. Of one whose subdued eyes,
Albeit unused to the melting mood,
Drop tears as fast as the Arabian trees
Their medicinal gum. Set you down this,
paragraphs.translated: Wait. A word or two before you go. I've given the state of Venice a bit of help in the past, and they know it. But enough about that. When you record these sad events in your letters, please describe me exactly as I am. Don't tone things down or exaggerate them out of hostility. If you're being fair, you'll have to describe me as someone who loved too much, but who wasn't wise about it. I was not easily made jealous, but once I was tricked and manipulated, I worked myself into a frenzy. Describe me as a fool who threw away a precious pearl with his own hands, like a silly Indian who didn't know what it was worth. As someone who was not emotional, but who then cried a lot. Write all this

paragraphs.original:
And say besides that in Aleppo once,
Where a malignant and a turbaned Turk
Beat a Venetian and traduced the state,
I took by the throat the circumcisèd dog,
And smote him, thus.
paragraphs.translated: down, and then say also that in Aleppo I once saw a Turk beating a Venetian, so I grabbed the Turk by the throat and hit him like this.

paragraphs.original: Stabs himself
paragraphs.translated: OTHELLO stabs himself.

paragraphs.original: Oh, bloody period!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, what a bloody end to all this!

paragraphs.original: All that is spoke is marred.
paragraphs.translated: Everything we've heard is bad.

paragraphs.original:
(to DESDEMONA)
(to
)
I kissed thee ere I killed thee. No way but this,
Killing myself, to die upon a kiss.
Kisses DESDEMONA, dies
paragraphs.translated: OTHELLO kisses DESDEMONA and dies.

paragraphs.original:
This did I fear, but thought he had no weapon,
For he was great of heart.
paragraphs.translated: I was afraid this would happen, because he was a noble, brave man, but I didn't think he had a weapon.

paragraphs.original:
(to IAGO)
(to
)
O Spartan dog,
More fell than anguish, hunger, or the sea,
Look on the tragic loading of this bed.
This is thy work. The object poisons sight,
Let it be hid. - Gratiano, keep the house
And seize upon the fortunes of the Moor,
For they succeed on you. - To you, lord governor,
Remains the censure of this hellish villain:
The time, the place, the torture. Oh, enforce it!
Myself will straight aboard, and to the state
This heavy act with heavy heart relate.
Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.
